DOC.HEAD: Author of `The Peter Principle' Dies at Age 70
DOC.TEXT: Author Laurence J. Peter, whose ``Peter Principle'' held that bureaucratic problems often occur because employees routinely are promoted beyond their competence, has died. He was 70. Peter, who suffered from heart trouble and a stroke, died in his sleep at his Palos Verdes home, his wife, Irene, said Sunday. Peter and Raymond Hull wrote the 1969 best-seller, ``The Peter Principle: Why Things Always Go Wrong,'' a satirical chronicle of incompetence based on Peter's experience with educational and other bureaucracies. According to Peter, every employee in a hierarchy tends to rise to the level of his or her incompetence. An employee is promoted from position to position as long as he can do his job to his superior's satisfaction. Eventually, however, the employee is promoted to a job he cannot do. And there he remains, a meddlesome, obstructive incompetent. Peter, a psychologist and professor of education, found such people in business, schools, government, churches and political parties. ``The cream rises until it sours,'' he wrote. Over time, Peter said, every post tends to be occupied by someone too incompetent to carry out its duties. The only people who accomplish any useful work are those who have not yet been promoted to their level of incompetence, he said. Peter also described the hazards of ladder-climbing, including ulcers, alcoholism, allergies and ``Tabulatory Gigantism,'' or an obsession with getting a bigger desk than one's colleagues. After hailing his principle as ``the key to an understanding of the whole structure of civilization,'' Peter said he only was kidding. But corporations took him at his word and sent job offers his way. He turned them down, saying he didn't want to rise to the level of his own incompetence. His book sold 8 million copies, was translated into more than 30 languages and is still available in paperback. Hull wrote in the book's introduction: ``Dare you read it? Dare you face, in one blinding revelation, the reason why schools do not bestow wisdom, why governments cannot maintain order, why courts do not dispense justice, why prosperity fails to produce happiness, why your utopian plans never generate utopias? ``If you read, you can never regain your present state of blissful ignorance; you will never again unthinkingly venerate your superiors or dominate your subordinates. Never! The Peter Principle once heard, cannot be forgotten.'' Peter followed ``The Peter Principle'' with eight other books, including ``The Peter Prescription: How to Make Things Go Right'' in 1972 and ``The Peter Plan: A Proposal for Survival'' in 1975. Born Sept. 16, 1919, in Vancouver, British Columbia, Peter worked in the Canadian school system and became a professor at the University of British Columbia. He left in 1966 for a post at the University of Southern California. In addition to his wife, Peter is survived by sons John and Edward, daughters Alice and Margaret and three grandchildren. Funeral arrangements were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Rude, Crude, Lewd, and Sober as Judges
DOC.TEXT: Guitars are still thrashed and arenas trashed, but one thing has changed on Motley Crue's latest tour: The heavy metal bad boys remember what they do. ``We only remember bits of past tours,'' lead singer Vince Neil said in this week's People magazine. Booze, drugs, and more drugs left the band members' memories as fuzzy as their guitar sound, until bassist Nikki Sixx nearly died of a heroin overdose in 1987. The entire Crue checked into a drug rehabilitation program, and now a drug counselor follows them around on tour to help them stay on the wagon, the magazine said. But concertgoers haven't yet mistaken the group for advocates of temperance. ``We don't just play rock and roll, we live it,'' Sixx said. ``We go on tour and get broken bones, diseases, the crowd leaves bloody. It's more like going to war.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: Opposition Plotting To Withdraw From Elections
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said early today that he was concerned the main opposition bloc may withdraw from the election campaign, and accused it of plotting to create a ``situation like Panama.'' He said he told U.N. election monitor Eliot Richardson about his worry that the opposition might pull out of the campaign then call next month's elections fraudulent, setting the stage for eventual U.S. military intervention. Richardson, representative of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, refused to confirm whether this had been a topic of his three-hour meeting with Ortega. The session ended shortly after midnight. This was the first weekend in the campaign that the National Opposition Union, or UNO, the 14-party bloc challenging the ruling leftist Sandinista Front, did not have mass rallies. General elections are set for Feb. 25. In Panama's May elections, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega annulled the results after his candidates were defeated by the opposition slate. The U.S. invaders who ousted Noriega last month installed as Panama's new president Guillermo Endara, who had run as the opposition's standard-bearer in May. The Sandinistas have claimed the United States might be planning an invasion of Nicaragua, a charge American officials have denied. Opposition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, in the United States after receiving treatment in Houston for a fractured knee from a fall at her home, was not expected back until some time this week. Her running mate, Virgilio Godoy, had been out of the country all week and returned Friday. The meeting between Ortega, who is running for re-election, and Richardson was originally scheduled for today but was moved up to Sunday night and started at 9 p.m. Aides on both sides said there had been scheduling problems. ``The main concern that I expressed has to do with the attitude of the North American government, with the Contra activity and also the risk being run should UNO withdraw from the electoral process,'' Ortega told reporters after his meeting in a hotel room. The United States has supported the Contra rebels in their battle with the government in Managua. ``The UNO people have expectations to create a situation like Panama,'' Ortega said. ``Moreover, I know that UNO leaders have spoken with U.S. congressmen who have visited Nicaragua. ``They're not playing fair,'' Ortega said of the opposition, ``because they're working so as to create in Nicaragua a situation similar to that of Panama ... and drag the United States into it,'' Ortega said. Opposition leaders could not be reached immediately for comment. They have repeatedly said they will take part in the elections, but also accuse the Sandinistas of using unfair tactics ranging from intimidation to monopolizing the news media. Last week, the opposition accused the government of blocking about $2 million in direct aid for its campaign that the U.S. Congress approved in October. But over the weekend, Mrs. Chamorro's newspaper, La Prensa, reported that a government minister had agreed to release the money. Richardson, a former U.S. attorney general, was asked about Ortega's claim the opposition might withdraw. He said he did not want to address the question in his U.N. capacity ``but as an observer of the American scene.'' ``I can't imagine the U.S. government exerting any such pressure,'' Richardson said.

DOC.HEAD: Pravda: Important U.S. Spy Caught and Sentenced to Death
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have captured and sentenced to death a diplomat who began spying for the United States nearly 30 years ago, passing classified information on topics ranging from chemical arms to politics, Pravda said. The Communist Party daily did not identify the man or say whether he had been executed. In its report Sunday, Pravda said the man, code-named ``Donald,'' was one of the most important of about 30 Western spies caught by the Soviets in recent years. It said he had confessed, but did not say when he was arrested. In today's editions, The New York Times quoted an unidentified U.S. official in Washington as confirming that an American agent ``from deep within the Soviet bureaucracy'' had been arrested. It said the American official expressed mild surprise that the Soviets had made the capture public. In Washington, a FBI press duty officer, Greg Jones, told The Associated Press he had no comment on the Pravda story. CIA spokesman Bill Devine also refused to comment. ``It's our standard procedure that we neither confirm nor deny such allegations,'' Devine said. The report was apparently intended, at least in part, to enhance the prestige of a KGB official whose name has been mentioned in connection with a corruption scandal. It reserved a glamorous role for the KGB official, Col. Alexander S. Dukhanin, who has been criticized by a legislative commission investigating charges of official corruption extending all the way to Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev. Dukhanin had corruption charges dropped against a former Moldavian Communist Party official who reportedly may have been the sole link between Ligachev and Uzbekistan party officials convicted of taking bribes. Ligachev, 70, reportedly the conservative force on the Politburo, has denied any wrongdoing in the case. Pravda claimed that ``Donald'' began spying for the Americans in November 1961, when he was a high-ranking Soviet representative at U.N. headquarters in New York. He supposedly met an FBI agent, John F., in the street after making his acquaintance at a party. Information changed hands, and the man the U.S. intelligence services code-named ``Donald'' was recruited, Pravda said. It said the Soviet diplomat, with access to classified information on a broad range of topics, supplied it regularly to the FBI and later to the CIA. ``Donald'' gave the Americans political and economic information, data on chemical and bacteriological defenses, and even information about diseases of rice, corn and wheat, Pravda said. Pravda said the purported spy's American contacts had used The New York Times to pass him messages. It quoted what it said was a personal ad in the newspaper on Oct. 20, 1964: ``Moody-Donald F., please write as you promised. Everything is fine with Uncle Charles and sister Clara. They want you to write to them. Don't forget the addresses of Dave, Doug, and their wives. Are you planning to travel? When? Where? We hope that soon our family will be together again. Greetings and best wishes from brother Edward K. and John F. Kloster, New Jersey.'' Pravda said that when Soviet investigators broke the codes, the first line was a reminder about the conditions of making contact with his American contacts, and the second line expressed their willingness to work through two unidentified contacts. During his career, ``Donald'' worked for the CIA in India, the newspaper said, where he was allegedly equipped by a U.S. spy with sophisticated espionage devices that enabled him to send information from unlikely places, for example a bus as it passed by the U.S. Embassy. While in India, ``Donald'' was warned that the CIA had leaked to the media a report that a Soviet official at the United Nations had been recruited as a spy by the Americans in the 1960s, Pravda said. The news put the man on his guard, but he failed to notice he was under heavy surveillance and was caught red-handed in an unspecified act of espionage, Pravda said. He confessed and was sentenced to death, the newspaper said. Pravda said ``Donald,'' asked about why he spied, answered: ``I was so accustomed to walking on a sharp edge that I did not think of a different life for myself.'' In its commentary on the case, Pravda says, suggested that he acted out of ``damaging vanity.'' ``And he was self-assured, too. He didn't believe that he would be caught,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Conflicting Emotions From Victim
DOC.TEXT: For actress Viveca Lindfors, a random slashing on a Greenwich Village sidewalk has only made her more determined to fight back in her own way. ``It's scary because you don't know who the enemy is any more and the attacks are random,'' said author Randy Osofsky, one of the friends with her during early Saturday's attack. ``These are the things that make you want to move out of the city.'' But Ms. Lindfors, who was mugged in 1982, said that would be a mistake. ``We all struggle with those thoughts, we all have fear that says we have to get out of here, but we have to fight back _ you don't want to be kicked out by kids or rats,'' she said. ``This is where we live, me and my children and grandchildren, and we're not going to be kicked out by those bastards.'' The slasher and victim said nothing in the attack, which occurred as she and three friends stood talking in front of an apartment building. ``Suddenly a guy was right in front of me holding my face, and the next second I was lying on the street. I heard screams, `Get him!' and I felt the blood,'' she recalled. And the next day she was wondering, ``Am I going to be afraid to walk the streets now? I hate that feeling.'' Police on Sunday reported no clues about the motive or identities of the small group of marauding young men believed responsible for the slashing and one that occurred a few minutes earlier and a few blocks away. Ms. Lindfors and Dennis Beal, 36, were cut on the face by a member of the gang. Despite the ear and facial wound that required 27 stitches the 69-year-old actress was back on stage a few hours later for a poetry reading. Later, she mixed pity of her attackers with anger. ``How do we fight back? How do we struggle against this kind of thing?'' Ms. Lindfors asked. ``I only know one way, and that is to keep on performing what is of spiritual value to people. ``If I could get into schools and read poetry to these kids, couldn't they turn their passion and that turbulence into the strong life force, use this life force in a positive way?'' Even so, she showed compassion for her attacker: ``I'm coming off easily, compared to him. My ear is cut, but his life is going to be hell if he doesn't face something within himself.'' Ms. Lindfors, a classically trained actress who spent eight years with the Royal Dramatic Theater in her native Sweden, has performed in scores of plays, films and television shows. Her films include ``Night Unto Night,'' in 1948 with Ronald Reagan, ``Four Men in a Jeep,'' in 1948, ``The Way We Were,'' in 1973, ``Welcome to LA,'' in 1977 and ``Creepshow,'' in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Skirts Commonwealth Capital
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Koryn, packing 110 mph gusts, knocked down trees and cut electrical power in the capital of this U.S. commonwealth before moving away today, authorities said. No serious injuries were immediately reported. The typhoon with maximum sustained winds of 85 mph swept past Saipan and was moving to the northeast at 8 mph, said Air Force Maj. Joel Martin, a meteorologist with the Guam-based Joint Typhoon Warning Center Rapid Response Team. As of 4 p.m. (1 a.m. EST), Koryn was 65 miles north of Saipan, Martin said. There were reports of downed trees and power lines before communications were cut with Saipan, Martin said, but added the storm's path ``seemed to have spared them a lot of the heavier winds.'' Forecasters predicted the typhoon would not affect any other islands before it lost power. The winds damaged power lines, cutting electricity on the island Sunday night, said Jean-Louis M. Pierrefeu, assistant executive director for the Commonwealth Utilities Corp.'s power branch. As the storm approached, residents boarded up houses, put boats to sea and moved to shelters, said Civil Defense coordinator Felix Sasamopo. The airport was closed. Conditions on Rota, the most southern of the Marianas, were not known because of poor communications, Martin said. The first island to feel the typhoon was Guam, just to the south of the Northern Marianas. Koryn skirted the U.S. territory to the west Sunday night with heavy rains and 90 mph gusts, knocking out power and sending more than 500 people to shelters. Without electricity, the island's 130,000 residents were without water. By tonight, electricity had been restored to at least 65 percent of Guam and 50 percent of the island had running water, said Ben Reyes, of the Guam Civil Defense. Island residents had been warned to keep a three-day supply of water, Reyes said. All of the people who had sought shelter had returned to their homes except for the 59 members of four families, who were provided emergency housing, he said. Updated reports showed four people suffered minor injuries from the storm, while the tin roofs of two houses were blown off, Reyes said.

DOC.HEAD: Supremacists and Their Foes March on King Holiday Weekend
With PM-King Holiday Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Unable to keep the Ku Klux Klan permanently out of town where it was founded, residents say some good has emerged from the racist group's annual marches against a holiday for Martin Luther King Jr. ``For the first time my community is sitting down and talking openly about problems that exist,'' said Bob Henry, president of Giles Countians United, formed to display the community's rejection of the white supremacist groups that have marched here every Martin Luther King holiday weekend since 1986. ``Pulaski's not a perfect town. We have racism here. We are a town that recognizes its problems and is moving forward and working to solve them.'' Henry's group outmaneuvered the Klan this year, forcing the Klan to hold its march in a neighboring town. About 300 white supremacists marched Saturday in Lawrenceburg, while about 300 counterdemonstrators marched in Pulaski. But Klan leaders said they would try to return to Pulaski next year on the weekend of the federal holiday for King, the slain civil-rights leader who would have turned 61 today. The Klan picked Pulaski, a town of 8,000 people about 70 miles south of Nashville, because it was where the group was founded in 1865. The modern Klan traces its roots to another branch founded in 1915 in Stone Mountain, Ga. This year, Henry's group obtained a parade permit first, and the city won a legal battle in federal court to prohibit marches by more than one group a day. About 200 Klan members or supporters still showed up Saturday morning for a rally on the steps of the Giles County Courthouse, and Pulaski police cited Thom Robb, the Klan's national director, with violating the city's parade ordinance after he held a news conference. Moving to Lawrenceburg, the Klan members were joined by about another 100 white supremacists. Three people were arrested on disorderly conduct charges after confronting Klan members, authorities said. Klan officials and supporters accused town leaders of conspiring to keep them out, and Pulaski officials didn't deny it, saying they're tired of negative publicity sparked by the racist group. Scott Shepherd, head of a group called the National Association for the Advancement of White People and a candidate for the Tennessee Legislature from Memphis, promised the Klan would be back in Pulaski next year. ``I understand we can't apply for 160 days prior to the parade,'' Shepherd said. ``But I can guarantee that on the 160th day prior to that parade I'll be here at 8 o'clock to apply for a permit.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We're not going to be turned around by letter bombs or threats or any kind of violence. Instead, we're going forward, with unity and courage and commitment.'' Coretta Scott King, widow of Martin Luther King Jr., during her her annual ``state of the dream'' address at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, where the late civil rights leader was pastor.
``Armenia is in a state of battle readiness.'' _ Karen Shakhbazyan, an Armenian activist, after deadly ethnic clashes between Azerbaijanis and Armenians in the southern Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.

``We all struggle with those thoughts, we all have fear that says we have to get out of here, but we have to fight back _ you don't want to be kicked out by kids or rats.'' _ Actress Viveca Lindfors, after receiving 27 stitches on her face because of a mugging on a street in New York City's Greenwich Village.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Senator, Reform Leader Joseph Clark, 88
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Sen. Joseph S. Clark, who swept the old guard out of City Hall and tried to do the same in the halls of Congress, has died. He was 88. Clark died at home Friday, said his wife, Iris. No cause of death was given. Clark is remembered for civil-service reforms during the 1950s as Philadelphia's first Democratic mayor in 67 years and for his advocacy of civil-rights and congressional reform in Washington, D.C. A series of speeches he gave in 1963, later published in book form as ``The Senate Establishment,'' attacked the upper chamber of Congress as ``a self-perpetuating oligarchy.'' He also wrote another book, ``Congress: The Sapless Branch.'' Clark received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. During World War II, he was chief of staff for the Eastern Air Command in the China-Burma-India theater. In 1951, he was elected mayor, ending a corruption-ridden Republican administration. He replaced the city's spoils system with civil service regulations. Clark said later his major accomplishments as mayor were ``the reform of the police _ taking them out of politics,'' and ``the opening of a career service in city government to blacks.'' ``No public servant has done more for the city than Joe Clark,'' said Mayor W. Wilson Goode. Clark made a point of challenging racist traditions. He took black friends to the Philadelphia Cricket Club near his home _ the first time in the club's 100-year history that blacks had been guests. ``If I hadn't been made a life member by my father the day I was born, they probably would have asked for my resignation,'' he said. In 1956, Clark was elected to the first of two Senate terms. He sponsored the Manpower Development and Training Act and the Area Redevelopment Act, but was often frustrated by the chamber's ruling powers. ``The Senate establishment is almost the antithesis of democracy,'' Clark told his Senate colleagues in 1963. ``It is what might be called a self-perpetuating oligarchy, with only mild overtones of a plutocracy.'' James MacGregor Burns, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, called Clark's speech ``of historical significance, because it aims squarely at this century-old coalition as it operates quietly in the Senate. He has moved the power process out of dim and musty committee and caucus rooms into the spotlight of the Senate floor.'' Clark didn't intially support John F. Kennedy's 1960 presidential campaign, but he campaigned hard after the Massachusetts senator was nominated. Kennedy asked him to draw up a civil-rights program for his ``New Frontier'' program. Clark eventually rose in the Senate, gaining seats on the Foreign Relations, Labor and Public Welfare and Rules and Administration committees. His relations with President Johnson were cool at best. Although he supported Johnson's Vietnam War policy in the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution in the Senate, he broke with the administration within a year. Back home, Clark earned many political enemies in his own party when he declared during the 1963 primaries: ``It's time to knock sleazy government out of the box in Western Pennsylvania.'' When he sought re-election in 1968, local Democratic leaders failed to work enthusiastically for him and he lost to Republican Richard Schweiker. Clark later spent two years as chairman of World Federalists U.S.A., a Washington-based that promotes an effective world government. Besides his wife, survivors include a son, daughter, and stepdaughter. A private funeral was held Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Flu-Ridden Pope Cancels Day's Activities
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II canceled all his activities today because of the flu, a Vatican spokesman said. Monsignor Piero Pennacchini, the deputy Vatican spokesman, gave no details of the pope's symptoms. He said John Paul had been scheduled to receive a number of visitors, including 50 members of the Chinese National Circus; the head of the Jesuit order, Peter-Hans Kolvenbach; Louis Sullivan, the U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary; and Cardinal Josef Tomko, prefect of the Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples. The 69-year-old pope himself disclosed he was suffering from the flu during a visit to a Rome parish on Sunday. ``Perhaps you're surprised by the fact that the pope, even though he's a step away from the children, doesn't hug and kiss them,'' the pope joked. ``He was about to do so, but then he thought that he has a virus and since there's enough influenza going around there isn't reason to add more'' to the contagion. A few minutes earlier, as soon as he finished saying Mass, the pope had a hot beverage and took some medicine to counter fever, the ANSA news agency reported. Asked how high the papal fever was, the pope's doctor, Renato Buzzonetti, was quoted as telling a reporter: ``I don't know, and if I did I wouldn't tell you.'' The flu began hitting Italians in December, starting mainly in northern Italy and moving down the peninsula to recently grip Romans, especially children.

DOC.HEAD: King's Son Says Father Would Be Embarrassed By Yonkers
With PM-King Holiday Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Martin Luther King 3rd, eldest son of the slain civil-rights leader, said his father would have been embarrassed by city officials' resistance to a court order to build more integrated housing. ``It is really kind of contradictory that the city officials of Yonkers would want to celebrate a Martin Luther King holiday and not try to live out what Martin King was about,'' King said during a breakfast speech Sunday, the day before the national holiday celebrating what would have been his father's 61st birthday. ``If he were here, I think he would be embarrassed,'' said King, who was 10 years old when his father was assassinated in 1968. ``Do you want to go down in history for doing what was expedient and popular or for doing what was right?'' King asked the audience of about 500 city officials and residents. The audience was mostly black, but it also included Yonkers' newly-elected mayor, Henry Spallone. Spallone was one of four city council members who defied a federal judge's ruling that found ``consistent and extreme'' housing segregation and ordered more integrated, low-income housing built. Last week, the U.S. Supreme Court overturned contempt fines for the council members but did not rule on the judge's discrimination finding. Spallone campaigned for mayor on a pledge to continue the resistance. In an interview after King's speech, Spallone rejected the implication that Yonkers is a racist city. He said the city has more low-income housing than any other municipality in Westchester County. But he also said some compromise on housing might be found. ``What's great about America is that there is always dialogue and always common ground to be reached,'' Spallone said.

DOC.HEAD: Black Pioneer Decries Civil Rights Movement
With PM-King Holiday Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: James Meredith, whose enrollment as the first black at the University of Mississippi sparked rioting in 1962, now is fighting white liberals instead of white supremacists. ``I was engaged in a war and the only thing that has changed is the enemy,'' Meredith told reporters Sunday on the eve of the national holiday honoring slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. ``When we went to Mississippi my enemy was the white supremacists. My enemy now is the white liberal.'' His enrollment at Ole Miss resulted in riots that were suppressed by federal troops. But he since has called integration ``the biggest con job ever pulled on anybody.'' Meredith said he never considered himself a part of the civil-rights movement. ``That's always been an insult to me,'' he said. Meredith blamed many of society's ills on a ``liberal elite,'' which he said wants to keep blacks in a second-class position under the pretext of helping them. Meredith surprised civil-rights activists in September when he went to work as an adviser to arch-conservative Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Since Helms' election to the Senate in 1972, he has vigorously opposed civil-rights legislation and other domestic programs favored by many blacks. Meredith, speaking to reporters before an address at Mount Holyoke College, had little to say about King or Helms' opposition to creating of the King holiday. ``The issue is not about Martin Luther King's birthday being a national holiday,'' he said. ``The issue is about the Martin Luther King holiday commission.'' Helms has opposed funding for the federal commission Congress set up to promote the holiday. He says establishing such a commission for one individual sets a bad precedent.

DOC.HEAD: David W. MacEachron, Leader of the Japan Society
DOC.TEXT: David W. MacEachron, who led the Japan Society for 15 years and advocated close American-Japanese economic cooperation, has died. He was 66. MacEachron died of colon cancer Saturday at his home in the Westchester County village of Hastings-on-Hudson. He was executive director and later president of the non-profit Japan Society, which promotes understanding between that country and the United States. He retired in 1989. During his tenure, MacEachron boosted the society's endowment by about $20 million and increased its role in encouraging cross-cultural friendship through film festivals, stage performances, art exhibits and conferences. Born in Grinnell, Iowa, MacEachron grew up in Oberlin, Ohio, and Des Moines. He earned a bachelor's degree in philosophy at Yale University and two degrees at Harvard University: a master's in public administration and a doctorate in economics. He also was program director and later vice president of the Council on Foreign Relations between 1962 and 1974 in New York. His wife, Frances, has been mayor of Hastings-on-Hudson for nearly eight years. The Japan Society planned a memorial service Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Threatens Rebellion Against Aquino Government
DOC.TEXT: A powerful provincial governor today threatened to lead a ``people power'' uprising if President Corazon Aquino's administration removes him for alleged links to last month's failed coup. However, the presidential spokesman said the government was determined to prosecute the governor, and the speaker of the House of Representatives demanded that the military take action against the provincial leader. The governor, Rodolfo Aguinaldo, a former lieutenant colonel of the Philippine Constabulary and one of the most colorful personalities in Philippine politics, also said he may order his constituents in Cagayan province to attack ``corrupt'' government officials. ``Where would I go if I am suspended or expelled?'' Aguinaldo asked in a telephone interview from his office in Tuguegarao, 200 miles northeast of Manila. ``I have only my principles. They (government officials) are harassing me. What will I do? I will fight, fight and fight! That's it,'' he added. Aguinaldo said that if he were removed from office, he would ask his constituents to stage massive demonstrations like the 1986 ``people power'' revolt that swept Mrs. Aquino to the presidency and ousted the late Ferdinand Marcos. ``The people will be enjoined to rise up against the dirty politicians and the corrupt officials,'' Aguinaldo said. ``Perhaps the people will stone these officials' houses, bang on their Pajero (jeeps) and Mercedes, seize their overpriced cement, sort of a massive people power.'' Local Government Secretary Luis Santos suspended Aguinaldo from office last week because the governor allegedly sent troops to Manila to back the Dec. 1-9 failed putsch, the sixth and bloodiest bid to topple Mrs. Aquino. However, Aguinaldo has refused to vacate his post and filed a civil suit challenging the suspension order. He also refused to comment on allegations he helped mutinous soldiers in the December coup attempt, which left at least 113 people dead and more than 500 wounded. Presidential spokesman Adolf Azcuna said the Department of Justice has issued a subpoena to Aguinaldo asking the governor to appear at a preliminary investigation hearing on rebellion charges against him on Jan. 26 in Manila. ``This shows that the government, though not as fast as perhaps our instincts would want us to (move) ... is determined to throw the book at this recalcitrant local official,'' Azcuna said. He said the suspension order was an administrative measure, while the rebellion charges filed by Santos with the justice department was a criminal case against Aguinaldo. Under Philippine law, a preliminary investigation has to be undertaken by government prosecutors before a formal case is filed in a court. Also today, House Speaker Ramon Mitra expressed anger at Aguinaldo's threats and said the military ``must do something forceful and decisive'' against the governor, who was ``making a fool out of the government.'' ``Do they (the military authorities) expect the president to pick up a gun and enforce her order by herself?'' Mitra said. ``Do they want the president to go to Cagayan and get Aguinaldo herself?'' In his comments, Aguinaldo said, ``This government is bent on getting me. Very soon there will be action here....'' He said he may be forced to ``go up the hills,'' a phrase which locally means becoming a rebel, if he is expelled. But Aguinaldo said he was confident he would be protected by his people. Aguinaldo was implicated but never charged in an August 1987 coup attempt. Afterward, he resigned from the armed forces and raised a private army, ostensibly to fight Communist rebels. He was elected governor of Cagayan in January 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose in Europe early today in quiet trading due to holidays in the United States and Japan. Gold prices fell. Foreign currency dealers in London said violence in some Soviet republics, particularly Azerbaijan, provided some support for the dollar over the weekend. The U.S. dollar is often seen as a safe haven in times of political turmoil or international tensions. In Frankfurt, dealers said the market has recovered from Friday's volatility. They said a large buying order late Friday along with nervousness about Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's stormy visit to Lithuania late last week helped push the dollar up then. Market participants said today the market was turning its attention to a wave of U.S. economic data due for release later in the week, particularly November's trade figures on Wednesday. Financial markets were closed in Japan today for a national holiday, and in the United States they were marking the birthday of the late civil rights leader, Martin Luther King Jr. Dollar rates at midmorning in London compared with late Friday: _1.6818 West German marks, up from 1.6785 _1.4954 Swiss francs, up from 1.4940 _5.7268 French francs, up from 5.7155 _1.8967 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8870 _1,255.00 Italian lire, up from 1,252.00 _1.1566 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1560 The dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at 1.6698 dollars, compared with 1.6705 dollars late Friday. The dollar was also quoted at 145.50 yen. Gold opened in London at $413 dollars a troy ounce, down from late Friday's $416.25. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $415.30. In Zurich, the bid price was $414.90, down from $416.75 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 49 cents to close at a bid $412.10. Silver was quoted in London at a bid price of $5.33 a troy ounce, down from Friday's $5.36.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Parliament Abolishs Communist Party's Leading Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Communists' leading role abolished. Picks up 12th pvs, ```We're hearing ...' EDITS thereafter to conform. ^By TONY SMITH
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted today to abolish the Communist Party's political monopoly and agreed to discuss further constitutional changes with the opposition, which is demanding a swifter transition to democracy. Lawmakers voted unanimously to delete clauses in the constitution that guaranteed Communist supremacy in Bulgaria for 44 years, following the lead of colleagues in East Germany and Czechoslovakia. On Sunday, more than 50,000 people rallied in Sofia to keep up the pressure on legislators and demand the immediate dismissal of old guard Communists still in the leadership. They chanted ``Communists resign! Resign!'' Parliament was also expected to adopt a declaration backing the restoration of the rights of the Turkish-speaking minority that arose from talks last week among Communists, opposition figures, nationalist leaders and ethnic Turks. The declaration aims to defuse ethnic tensions between Slavic nationalists and members of Bulgaria's estimated 1.2 million ethnic Turks. They also adopted a proposal by Andrei Lukanov, the No. 2 official in the Communist Party, to set up the group that is to join lawmakers and opposition figures in drafting proposed further constitutional changes. The changes are likely to include scrapping the reference to Bulgaria as a ``Socialist state ... headed by the working class'' and be voted on when Parliament next meets in February. The country's new President and party leader, Petar Mladenov, is under pressure from pro-democracy opposition forces to speed reforms. The demonstrators on Sunday demanded a ``government of national accord'' and the resignation of Premier Georgi Atanassov, a holdover from the hard-line rule of Todor Zhivkov, who was ousted Nov. 10 after 34 years in power. Leaders of the pro-democracy opposition Union of Democratic Forces also read excerpts from a declaration agreed upon Friday by nationalists, Communists and opposition representatives aimed at ending ethnic discord. Last month, the country's new leaders struck down a Zhivkov decree under which Turks were forcibly assimilated. Thousands of ethnic Slavs reacted by taking to the streets in protest and staging strikes. Petko Simeonov, president of the Glasnost and Democracy Club, has accused orthodox Communists of manipulating nationalist sentiments in an attempt ``to smash democracy.'' At Sunday's three-hour rally, opposition leaders announced a list of demands that include: two-stage legislative elections in May and November, removing Communist cells from the army, police and workplace, and scrapping the constitutional guarantees of Communist supremacy. Petar Beron, a leading opposition spokesman who read the demands from the steps of Alexander Nevski Cathedral, called for some parliamentary seats held by Zhivkov cronies to be contested in May, with a full general election in November. ``We're hearing of changes in nearby countries like Romania, even Albania, so we demand democratic guarantees,'' Beron shouted to the crowd, who sang and cheered in almost a holiday mood. He also called for a full report on the finances of the secret police and the removal of all former Zhivkov collaborators from the government. In explaining the call for two-stage elections, the opposition movement's president, Zhelio Zhelev, told reporters the opposition had no time to prepare for full general elections provisionally slated for May. ``We couldn't win full elections in May, but in November we have a good chance,'' he said. ``How can we win elections in May when Department Six (the secret police) still exists and the mass media are still under dictatorship?'' asked Ljubomir Sobajiev, another UDF speaker. The opposition will demand May elections for 100 to 120 parliamentary seats occupied by ``those compromised under Zhivkov,'' Zhelev said. The demands were to be presented at talks with the government that are to begin Tuesday. Student leader Emil Koshlukov issued a warning to the government: ``Czechoslovak students swept away totalitarianism like an epidemic, and we will also sweep Bulgaria with the `Czechoslovak flu' this winter.'' In an apparent response to opposition calls for weeklong rallies, Parliament President Stanko Todorov called on Sofia's mayor and police to protect assembly members and ensure ``necessary conditions for the normal working of Parliament.'' Todorov's request, in a letter, was read on state television. Mladenov, a former foreign minister, has promised democratic changes, including free elections and freedom of the press. But the opposition has criticized him for the slow speed of reform and for allowing former Zhivkov associates to remain in high-ranking party positions. ``After Nov. 10, our newly-reformed leaders promised to tell us the real situation _ but we're still waiting,'' said Mihail Mihailov, one of the 20-plus speakers at the rally. Friday's agreement on the ethnic situation confirms a Dec. 29 government decree guaranteeing Turks' rights to reassume their own names after years of forced assimilation under Zhivkov. Nationalists had demanded the decree be revoked, pending a national referendum, but appeared to be satisfied with Friday's declaration guaranteeing Bulgaria's territorial integrity and Bulgarian as the national language. Some demonstrators Sunday carried banners that read ``apologize,'' apparently referring to nationalists' accusations that pro-democracy leaders were ``unpatriotic'' because they supported the minority rights.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Reduce Surveillance of U.S. Embassy, But Fang Link Denied
DOC.TEXT: Chinese police reduced surveillance around the U.S. Embassy to its lowest level since June, an embassy spokesman said today, prompting speculation of an accord on a Chinese dissident who took refuge inside. However, embassy spokesman spokesman Sheridan W. Bell moved to squelch such talk, saying the Chinese gave no reason for their move. ``If a secret agreement has been reached, it's a secret to me,'' he said. Astrophysicist Fang Lizhi and his wife fled to the embassy in June when China cracked down on pro-democracy protesters. Since then, their presence at the embassy has been a major irritant in U.S.-Chinese relations. However, neither side has acknowledged even holding talks on the Fangs, for whom the Chinese have issued arrest warrants as ``counterrevolutionaries.'' China said last week that the ``only way out'' for the couple was to plead guilty. The Fangs' presence has prompted heavy Chinese surveillance since June at the main embassy building and at the ambassador's residence several blocks away. The United States has not said in which compound the Fangs are living. The surveillance peaked in early November, when dozens of uniformed and plainclothes police watched the compounds' gates, and their black Mercedes with dark windows and no license plates lined the blocks. The number of police dropped gradually in November but reached a new low late last week, according to Bell. Today, the main embassy building was guarded only by five uniformed police with automatic pistols while three guarded the ambassador's residence. Only one police car was sighted in the area _ an unmarked Mercedes with two men inside that was parked on a sidewalk a block from the residence. ``We have called for (the Chinese) repeatedly in the past to remove the extra troops, weapons and cars from in front of the buildings,'' Bell said. ``Now the unmarked cars are no longer parked in front of the embassy buildings. .... All we know is that they are gone.'' Immediately after the Fangs took refuge at the embassy, police outside began carrying automatic rifles and wearing helmets. However, they switched back to their usual pistols in November, when former U.S. President Richard Nixon visited and complained. Earlier this month, a China-watching magazine in Hong Kong reported that Fang would be allowed to leave the embassy and go into exile in Australia or another country later in January. The Chinese-language Pai Shing semi-monthly reported that the United States and China had reached an ``understanding'' on resolving the impasse over Fang when U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft visited Beijing in December. The Scowcroft trip was denounced by many U.S. lawmakers and others who believed it too early to resume high-level talks with China, which Washington suspended after troops killed hundreds of unarmed civilians June 3-4 in clearing central Beijing of pro-democracy protesters. The critics argued that China had made no corresponding concession. Pai Shing noted that an agreement on Fang would ease criticism of President Bush's decision to send his national security adviser to China.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco, Denver to Meet in Super Bowl
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco 49ers will get their chance to be the first team in a decade to win two straight NFL championships, while the Denver Broncos have earned a fourth shot at winning their first Super Bowl. Behind an almost flawless passing performance by Joe Montana, the 49ers beat the Los Angeles Rams 30-3 for the National Football Conference championship in San Francisco on Sunday. In Denver, the Broncos, led by quarterback John Elway, defeated the Cleveland Browns 37-21 to win the American Football Conference title and go on to face the 49ers in New Orleans on Jan 28. Montana, who passed for 156 yards in a 21-point second quarter that broke the game open, had a 20-yard TD pass to Brent Jones and an 18-yarder to John Taylor, his 30th and 31st in postseason. That broke the record of 30 by Pittsburgh's Terry Bradshaw. Against Denver they will try to match another standard set by Bradshaw and the Steelers with their fourth Super Bowl victory. Pittsburgh also was the last team to win two straight Super Bowls, in 1979 and 1980. The Broncos beat the Browns for the third time in an AFC championship game since 1987 as Elway enjoyed his best game of the season and his best ever in the playoffs. He completed 20 of 36 passes for 385 yards and three touchdowns, and took Denver on scoring drives of 82, 80, 80 and 60 yards. The Broncos want to avoid tying the Minnesota Vikings' record of being 0-4 in the Super Bowl. The 49ers are 3-0 in the big game and have been overwhelming all season.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls in East; Central Plains Enjoys Warm Weather
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `In California, ...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with hypothermia death; pickup 8th graf pvs, `A small ...'
DOC.TEXT: Snow blanketed parts of the East today, while unseasonably high temperatures warmed parts of the Plains. Temperatures were in the 30s and snow was falling early today in Washington, D.C., and Philadephia. Snow also fell today in the West, in parts of Nevada and Washington state. In the Plains, temperatures were above normal Sunday, with record-breaking highs in the 60s in parts of Kansas and Nebraska. Highs were in the 70s in the southern Plains. The high for the nation Sunday was 79 at Brownsville, Texas. More seasonable temperatures prevailed in the East, with temperatures in the single numbers to teens in northern New England. Light sleet or snow was scattered across the Great Lakes region Sunday, while dry weather prevailed in much of the nation's midsection and East. In California, weekend storms laid out a carpet of snow for Sierra Nevada skiers. But the weather also was blamed for the hypothermia death of a 12-year-old boy who was separated from a church outing Saturday and was found Sunday buried in snow near a ski resort 45 miles northeast of Los Angeles. The storms dumped heavy rain in lower elevations, and thousands of fans at the National Football Conference championship game in San Francisco had to trudge through a water-logged and occasionally muddy parking lot at Candlestick Park. A small waterspout, a whirlwind over water, swept across Shelter Island in San Diego early Sunday, causing an estimated $75,000 damage mostly to beached and anchored boats, authorities said. In Las Vegas Sunday, a bus traveling in heavy rain skidded into concrete barriers on Interstate 15 and tipped over, injured about 30 people, authorities said. Most passengers escaped with minor cuts and bruises, but one was hospitalized with fractured ribs. DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Accuses Hong Kong of Mistreating Boat People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with goverment reax; MINOR EDITING; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong suffer beatings by security forces, and many could risk political persecution when they are forced back to their Communist homeland, Amnesty International charged today. The London-based human rights group urged the Hong Kong government to stop its forced repatriation program, which began in December to ease the burden of detaining the refugees. ``The fundamental rights of people who face a genuine risk of persecution are being violated,'' said the report, which was based on a recent fact-finding mission to Hong Kong. The Hong Kong government called the report ``unfounded'' and said it was committed to its policy of sending the Vietnamese home. Amnesty accused the Hong Kong government of mistreating the 51 boat people who were forcibly returned to Vietnam in December. It quoted witnesses as saying security forces dragged them from the Chi Ma Wan detention center in a dawn raid on Oct. 31, using kicks, beatings and choke holds. Hong Kong's Secretary of Security Geoffrey Barnes said ``a minimum of necessary force was used on that occasion.'' ``There is no truth whatsoever in the accusation that people at Chi Ma Wan were ill-treated or rendered unconscious,'' he said in a statement. The refugees were then taken to another detention center, the Phoenix House. Early Dec. 12, hundreds of security forces in riot gear brought them to the international airport. During that operation, reporters did not see any evidence of brutality. The report also charged the government with quashing investigations of official misconduct in the camps, citing two incidents when 200 boat people were allegedly beaten and kicked by security forces last year. In the High Island Detention Center, it said, unruly boat people are routinely locked in empty subdivided cargo containers for several days. The report said many Vietnamese feared that if they spoke up about abuses, they faced ``possible retribution by the police and risked unfavorable treatment in the screening process.'' Amnesty criticized the screening process to separate refugees with the right to find a new country from ``economic migrants,'' who will be forced back to Vietnam. Of the 40,000 Vietnamese awaiting screening, an estimated 85 percent face forced repatriation. They make up the bulk of boat people who arrived after mid-June 1988, when Hong Kong stopped automatically granting refugee status. Under the screening process, boat people are given a hearing with an immigration officer. They can appeal the decision once. As of Tuesday, 7,567 Vietnamese had been refused refugee status, and 1,889 had lost appeals. So far, 997 have voluntarily returned to Vietnam. Amnesty said that during the screening process, boat people receive no legal advice and are often interviewed by immigration officers with scant knowledge of the human rights situation in Vietnam. The report cited one case of an immigration officer who seemed unaware that Vietnam had once been divided into two countries, a Communist north and a capitalist south. Another case involved a young Vietnamese who was refused refugee status even though he allegedly was fleeing a five-year term of ``political imprisonment'' in Vietnam. An emergency intervention of the office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees provided the man refugee status. However, Barnes defended the screening process, saying Hong Kong has given the ``benefit of the doubt'' to many refugees. But he said the colony would proceed with forced repatriation. ``They have no alternative but to return to Vietnam to restart their lives,'' he said. ``It would be wrong and cannot be humane to leave them in detention indefinitely.'' Vietnam has promised not to prosecute or mistreat the boat people for fleeing their homeland. But the Amnesty report said it fears that local officials may persecute those who return. Timothy Raison, a British parliamentarian who visited some of the forcibly repatriated boat people, has said he found no sign of persecution.

DOC.HEAD: Nations Meet to Set Up Development Bank for Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand today opened a 34-nation conference to form an Eastern European development bank and urged delegates to move quickly to clear that region's path toward free markets. The nations are expected to agree to put at least $12 billion into the bank in what could become one of the largest regional assistance programs since the U.S. Marshall Plan that rebuilt Western Europe after World War II. Opening the two-day conference to form the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Eastern Europe, Mitterrand expressed hope the bank could be operating by the spring. ``If we don't move fast enough, we risk being passed up by events,'' he told delegates from both Eastern and Western Europe. He asked them to move at ``a speed that isn't traditional in international affairs.'' Mitterrand proposed the idea of the bank to leaders of the 12-nation European Community in November, and the group of Western European nations formally approved the concept at last month's summit in Strasbourg. Under that plan, the bank would provide loans, loan guarantees, economic and technical assistance, and make equity investments in some projects in Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, East Germany, Romania and Bulgaria. All those countries are undergoing democratic transformations. Mitterrand has suggested the loans be tied to progress toward democratic elections. The deficit-plagued United States has given Western Europe the lead in the plan, saying it is more familiar with the problems of Eastern Europe. The starting point of the talks will be a French proposal that the EC hold a majority share of 53 percent of the capital. The four largest countries _ France, Britain, West Germany and Italy _ have reportedly been asked to hold 8.5 percent each. The United States, Japan and Soviet Union would each hold 8.5 percent, as would the European Free Trade Association composed of Switzerland, Austria, Sweden, Norway, Finland and Iceland. Eastern European countries other than the Soviet Union would hold a total of 6.5 percent. The others shares would be divided among the remaining nations, including Australia, Canada and New Zealand. Negotiations on the bank could be concluded by the end of March, EC spokesmen said, but it could take more than a year before ratification and approval by individual governments on their contributions. A second round of talks is envisioned for Feb. 19. Other issues include whether the bank should lend money significantly below market rates and whether loans should be made only to the private sector or also to finance public sector projects. The United States and some other countries also have reservations about whether the Soviet Union should be a borrower as well as a shareholder. Undersecretary of the Treasury David Mulford and Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs Robert McCormack are leading the U.S. delegation to the conference. The EC has been coordinating international efforts to aid the emerging democracies in Poland and Hungary. So far, about $6 billion in food aid, grants, loans and trade have been donated or committed by 24 industrialized nations.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Injured in Explosion During Holdup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: An explosive that robbers intended to use to blast open a safe went off prematurely today, injuring about 30 people during the holdup in a crowded post office, police said. The injured were rushed to different hospitals in the central Italian city. Two were reported in critical condition. At least five armed and masked bandits fled in two cars with an undisclosed amount of cash, a police officer said on condition of anonymity. One was believed to have been injured in the blast. The post office, on the city outskirts, was crowded shortly after it opened. Many of the customers were lining up for payment of their pensions.

DOC.HEAD: Jane Fonda's Teen-Age Son Arrested on Graffiti Charge
DOC.TEXT: Troy Hayden, teen-age son of actress Jane Fonda and her ex-husband Tom Hayden, was arrested early today after police caught a group of boys spray-painting graffiti at a parking lot, authorities said. ``I can't give out his name since he's a juvenile,'' said Sgt. Rick Walker. ``He indicates he's the son of Jane Fonda. We've verified it.'' The 16-year-old, Ms. Fonda's only son, was arrested about 1:30 a.m. near the San Diego Freeway, Walker said. ``He and seven other young gentlemen were applying graffiti to phone booths and posts at a park-and-ride,'' Walker said. The sergeant did not know what the graffiti said. The boy was booked for investigation of vandalism and breaking a 10 p.m. curfew, both misdemeanor violations. A telephone message left before business hours for his parents' spokesman, Stephen Rivers, was not immediately returned. Ms. Fonda and Hayden, a longtime activist and Democratic member of the state Assembly, dissolved their marriage last year. Although the settlement was private they announced they would share custody of their son. Ms. Fonda also has a daughter from a previous marriage, Vanessa Vadim, who was arrested Oct. 6 in New York on charges of obstructing governmental administration, loitering for the purpose of purchasing drugs and disorderly conduct. Ms. Vadim, 21, was accused of trying to interfere with police when her boyfriend was being arrested on a drug charge. In November, a judge ordered her to perform three days of community service and told that if she stays out of trouble for six months, the complaint against her will be dismissed. Her father is filmmaker Roger Vadim.

DOC.HEAD: Northern California Continues Quake Recovery
Precede UNDATED
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with 49ers winning game, Super Bowl spot; Mc Farren with space for Watsonville mayor's name is cq. Also sent in advance as b0275 of Jan. 12
DOC.TEXT: Quake-related calls to suicide hotlines have dropped to a fraction after three months, but unsettling reminders of the earth's fury remain. A shopping mall in a seaside town resembles an abandoned movie set, hundreds of people are still homeless and major sections of freeways are still closed or detoured. Aftershocks have subsided since the earthquake of 7.1 magnitude shook Northern California on Oct. 17, but the recovery efforts expected to take years are apparent as hammering and the hum of heavy construction equipment fill the air from San Francisco and downtown Oakland to Watsonville. The 15-second temblor injured 2,500 people, killed 67 and left 10,000 homeless; $7 billion damage made it the nation's costliest quake ever. Almost 70,000 claims have been filed with the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the San Francisco Bay area for temporary housing help, home and business loans, grants and other aid. The American Red Cross says 14,000 families probably will have received temporary shelter, clothes, blankets, food and other help. The eyes of sports fans across the country were on Candlestick Park and a World Series game between the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland A's when the quake hit. The ballpark was in the limelight again this weekend as the 49ers beat the Los Angeles Rams 30-3 to clinch a Super Bowl berth. ``Life is not as anxious as it was for anyone, but it isn't the same for anyone. ... It'll never be the same again,'' said Eve Meyer, executive director of the San Francisco Suicide Prevention Hotline, which saw quake-related calls drop from a peak of about 200 a day to the current average two a day. ``They say in about six months, it'll be back to normal and everyone will forget all about it,'' said Erik Carlson, of Mahopac, N.Y. The quake damaged his spine and left him paralyzed from the waist down in the wreckage of the collapsed Cypress section of the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland. ``How could I? Look at what it did to my body,'' he said. And while Watsonville's Fox Theater marquee wishes passers-by ``Happy New Year'' in English and Spanish, that prospect remains dubious for many of the estimated 1,000 people left homeless in the agricultural community 70 miles south of San Francisco. Maria Alvarez and her husband slept in a parking lot with their five children and several other families for four nights after the quake. Now they have a trailer supplied by the federal government for 18 months. But after that, she doesn't know if they can afford to rent a new home. ``I've been living here for about 30 years. Now to move somewhere else, I wouldn't feel right. To start again, it's hard to do,'' Alvarez said, standing in the 40-trailer Crestview camp, one of a half-dozen in the Watsonville area. ``At least they're secure now,'' said Mayor Todd Mc Farren. ``But they have a lot of fears about what's going to happen in 18 months ... and I don't have an answer for them.'' Mc Farren expressed concern for the future of the city that sustained $60 million in damage and lost $400,000 in sales tax and $200,000 in property tax. ``A lot of workers have left town and the canneries are concerned they won't come back in the spring ... the word's out there's no place left to live.'' The once quaint and tranquil Pacific Garden Mall is the focal point for damage in neighboring Santa Cruz, 60 miles from San Francisco near the quake's Loma Prieta epicenter. Today, it resembles an abandoned movie set or a ghost town. Most of the buildings _ with broken windows, chipped walls and tilted frames _ are fenced off. Others have been demolished, leaving huge holes. Around the mall's fringe are vinyl ``pods'' where 45 businesses have set up temporary shop, for what may be a two-year stay. One shop displayed leftover holiday T-shirts proclaiming, ``Yes, Virginia, there IS a Santa Cruz.'' In San Francisco's Marina District, near the Golden Gate Bridge, ``For Rent'' signs _ some vouching for the safety of the premises _ fill apartment windows, and vacant lots abound where buildings were torn down. The Embarcadero Freeway, once a key entrance to the waterfront and Chinatown, is closed. Its future is uncertain as officials debate environmental, economic and public safety implications of its repair. A survey by the San Francisco Economic Development Corp. shows the city's $3.4 billion tourism industry has been hard hit. The number of spouses coming with conventioneers and the number of leisure travelers _ who account for half of all visitors from outside the region _ is down a third from a year ago. It's been hard to convince outsiders the city is safe, that ``this isn't Soviet Armenia,'' said San Francisco Visitors and Convention Bureau spokeswoman Sharon Rooney. ``We've proven we can rebound from that _ the cable cars were running within 48 hours after the earthquake. ``We're a city probably better prepared than any other city for an earthquake.'' Across the bay in Oakland, where the Cypress section of the Nimitz Freeway crumpled like a paper fan and killed 42 people, all but a small portion of the roadway has been demolished. A 1\-mile swath, like a glaring scar, divides the heavily damaged downtown and a neighborhood ravaged by drug-related violence. City Hall has been vacated as authorities consider spending an estimated $40 million to $50 million for repairs, and a major department store long vital to a struggling economy faces $8 million to $10 million in renovation bills. In addition, Alameda County needs $20 million to keep homeless shelters open and up to $100 million to repair residential hotels closed by the quake, said county supervisors' Chairman Don Perata. Erik Carlson, for one, will never be convinced of the region's safety. ``I would come back, but I wouldn't stay long,'' he said shortly before leaving to return to New York. ``Live in California? Out! Completely! No way!''

DOC.HEAD: Mass For 43 Victims In Disco Fire; Toxic Fumes Blamed For Deaths
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 people filled the city's main cathedral today for a one-hour funeral Mass for the 43 people killed in a discotheque fire, which medical examiners said had released deadly fumes. Medical examiners found fatal levels of carbon monoxide in blood samples taken from all of the victims of the fire early Sunday, said Judge Javier Seoane, who is heading up the judicial investigation in this northeastern city. He added the samples had been sent to Madrid for further tests to determine if other poisonous gases were present. The victims apparently died from the hydrocyanic acid as well as carbon monoxide poisoning, government spokesman Ignacio Bruna said. Many of the victims died in their seats in the basement lounge. Both types of fumes can be given off when carpets, drapes, furniture coverings and other synthetic material made from certain compounds come into contact with intense heat, Civil Protection chief Antonio Herrero said. The victims included five members of a band playing in the lounge and the parents and wife of one of the dead musicians, the Spanish news agency EFE said. A U.S. military base is about 10 miles west of Zaragoza, but the discotheque was not frequented by U.S. servicemen, and authorities said all the victims were local residents. One woman remained hospitalized with serious injuries, doctors said. A firefighter and another customer were treated and released. The fire began in the Flying discotheque in a run-down section of Zaragoza, when an electrical overload triggered a short circuit. It was extinguished in minutes. However, toxic smoke poured through air-conditioning ducts to the basement, where the dance floor, bar and lounge are located, said a local government representative, Carlos Perez Anadon. Investigators found traces of hydrocyanic acid in the lounge, said Bruna. Perez Anadon said the official cause of the fire and the deaths would not be determined until autopsies were completed, but he added that hydrocyanic acid is commonly mixed with water in executions by poisonous gas. The acid is also sometimes used as a fumigant. However, Spanish National Radio said the chemical, used to produce acrylic fibers, may have been in material for the discotheque's interior decoration. Perez Anadon said records indicated the club's owners had not used materials with the chemical, which is prohibited by city fire laws. Herrero said about 5 percent of all synthetic fibers, including acrylics, contain hydrocyanic acid. Investigators said they first suspected hydrocyanic acid because the victims were overcome so quickly. ``They didn't make any type of movement to protect themselves,'' said Herrero, who arrived at the discotheque with rescue workers. Deputy Mayor Luis Garcia Nieto said firefighters arrived eight minutes after they received news of the fire, but he said rescue workers could do little to help those inside. ``Several people died in their seats. It was very fast,'' added Antonio Gonzalez Trivino, mayor of Zaragoza, a provincial capital 200 miles northeast of Madrid. Perez Anadon and Gonzalez Trivino both said the disco appeared to be in compliance with fire laws enacted in December 1983 after a fire at a Madrid disco killed 79 people. It was the second catastrophic fire in Zaragoza in a decade. More than 70 people died in a July 1979 blaze at the Corona de Aragon hotel.

DOC.HEAD: New Team Named to Prosecute Noriega
With PM-Noriega-Narcotics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. attorney in Miami named a top Justice Department lawyer and two other veteran prosecutors to handle the case of Panamanian strongman Manuel Noriega and said he never intended to prosecute it himself. Dexter Lehtinen on Saturday named Deputy U.S. Solicitor General William C. Bryson, a veteran federal attorney from Washington who played a role in the Oliver North case and government efforts to restrict abortion, to help lead the team prosecuting Noriega on drug-trafficking charges. Assistant U.S. Attorneys Michael Patrick Sullivan and Myles H. Malman, both longtime Miami prosecutors, also will lead the team. Though Lehtinen appeared as co-counsel at Noriega's arraignment, he said at a news conference, ``There was never a time when I planned to (prosecute Noriega) or wanted to do it.'' And Lehtinen it was his decision to remove himself from a direct role in the case, not Attorney General Richard Thornburgh's. Bryson, 44, has been with the Justice Department since 1978 and was named deputy solicitor general in 1986 after serving as the chief of the criminal appellate section. The former law clerk to Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall served as the acting solicitor general last year. During that time, he wrote the government's Supreme Court brief urging the justices to overturn the landmark 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision guaranteeing a woman's right to an abortion. Bryson also was involved in the attorney general's attempt to keep classified information from leaking out at the Iran-Contra trial of North. Classified information also is a concern in the Noriega case because of his long association with the Central Intelligence Agency. Bryson will coordinate the briefing and argument of legal issues in the government's case against Noriega, charged with protecting cocaine shipments, a drug laboratory in Panama, Colombian cartel leaders who took refuge in Panama and drug money shipments. Sullivan, 42, who Lehtinen named chief prosecutor, is senior litigation counsel in the Miami office and has been a federal prosecutor for 18 years. One of his most visible cases was one in which a ring of officers allegedly stole drug shipments from dealers to sell for their own profit. Malman, 43, No. 3 in Lehtinen's office, has been a prosecutor for 15 years. He obtained convictions against members of the Cali cocaine cartel in a Drug Enforcement Administration money-laundering case known as ``Operation Swordfish.'' Malman had been handling the drug racketeering indictment up until Noriega's arrival in the United States on Jan. 4. Five co-defendants had been taken into custody earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Farmers Strike, Israeli Soldier Stabbed in Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Israeli farmers went on strike and blocked roads with burning tires today to demand the government ease the debt of collective farms. In Jerusalem's Old City, an Arab stabbed an Israeli woman soldier six times in the back and chest, police said. Sixty people were detained for questioning, police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. Israel radio said police were investigating whether the soldier was wounded with a knife or with a screwdriver found near the site. Attacks in Jerusalem have been rare in the 25-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. On Sept. 20, a Jewish seminary student was stabbed in the same area of the Old City. In northern Israel, scores of angry farmers used tires and rocks to close a main road near the Lebanon border, Israel radio reported. Police used force to disperse the crowd, and several protesters were arrested, the radio said. It gave no other details. The strike was triggered by mounting farmers' debts and to commemorate the death of a farmer who committed suicide last week because of his debts. A government-backed program recently was put in place to resolve the financial problems of kibbutz, which are collective farms. But the debts of other farming collectives have not been resolved. ``We aren't asking for gifts, but we have to be able to make a living so we can pay off our debts,'' strike organizer and poultry farmer Avi Krempa said. ``Otherwise our settlements will fall apart.'' Krempa said the farmers were staging the one-day action to press demands for higher government subsidies and increased quotas for egg and poultry production that would enable the moshavim to pay off their debts. Parliament was scheduled to debate a bill on the issue later this week, Krempa said. Krempa said that 22 of the striking settlements he represents have accumulated debt of $75 million that they cannot pay off because their farms are not profitable.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Rape Victim Picks Out Suspect By Scent, Feel of Hands
DOC.TEXT: A blind woman identified a 14-year-old boy as the person who raped her in her apartment building's laundry room by smelling his cologne and touching his hands, police said. The 24-year-old woman, legally blind for three years, immediately recognized the scent of the suspect's cologne and later felt his hands in a lineup at a police station, investigators said. The assailant held his hands over the victim's mouth during the attack. ``It was the smell of his cologne,'' the woman said Sunday. ``That was the major key. I could tell, too, by the size of his hands and how rough or smooth they were.'' The boy accused in the rape lives in the victim's apartment building, and on the same floor. Police knocked on his door during their investigation and the victim, who accompanied the investigators, got a whiff of his cologne. ``A lot of people can't even give a good description of a rapist,'' said police Detective Catherine Fitzgibbon. ``Yet this woman was able to pick him out by his touch and smell. It was remarkable. ``I've never heard of a blind woman being able to pick someone out of a lineup,'' Fitzgibbon said. Another officer, however, cautioned that such identifications might not be admissible in court. ``The sense of smell and feel,'' said Detective Karl Kurth. ``Is that enough to stand in a court of law? I don't know.'' The woman said she was in her building's laundry room folding her towels when the assailant came up from behind, shoved her in a corner and raped her. The suspect was named in a juvenile petition and was held at a youth home. He was scheduled to appear Tuesday in Juvenile Court to determine whether he would remain in custody and whether he would stand trial as an adult.

DOC.HEAD: Gordon Jackson, Star of `Upstairs, Downstairs,' Dead at 66
LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gordon Jackson, who played the butler in ``Upstairs, Downstairs'' and brought his mellifluous Scots accent to dozens of films, stage and television roles, has died, his agent said today. He was 66. Jackson died Sunday in London's Cromwell Hospital with his wife, Rona, at his side, Michael Anderson said. The cause of death was not disclosed, but Anderson said Jackson had been ill for a short time. The tall, ginger-haired Jackson started acting as a teen-ager soon after the outbreak of World War II. His rueful expression first typecast him as a coward and a weakling, although maturity brought him a greater variety of roles. His acting career spanned nearly half a century and included more than 60 film credits, but he was best known for his role as the stiff-upper-lipped butler Hudson in the internationally successful television series ``Upstairs, Downstairs'' from 1970 to 1975. He won a British Actor of the Year award in 1974 for the series, reruns of which are still being shown in the United States. Jackson, described as gentle and self-effacing by friends, once said: ``My trouble is that I'm underconfident and I'm too tentative. I'm not a go-getter and I never have been. ``It's only when the curtain goes up and the cameras start to roll that I don't enjoy this business.'' Jackson was born in Glasgow in 1923. He started an apprenticeship with Rolls Royce in Edinburgh, but got his first professional acting job as in 1941, playing a Scottish soldier in the film ``The Foreman Went to France,'' a story of Britons trapped in France in 1940 by the German invasion. His film credits included ``Whisky Galore'' in 1948, ``Mutiny on the Bounty'' in 1961, `The Great Escape'' in 1962, ``The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie'' in 1968 and ``The Whistle Blower'' in 1986. He also played the tough undercover police chief Cowley in the British TV thriller series ``The Professionals'' from 1977 to 1981, and was in the 1988 TV movie ``Noble House.'' On stage, he was Shakespeare's Banquo in ``Macbeth,'' Horatio in ``Hamlet,'' Mavolio in ``Twelfth Night'' and a host of other characters in London's West End. ``Upstairs, Downstairs'' co-star John Alderton recalled Jackson as ``the sweetest, gentlest man I have ever met. To have worked with him was a privilege, to be counted as a friend was an honor. His unparalleled contribution to film and television for over 50 years will remain a testament to his very special talent.'' Jackson is survived by his wife, Rona, also an actress, and two sons. Funeral plans have not been made.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Group Meets to Discuss Cambodian Peace
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met today to discuss what many see as the best chance in years to end the Cambodian civil war. The closed-door meeting followed reports that Khmer Rouge guerrillas had taken territory from Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed government and attacked the country's two largest cities. The Khmer Rouge radio reported today that thousands of people fled the western city of Battambang following a guerrilla attack Jan. 5. The report could not be confirmed. Representatives from Britain, China, France, the United States and the Soviet Union began talks this morning. Diplomatic sources said it was unlikely a statement on the progress of the talks would be issued before the meeting ends Tuesday. The Foreign Ministry issued a statement as the talks began urging the diplomats to find ``a solution to allow an end to the murderous conflict tearing apart Cambodia that prevents a return to power by the Khmer Rouge.'' About a dozen supporters of the non-Communist resistance in Cambodia gathered outside the International Conference Center to protest the Khmer Rouge and the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh. ``The people of Cambodia cannot and the free world should not resign themselves to an alternative between two despotisms,'' said a statement signed by 41 French parliamentarians supporting the protesters. Hundreds of thousands of people died during the Communist Khmer Rouge's 3{-year grip on power, which ended when Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978. Since September, when Vietnam said it withdrew the last of its troops from Cambodia, concern has risen that the Khmer Rouge would again seize power. The Security Council delegates likely will focus on an Australian proposal for an interim U.N. administration to run Cambodia until free elections can be held. Cambodia's disputed seat in the United Nations, held by the three-party guerrilla alliance since 1982, would be left vacant until a new government is elected. The plan received a boost Friday after a Soviet deputy foreign minister, Igor Rogachev, announced the Soviet Union and China have agreed the United Nations should play ``a very major role'' in a settlement. The announcement holds promise for the talks since the Soviets arm the Communist government of Prime Minister Hun Sen and China arms the Khmer Rouge, the strongest rebel group. France, Britain, and the United States have reacted favorably to the Australian plan. Vietnam and Phnom Penh have lent conditional support. So has Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the alliance, and former Prime Minister Son Sann, head of its smallest faction.

DOC.HEAD: Government Declares Young People Adults
DOC.TEXT: About 1.8 million 20-year-olds officially became adults today in ceremonies commemorating Coming of Age Day, a national holiday. Women dressed in beautiful pink and gold Japanese kimonos, and men in Western suits filled the streets of Tokyo, in keeping with a custom in which young people are given new clothes upon reaching maturity.
