But instead of heading for ancient temples to be confirmed as adults in religious or cultural rites, the young people went to municipal offices where mayors presided over brief ceremonies and urged them to be good citizens. Coming of Age Day has little meaning as a rite of passage for many contemporary Japanese youth, however. At 20 years old they gain the legal right to drink, smoke and vote for the first time. But many young Japanese and been drinking and smoking for years, and many 20-year-old do not even attend the event. Ritsuko Hagiwara, a university student in Tokyo, wrote the leading newspaper Asahi Shimbun that she decided not to participate in the holiday and would use money from her parents intended for a new kimono instead for a trip abroad with friends. ``Although I was attracted by the gorgeous invitation (sent by the city government), I've begun to have doubts about the whole thing. Coming-of-Age Day was originally supposed to celebrate becoming an adult and afterward one was supposed to be able to live independently. ... But I'm still a student, and will have to be taken care of by my parents for the next three years,'' she wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Chuck Stuart's Crime Tarnished a City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, `Boston was ...' to ADD that Flynn helped lead opposition to busing.
DOC.TEXT: Charles Stuart's crime went far beyond the murder of his pregnant wife, rushing an undercurrent of racial tensions to the surface that spread fresh dirt on a city often portrayed as an educational and cultural center. ``It became a crime story that played nationally because it fit so neatly with our national tragedy of racial discord,'' said Mayor Raymond L. Flynn. ``The ... most evil thing about this awful fraud was that it hurt the heart and the soul of a city that has worked so hard to break down the racial barriers that for years divided it.'' The bullet that killed Carol Stuart touched everyone for the worst, including the state of Massachusetts and its governor, Michael S. Dukakis, who have been the butt of daily ridicule for big spending, taxes, low bond ratings and the falling star of the ``Massachusetts Miracle'' economy. But this time, public anger, mostly from blacks, was directed at Flynn and Boston police. It was the mayor who ordered a giant dragnet in the Mission Hill neighborhood after Stuart told authorities that a black gunman forced his way into the white couple's car as they left a hospital birthing class Oct. 23, then robbed and shot them. Stuart's desperate pleas over his car phone that guided police to the couple were later broadcast and published nationally along with photos of him and his mortally wounded wife bloodied in their car. The grim images exacerbated white fears of a crime-ridden city where in the two months before there had been nearly 200 shootings in neighborhoods where large numbers of blacks live. Before Mrs. Stuart's murder, police had been fanning through the neighborhoods frisking black men in efforts to halt the crime spree. Then, with the city outraged over the murder of Mrs. Stuart, blacks said police were out of control, violating their constitutional rights and trying to intimidate them. As it turned out, Stuart's story was the big lie. When police started to close in on him after a brother, Matthew, fingered him, Stuart leaped off a bridge Jan. 4. His suicide cleared a black man who had been labeled by police sources as the prime suspect, William Bennett, a 39-year-old ex-convict with a record of 60 arrests, including jail time for shooting a policeman. The city's image was further tainted as black witnesses charged that police had manipulated evidence and put words in their mouths that pinned the crime on Bennett. Flynn, a potential Democratic gubernatorial candidate this year, was so concerned about Boston's image as well as his own that he devoted nearly half his annual State of the City speech last Wednesday to the Stuart case. ``When I ordered an aggressive police reponse ... I wanted to send a strong signal _ as strong as I could _ to show the city's outrage, and to show that we would not tolerate such an act,'' he said. Boston was branded a racist city 15 years ago when forced busing to integrate city schools erupted in violence. ``Just as today, the stereotype was accepted,'' said Flynn, who as a city councilor during the 1970s helped lead the opposition to busing. What seemed to gall whites more than anything was that Stuart was able to pull off the hoax. ``I'm embarrassed what it did to the city,'' said Jeanine Fowler, a 34-year-old bartender at the Bull and Finch Pub, a tourist spot on which the bar in the TV show ``Cheers'' is modeled. ``He took advantage of our prejudices that we all do have. People say Boston is supposed to be such an educated city and cultural center, and then this happens and that makes us preying on the black community. And he (Stuart) created this all himself.'' On the Thursday that Stuart committed suicide, news of his plunge into Boston Harbor was all over the television in the Bull and Finch. While the local customers and the help were watching for every new detail, most of the tourists were more interested in seeing the city's sights. Ashley McCown, a marketing associate for the Massachusetts Office of Travel and Tourism, said there is no way to judge how the Stuart case might affect the more than $8 billion tourism business in the state. But Bob Cumings, president of the Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau, said he had just returned from major industry meetings in New Orleans and there was no indication anyone was considering scratching Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Government Promises to Consult with Opposition on Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with government pledging to consult with opposition on elections; picks up 4th pvs, `In its...'
DOC.TEXT: The new government today promised to consult all opposition parties on the timing of elections this year but said it would make the final decision on the balloting. Trials were scheduled to begin today for members of the Nicolae Ceasescu's hated Securitate secret police in Timisoara, police said. Protests in the western city ignited a popular revolution last month that toppled the Communist dictator. Other trials for Ceausescu colleagues, including one of his sons, will begin this week on charges of aiding genocide and bringing on economic ruin, state television reported. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were found guilty of such charges and executed Dec. 25. Dragos Munteanu, a spokesman for the governing National Salvation Front, said no decision has yet been made to delay the scheduled April parliamentary vote, despite opposition parties' demands for more time to organize their compaigns. He said the government would consult the opposition parties and delay the elections ``if the political forces are for it.'' But he added that he favors holding the vote as soon as possible. Munteanu said the hasty decision to outlaw the Communist Party Friday night, a move that the provisional government overturned Saturday in favor of submitting the issue to national referendum, showed the need for quick elections. The questions of banning the party and capital punishment will be submitted to a national referendum Jan. 28. Calling the party ban a mistake made of inexperience, Munteanu said, ``This is one of the reasons to have the elections as soon as possible, to have a legal government, a parliament.'' Romanians still have to learn the principles of democracy, he said. ``When I speak about learning democracy, even the government has to learn it,'' he said. ``We don't have real statesmen and politicians. They have to learn it.'' In its report Sunday, state television showed Valentin Ceausescu, a son of the deposed dictator; former Communist Party Secretary Emil Bobu; former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu; Marin Neagoe, who directed personal security for Ceausescu; and Dimitru Popescu, former director of the Sociopolitical Academy. The five are being investigated for abetting genocide and sabotaging the economy, which was squeezed dry by Ceausescu's payoff of Romania's foreign debt of more than $10 billion between 1982 and 1989, Romanian television said. Interim Foreign Minister Sergiu Celac told reporters that Romania's economy is in ``almost complete ruin'' and that the country needs massive food imports to feed its 23 million people. The genocide allegation refers to the thousands killed during December's popular uprising _ during which Securitate units fought army troops and civilian revolutionaries _ as well as victims of political repression during Ceausescu's 24-year reign. The exact charges to be levied at the trial have not been disclosed. Valentin, Ceausescu's eldest son, was a member of the Communist Party's policy-setting Central Committee. Bobu was Ceausescu's closest associate in running Romania after the dictator's wife, Elena. Ceausescu's youngest son, Nicu, and his daughter Zoya were arrested soon after he was overthrown. But they were not shown on television over the weekend. There was no indication exactly when or where the trials would take place, but interim President Ion Iliescu told a mass rally Friday that the trials would be public and televised.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Kept Close Ties to Noriega Before Indictment, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs of former DEA chief's quotes after 5th graf, Quiel also
DOC.TEXT: While federal prosecutors were moving to indict Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega on narcotics charges, the Drug Enforcement Administration was maintaining close ties with him and offering praise for his cooperation in the war against drugs, a congressional report shows. ``The DEA has long welcomed our close association and we stand ready to proceed jointly against international drug traffickers whenever the opportunity arises,'' drug enforcement administrator Jack Lawn wrote to Noriega less than a year before the indictment was entered in federal court in Miami in February 1988. Lawn had special praise for the work of Luis Quiel, Noriega's liaison to the DEA, as ``integral to the success of fighting international drug trafficking.'' But according to the final report of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on narcotics, issued in December 1988, Quiel was also Noriega's liaison to the Medellin drug cartel and ``thus in a position to alert the drug traffickers to whatever information the DEA had provided him.'' Quiel also acted ``as Noriega's enforcer to eliminate competitors of the Medellin cartel by turning them over to the United States,'' the panel said. Lawn's predecessor as DEA administrator, Francis M. Mullen, told The Day newspaper of New London, Conn., last week that he had been surprised by Noriega's indictment because ``he was our fair-haired boy down there.'' ``Whenever we'd ask him for help, he'd always give it to us,'' said Mullen, who left DEA in 1985. The report, issued in December 1988 after a three-year investigation, paints a vivid portrait of Noriega and his involvement with drugs, money laundering, gun running and other illegal activities over his 20-year rise to power as Panama's military strongman. The first links between Panamanian officials and narcotics traffickers were forged while Gen. Omar Torrijos ruled Panama, the report said. But after Torrijos died in an airplane crash in 1981, Noriega took charge of the country's most important institutions, using them to generate revenue for officers of the new Panamanian Defense Force and to exercise control over the drug traffic. Before he was ousted last month by the U.S. invasion of his country, Noriega controlled the customs, immigration and passport services, civil aeronautics, the National Bank of Panama and the attorney general's office. He pushed legislation through the national assembly consolidating the National Guard, navy, police and customs into a unified Panamanian Defense Force under his command. ``As head of the PDF, Noriega now controlled all elements of the Panamanian government essential to the protection of drug trafficking and money laundering, increasing his control over Panama and enriching himself,'' the panel said. One witness, Ramon Milian Rodriguez, a Miami-based, Cuban-born accountant, testified he negotiated an agreement with Noriega in 1979 on behalf of the Medellin cartel which gave Noriega a commission to provide security and handling for drug money arriving in Panama to be laundered through its banking system. PDF soldiers met planes ferrying billions of dollars in cash from Miami, guarded the money as it was loaded into armored cars and delivered it to the Banco Nacionale de Panama, according to the subcommittee. Milian Rodriguez said Noriega eliminated him as a middleman in 1983 by arranging to have information about his money laundering operation passed on to the DEA. The tip resulted in his arrest and eventual prison sentence. The panel said it had evidence to corroborate Milian Rodriguez' story that Noriega's cronies then took control of the money laundering business. Soon Noriega's associates began to smuggle narcotics themselves using light planes, the panel said. But in 1984, Noriega's interests clashed with those of the Medellin cartel. Noriega, the panel said, had permitted the cartel to establish cocaine processing plants in Panama, including one at La Palma in Darien Province near the Colombian border. It alleged that Noriega accepted $5 million from the drug cartel to protect the facility. But in mid-May 1984, concerned about pressure from the DEA, Noriega ordered his soldiers to raid the plant and arrest its employees. Feeling betrayed, the cartel's leaders ordered Noriega's assassination, the panel said, quoting a Noriega associate, former Panamanian intelligence official Jose Blandon. Blandon testified that Noriega turned to Cuban Premier Fidel Castro, and accepted Castro's recommendation that he return the $5 million and the plant machinery and release the 23 persons who had been arrested. U.S. law enforcement agencies continued to view Noriega as a friend of the United States, the subcommittee said. Lawn, the DEA administrator, wrote Noriega on May 8, 1986, stating the DEA's ``appreciation for the vigorous anti-drug trafficking policy that you have adopted which is reflected in the numerous expulsions from Panama of accused traffickers...'' The subcommittee noted Lawn's testimony that Noriega was actively cooperating in such areas as crop eradication, narcotics investigations, money laundering and drug interdiction. Because the DEA shared information with the Panamanian government, drug dealers linked to Noriega were advised whether or not their planes were on a DEA watch list, the report said, quoting witnesses. Francis McNeil, former U.S. ambassador to Costa Rica, told the panel that while law enforcement and intelligence agencies worked closely with Noriega, the State Department did not trust him. In June 1986, he said, a State Department investigation concluded that Noriega was corrupt but there was no clear evidence that he was involved with narcotics.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Party Chief Elected Republic's President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with vote to limit voting rights; picks up 5th pvs, `Brazauskas, 57...' SUBS 3 grafs for 10th pvs, `The Lithuanian...' to ADD background on vote, previous Lithuanian president. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's Communist Party chief was overwhelmingly elected the republic's president today in a clear endorsement of his defiant stand toward Moscow and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Algirdas Brazauskas was elected 228-4, with 19 abstentions, by the republic's Supreme Soviet legislature, the Tass news agency reported. The republic's Supreme Soviet also voted to limit voting rights for military personnel, requiring them to have lived in Lithuania for at least 10 years, said Eduardas Potasinskas, a journalist for Lithuanian TV. The measure in effect restricts voting in local elections Feb. 24 to servicemen from Lithuania or a few long-serving soldiers and sailors. Brazauskas, 57, faced alternative candidates: national legislator Kazimeras Motieka and Romualdas Ozolas, a leader of the pro-independence group Sajudis. Potasinskas said the vote will ``strengthen the position of Brazauskas in dealing with Moscow.'' Brazauskas backed the Lithuanian party's decision Dec. 20 to break away from the national Communist Part, the first such break since the Communists took over in Moscow in 1917. Gorbachev, who had denounced the move, visited Lithuania from Thursday through Saturday to try to persuade Lithuanian Communists to reverse their decision. The Lithuanians refused to budge and Gorbachev failed to end the schism. He concluded his visit Saturday by saying he saw ``no tragedy'' in a multiparty system _ a change from his previous unconditional call for a one-party system. Gorbachev pleaded for unity repeatedly but was confronted by pro-independence demonstrators at many stops. Public opinion strongly supports independence for the Baltic republic of 3.7 million, which was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Brazauskas has been the Lithuanian party's first secretary since Oct. 20, 1988. His new title, the equivalent of president, is chairman of the Presidium of the republic's Supreme Soviet. He takes over from Vytautas Astrauskas, who resigned. Astrauskas, 59, had served as the republic's president since December 1987. He was regarded by Lithuanian activists as a conservative, but not a vehement opponent of the independence drive. There was no discussion at the Supreme Soviet of how many people the voting restrictions would affect, and the Soviet Union does not publicize the number of military personnel stationed in its republics. Lithuanian progressives feared their favored candidates would not fare as well as they could if the servicemen were allowed to vote. But the national government has struck down similar attempts to restrict voting rights in other republics.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest Cuts In Train Service
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people demonstrated across Canada to protest massive reductions in passenger rail service, which left some communities without train stops today. Two people were killed in a train-truck collision Sunday on the final daily run of the Canadian, the famous transcontinental, and the last passenger train run from Sydney in Nova Scotia to Halifax was canceled because protesters padlocked themselves to the locomotive. As of today, the transcontinental run known for its scenic views is being changed to a different route and reduced to three times a week. As cries of ``All aboard!'' were heard Sunday for the last time in some towns, Via Rail passengers and employees directed their rage at the federal government, which decided in October to cut Via's subsidies to $350 million by 1992 from $640 million in 1988. Under the cuts, 17 of Via's 38 routes were eliminated, as were 2,700 jobs _ 38 percent of the workforce. The service reductions went into effect today after a federal court ruled Friday that a formal environmental review was not needed. ``I think it's wrong _ it's going to hurt national unity,'' Julia Conley, 64, told about 450 people at Toronto's Union Station in a voice quavering with emotion. Sunday's protests attracted hundreds of people in cities such as Halifax, Ottawa and Toronto. Two people were killed when the Canadian collided with a pickup truck at a crossing in a residential area near Pembroke, Ontario, about 60 miles west of Ottawa, police said. The train continued on its run from Montreal to Vancouver. ``It's quite a way to end it all,'' said conductor Don Green, who is retiring after 34 years. ``I haven't seen something like this in 15 or 20 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Assures Polish President of Further Japanese Economic Support
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan today assured President Wojciech Jaruzelski of further economic support for Poland as economic experts discussed terms of promised Japanese credit guarantees. Kaifu also met with with non-Communist Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and the leaders of both chambers of Parliament on the final day of his two-day visit. He is scheduled to travel to Hungary later today to wrap up his seven- country tour of Europe. The state news agency PAP said Kaifu told Jaruzelski that Japan would increase its support for the changes under way in Poland, particularly in financial cooperation. Poland and Japan signed an agreement Sunday in which Tokyo pledged a $150 million credit to a stabilization fund to back the zloty as it becomes a convertible currency. Japan also agreed to provide Poland with $25 million in food aid, and $15 million to help train Polish managers. The two countries also discussed a possible $350 million guarantee for government investments and a $500 million guarantee by the Japanese Export-Import Bank for Japanese investments in Poland. Poland is also hoping for Japanese support during negotiations on Poland's $40 billion foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Recorded in Eastern Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook eastern Taiwan today but there were no immediate reports of casualties or serious damage. The quake, which measured a preliminary 5.8 on the Richter scale of ground motion, struck at 8:42 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau said. The epicenter was about 20 miles north of Hualien, a city in eastern Taiwan 75 south of Taipei. The quake was felt in Taipei, where residents reported that it shook furniture. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake registering 6 on the scale can cause severe damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Successfully Test Navigation System That Sounded an Alarm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to recast, CORRECT number of phantom signals to five, sted three. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Mission Control reported...'. SUBS 9-13th grafs pvs, `Controllers were...', with 6 grafs to add flight director's comments on navigation system problem, update with weather now good at landing sites. Picks up 14th graf, `Mission Control said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts settled into a day of medical and science experiments today after their sleep was interrupted by an alarm signaling a brief problem with a navigation system. The five phantom signals that triggered the buzzing alarm posed no threat to the mission, and the five crew members went back to bed. After waking at the normal time, commander Dan Brandenstein successfully tested the system and brought it back on line. Mission Control reported the fleeting signals were in a speed-measuring accelerometer that is part of what's known as an Inertial Measurement Unit, a key component of the shuttle's guidance system. When the alarm sounded in the cabin as the astronauts slept, Brandenstein woke up and asked the control center if there were anything he could do. Controllers told him the spaceship computer had shifted automatically to a second IMU, that everything was OK and to go back to sleep. There are three such devices aboard. Only one is needed for a safe flight, but flight rules dictate that if one failed, Mission Control would consider bringing the astronauts home as soon as possible because of the possibility of a common problem in all three units. When the astronauts were wakened at the regular time two hours after the alarm, they were told that scientists on the ground had monitored the suspect unit and had detected no further problems. Brandenstein was told to put it back in operation and realign it by aiming at two stars. ``The crew successfully did some celestial navigation,'' said Mission Control commentator Brian Welch. ``We just got word that all looks good. IMUs 1, 2 and 3 are all chugging along in good shape.'' Flight director Al Pennington said that five transient signals were received in a 10-minute program, each indicating either a lack of acceleration or a minus acceleration. The problem may not be with the accelerometer but with one of the systems that transmits the data to Mission Control, Pennington said. Specialists were attempting to find out what went wrong, he said. Weather over North Africa was clear today and the astronauts snapped pictures of Lake Chad, the Nile Valley and fires in Kenya for an IMAX film called ``Planet Earth,'' which will document damage that man and nature are doing to the planet. They also probed and poked one another with medical instruments, seeking information on how the human body adapts over time to space weightlessness. Officials earlier had reported that if Columbia had to come home early, weather could pose a problem at the primary landing site at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., and a secondary site at White Sands Space Harbor, N.M. But Pennington said a new forecast calls for good weather both days at both places. He also said the weather was good today over the runway at the Kennedy Space Center launch site at Cape Canaveral. Mission Control said the weather for Friday's planned landing at Edwards looked good. A nighttime touchdown is scheduled for 2:59 a.m. PST. The wakeup music today was the University of Washington fight song. One of the crew members, mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar, is a Washington graduate. ``Good morning for your second wakeup of the morning,'' the control center said, referring to the earlier alarm. Brandenstein, Dunbar, pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Marsha Ivins and David Low are devoting the final days of the flight to experiments after accomplishing their main goals during the first half of the mission. They deployed a Navy communications satellite on the second day, and on the fourth day they snagged an errant 11-ton science laboratory, and stowed it in the cargo bay for return to Earth. One experiment that suffered a mishap on Friday was restored to health on Sunday. It involves melting and resolidifying a metal, indium, to determine how the material reacts to the process in weightless space.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Open on Withdrawal of Soviet Troops
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia began talks today with the Soviet Union on the withdrawal of about 75,000 Soviet troops, and one source said Czechoslovak officials want at least half of the force out by May. On the eve of the talks, about 6,000 people protested in the town of Pohorany, demanding the entire Soviet force leave by Aug. 21 _ the 22nd anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion that crushed the Prague Spring reforms. Foreign Ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky said last week that the Soviet forces should leave Czechoslovakia by the end of the year. ``The idea is to have them (Soviets) make a political commitment during these talks that all the troops will leave by the end of the year,'' the source said on condition of anonymity. ``The rough idea of the time frame on the Czechoslovak side is to see a 50 to 60 percent withdrawal by mid-May,'' the source said, adding the talks should focus on technical details of the pullout as well as its precise timing. No details emerged from the talks, led by Deputy Foreign Minister Evzen Vacek and his Soviet counterpart, Ivan Aboimov. The source said demands for the complete withdrawal before Aug. 21 were ``technically out of the question.'' He noted it took a year to withdraw 5,300 soldiers, 708 tanks and 200 planes from Czechoslovakia in 1989 as part of a Kremlin move to withdraw about 50,000 troops from Eastern Europe. A peaceful revolution in November and December toppled the hard-line Communist government. Dissident playwright Vaclav Havel is now president and Alexander Dubcek, the former Communist Party chief who sponsored many of the Prague Spring reforms in 1968, is head of Parliament. In another development today, a South Korean government delegation arrived in Prague to discuss establishing diplomatic relations, the state CTK news agency reported. The delegation was invited by the Foreign Ministry, CTK said. South Korea, which is staunchly anti-Communist, has established formal diplomatic ties with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia in recent months. In December, South Korea and Czechoslovakia agreed to open trade offices in each other's countries.

DOC.HEAD: Italy's Neo-fascists Elect New Secretary
DOC.TEXT: Giuseppe Rauti, who as a youth joined the forces of dictator Benito Mussolini, was elected leader of Italy's neo-fascist party today. Rauti, 63, defeated Gianfranco Fini, 38, by a vote of 744-697 to lead the Italian Social Movement. Fini had led the party since 1987. The vote came at the end of a heated congress during which police were called in to break up fistfights between rival factions. The Italian Social Movement is Italy's fourth-largest party in Parliament and holds 6 percent of the seats in the Chamber of Deputies. It currently is an opposition party. Fini had been the designated successor of Giorgio Almirante, one of the party's founders and its longtime leader who died in 1988. Rauti is considered anti-capitalist and anti-American. The Italian Social Movement held its congress in the Adriatic resort of Rimini, not far from Mussolini's hometown of Predappio, where party members went to honor his grave during the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: 1,200 Arrest in Crackdown on Crime
DOC.TEXT: Police and national guard units stopped and searched vehicles today and have arrested 1,200 people as part of a crackdown on street crime, authorities said. President Carlos Andres Perez ordered about 5,000 police and national guard troops on the streets of Caracas earlier this month after the slaying of Luis Federico Carbonnell, a University of Massachusetts professor who was visiting relatives. Three men and a woman have been arrested and charged with the slaying, which police said came in an attempt to steal his car in a middle-class neighborhood. The slaying prompted Perez to announce a restructuring of police forces and step up the patrols, but several people today doubted whether the effort would end violence that is tied to economic problems. ``What they're trying to do is avoid another (riot),'' said Luis Emiro Alvarez, a teen-ager who said he'd been stopped by police asking him for identification. In February, riots broke out following price increases in food and public transportation claimed 300 lives and thousands injured. Police and national guard units today concentrated on major thoroughfares and stopped cars and buses instead of dispersing into the outlying slums, where most crime takes place. About 1,200 prisoners were taken into custody over the weekend, national guard spokesmen said. The majority of the prisoners were young men guilty of illegal weapons possesion, drug smuggling and lack of proper documentation, said Luis Garcia Morales, national guard lieutenant. ``Nobody can deny that we have restored tranquility to Caracas,'' he said. ``Pay attention because this could be one of the few nights Caracas has no crimes and no criminals.''

DOC.HEAD: 10 School Childern Die, 33 Others Survive Collision
DOC.TEXT: A boat carrying children to an elementary school collided with a cargo vessel and capsized today, killing 10 of the pupils, the state news agency Bernama reported. Thirty-three people swam ashore or were rescued from the accident in a river near the town of Sapi, about 970 miles east of Kuala Lumpur, Bernama reported. A Sabah state official, Hassan Abdul Mutalib, was quoted as saying a police search party had recovered the bodies of nine of the children while the search for the tenth body continued. No further details were available.

DOC.HEAD: Veterinarian Hospitalized Following Chimp Attack
DOC.TEXT: A chimpanzee went on a rampage as it was being moved early this morning and bit off a veterinarian's ear and part of one hand, police said. Dr. John C. Kelliher, 43, of Adelphi was helping William C. Holmberg transfer two chimps from their cages to a transport cage when one of the animals forced its way loose and attacked Kelliher, police said. Holmberg hit the chimp, a 20-year-old male, with a large metal pipe, said state Trooper Clint Irvin. As the chimp released Kelliher, Holmberg managed to push the injured veterinarian into an empty animal cage and lock the door. When police officers arrived, Holmberg borrowed a gun from one of them and shot the chimp four times, but the animal remained alive until another officer destroyed it with one more shot. Kelliher was flown to Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh, where he was listed in fair condition. The thumb, fourth and fifth fingers on one hand were amputated, his left ear was bitten off, and he was also bitten on his face, head, scalp and forearm. Holmberg used to run a zoo at a small amusement park in Westmoreland County, and has been taking care of the chimps and assorted exotic birds since it closed about five years ago, said police dispatcher Marilyn Sinsabaugh. The chimps were being taken to a laboratory in Maryland when the attack occurred around 2:15 a.m., Sinsabaugh said. She didn't know why they were going to the lab.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Victims Arrive for Medical Treatment in Israel
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-one Soviet children who were injured by radiation in the Chernobyl nuclear accident arrived in Israel today for a month of medical tests. Last month, a group of 52 children from the Chernobyl area spent three weeks on vacation in Israel. The visits are part of a thaw between the two nations, which have not had full diplomatic ties since the Kremlin broke relations in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. Today's group arrived on a special flight of the Soviet airline Aeroflot from the Ukrainian capital of Kiev. In addition to the children, aged 6 to 13, there were three Soviet firemen who were exposed to large doses of radiation as well as five doctors and a Soviet television crew. Israeli doctors who studied the children's dossiers in Kiev and returned home Sunday said some were not properly treated following the April 1986 catastrophe at the nuclear power plant. The children suffer from blood disorders, anemia, glandular problems, loss of hair and other symptoms associated with radiation sickness, Israeli doctors said. The group was brought here at the initiative of Histadrut, Israel's trade union federation, which will pay the medical costs. The flight was paid for by Ukrainian trade unions. Israeli doctors said the children would undergo medical tests at Beilinson Hospital in suburban Tel Aviv that would help properly diagnose their health status and offer further treatment. Rina Zaitzev of the hospital's oncology department said 10 children would be treated each day while others would travel in Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Italian, Israeli Honored in Mathematics
DOC.TEXT: The Wolf Foundation announced Monday that Ennio de Giorgi of Italy and Ilya Piatetski-Shapiro, an Israeli immigrant from the Soviet Union, will share this year's $100,000 prize for mathematics. The awards will be presented in May, along with prizes for physics, chemistry, agriculture, medicine and the arts. De Giorgi, 61, a professor in Pisa, holds a degree in mathematics from the University of Rome and since 1959 has taught at the Scuola Normale Superiore, a university in Pisa. Piatetski-Shapiro, 60, teaches mathematics at Tel Aviv University and at Yale University. He earned his doctorate at the Moscow Pedagogical Institute and taught at Moscow University before immigrating to Israel in the mid-1970s. The Wolf Foundation Prizes were established in 1975 by the late Ricardo Wolf ``to promote science and art for the benefit of mankind.'' Wolf was a German-born inventor and philanthropist who emigrated to Cuba and served as its ambassador to Israel. He died here in 1981. Last year's winners in mathematics were professors John W. Milnor of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University and Alberto P. Calderon of the University of Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Politician Wounded, Union Leader Reported Beaten
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ An opposition politician was shot and wounded and a union leader was arrested and beaten by soldiers during an anti-government strike, radio reports said. Jude Jean-Jacques, head of the tiny Radical People's Power Youth Association, was hit in the shoulder Friday by a bullet fired from a passing car into a group of protesters, independent Radio Haiti Inter said. He remained hospitalized Monday. His condition was not released. Nelly Bouarnais, general secretary of Haiti's public transport union, was being held Monday without charge in the national penitentiary. The authorities gave no explanation for the arrest. Union officials told Haiti Inter in a weekend broadcast that Bouarnais was beaten by soldiers who arrested him near his home Friday. The 24-hour general strike Friday, organized by 20 opposition political parties and unions to protest the military government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, received little support.

DOC.HEAD: Springsteen, Girlfriend To Be Parents, Spokeswoman Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with report confirmed; CORRECTS typo in Hungry in last graf. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Rock superstar Bruce Springsteen and his girlfriend, Patti Scialfa, are expecting a baby, a spokeswoman said today. Marilyn Laverty, spokeswoman for Columbia Records, the singer's record company, confirmed USA Today's report of the pregnancy but did not say when the baby is due or whether the couple will marry. Springsteen's manager, Jon Landau, did not immediately return a call seeking further comment. Springsteen and Scialfa, his former backup singer, revealed their romance publicly in the spring of 1988, after Springsteen split with his wife, actress Julianne Phillips. He had married Ms. Phillips in 1985; the couple had no children. Springsteen, 40, is known for such hits as ``Born in the U.S.A.,'' ``Hungry Heart'' and ``Born to Run.''

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Bulgaria
With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Recent key events in Bulgaria: Oct. 29, 1989 _ Todor Zhivkov, Communist Party chief since 1954, responds to a public protest by promising reform. Nov. 3 _ Anti-Zhivkov rally draws 9,000 people. Nov. 10 _ Zhivkov is ousted and replaced by Petar Mladenov, considered more moderate. Nov. 17 _ Parliament scraps a law that forbids dissent. Nov. 18 _ In the largest protest since Bulgaria became a Communist nation, 50,000 people demand more democracy, free elections, respect for human rights and an end to 45 years of police repression. Dec. 8 _ Four full members and two candidate members of the Communist Party's Politburo and 20 members of the policy-setting Central Committee, including Zhivkov, are removed from their posts. Dec. 10 _ Rally draws 50,000 people in support of an independent opposition. Dec. 11 _ Two-day Central Committee session starts, and 15,000 people hold vigils outside Communist Party headquarters. Mladenov proposes removing a law guaranteeing the party's leading role, opening a dialogue with opposition groups, holding an early party congress in March and nationwide free elections in May. Dec. 27 _ Government and opposition _ the Union of Democratic Forces _ agree to hold talks. Government dismisses Interior Minister Georgi Tanev. Jan. 8-9, 1990 _ Demonstrations and unrest break out over restoration of certain rights to the Turkish minority, which was forcibly assimilated under Zhivkov. Jan. 12 _ Government commission says Zhivkov will be charged with corruption and put on trial. Jan. 12-13 _ Government agrees to retain Bulgarian as official language in return for a halt to anti-Turkish protests. Sunday _ Rally draws 50,000 people demanding faster reforms and two-stage elections in May and November. Monday _ Parliament abolishes guaranteed leading role of Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Said to Have Sold Guns to Both Right and Left
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's former military strongman, was heavily involved in international gunrunning, working both sides of the political street, according to Senate investigators. At one point, pilots flying weapons for Noriega to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua are said by witnesses to have flown on to the United States with a cargo of narcotics. Noriega, who controlled Panama security apparatus, was well positioned to engaged in ``the gray market arms business,'' according to the 1988 report of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on narcotics headed by Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. Even before the death of Gen. Omar Torrijos, then Panama's ruling figure, in a mysterious 1981 plane crash, Noriega had the authority to issue certificates to legitimize the shipment of foreign arms to Panama. ``Once in Panama, Noriega would sell the weapons to whomever bid the most for them,'' the committee said, citing the testimony of Jose Blandon, a former Panamanian intelligence official and one-time Noriega adviser. Blandon told the subcommittee that Noriega's earliest clients in the late 1970's included the Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua, who were successfully battling to oust that country's dictator, Anastasio Somoza. Noriega's associates purchased the weapons in Europe, brought them to Panama and then moved them into neighboring Costa Rica for shipment to the Sandinistas. Quoting Blandon, the report said that those buying guns for Noriega included Michael Harari, a retired agent of the Israeli intelligence service, Mossad. Harari, who traveled to Israel immediately after U.S. troops invaded Panama last month, has been described as one of Noreiga's closest advisers, a description he rejects as false. The Senate panel reported that although Noriega sold many weapons to the Sandinistas, ``many more wound up in storage when the Sandinista war ended in 1979.'' Floyd Carlton, a former Noriega pilot, testified that the excess weapons were then ``marketed by Panama to the rebels in El Salvador.'' Carlton said he and his partner, Cesar Rodriguez, flew the weapons to El Salvador in 1980 using Panamanian military aircraft. On one trip the plane Rodriguez was flying was damaged on takeoff and crashed when it attempted to land in El Salvador. Carlton, flying a second Panamanian plane on the same weapons-delivery mission, said he pulled Rodriguez from the aircraft, put him on his plane and flew to Panama, where they both went into hiding. ``When Salvadoran officials discovered the wreckage of the Panamanian Defense Forces plane, the origin of the weapons was obvious,'' the panel said. Noriega, seeking to expand his arms business, used his contacts with his military intelligence counterparts in Latin America ``to find and develop weapons markets which he could supply profitably,'' the panel said. In an apparent disregard for the ideology of his customers, one such market became the Contra rebels in Nicaragua battling the now-ruling leftist Sandinistas, the panel said. But the arms transfers to the Contras had a double-edged thrust, according to participants. Many of the Panamanian pilots carried mixed cargos of guns and drugs, the committee was told. When they reached Costa Rica, they unloaded the weapons and flew onto the United States with the narcotics, a witness, Werner Lotz, told the panel.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Puts Department Store Chains Under Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The filing...', to DELETE incorrect reference to overdue bills.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp., owner of Bloomingdale's and many other famous American department stores, today placed them under bankruptcy court protection, allowing the debt-swamped chains to operate while attempting to work out their troubles. The decision to file for Chapter 11 protection was made late Sunday by the boards of Campeau and its Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. subsidiaries, which operate 260 stores in the United States, including Rich's, Jordan Marsh and Lazarus as well as Bloomingdale's. It is the biggest Chapter 11 filing in American retailing history and reflects Campeau's inability to pay off $8 billion in debt, much of it acquired when the Canadian parent acquired the two U.S. subsidiaries in the mid-1980s. The filing followed weeks of speculation in the retail trade over how Campeau would deal with the problems of operating its chains while continuing to pay suppliers. ``The decision to seek Chapter 11 relief was based on a conclusion that action was required at this time in order to preserve the operations strength and assets of the two department store companies while the corporate debt is restructured,'' Campeau said in a news release. Campeau said the filing was made in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Ohio in Cincinnati. Federated and Allied are based in Cincinnati. Carol Sanger, a Cincinnati-based spokeswoman for Campeau, said U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug hadn't issued any orders about appointment of trustees or set court hearings. The court opened briefly on the Martin Luther King holiday to receive the Campeau filing. Under a Chapter 11 filing, the companies get a reprieve from creditor bills and can continue operations while reorganizing their finances. But all decisions regarding the companies must be approved by a bankruptcy judge. Sanger said Federated and Allied would notify suppliers today of the filing. Toronto-based Campeau, which also owns commercial real estate and shopping malls in the United States, stated that all of its U.S. stores would remain open and the company expected all customer services, such as credit card purchases and merchandise returns, to continue normally. One of the chains, Lazarus, ran full-page ads in Cincinnati and Columbus newspapers today saying it was conducting ``Business As Usual.'' Maria Kaldis, a clerk at a downtown Columbus Lazarus, said employees learned about the bankruptcy filing early this morning. ``This won't affect the employees at all,'' she said. ``That's something that doesn't involve us. It's business as usual.'' In addition to the Chapter 11 filing, the companies announced today they had negotiated further bank financing to cover their current cash needs. Federated said it had an agreement in principle with a bank syndicate led by Citibank for $400 million in financing, while Allied had a similar agreeement from Chemical bank for $300 million. Both are subject to agreement by the syndicates and approval by the bankruptcy court. A number of analysts have said a Chapter 11 filing could benefit Federated and Allied, by reassuring suppliers they would get paid if they continued shipping merchandise to the troubled stores. Suppliers who ship merchandise to the stores after the Chapter 11 filing would take precedence over many other creditors in getting paid. On Sunday, Campeau had announced it won a five-day reprieve from a group of banks for a deadline today for deciding whether the company was in default on a $2.34 billion loan arrangement. The banks, lead by Citibank, earlier granted a two-week extension for the troubled Toronto-based company to prove that it was able to repay the loan. One analyst said the bank move appeared to be in reaction to a decision by Campeau's board of directors Thursday to split the U.S. retailing units from the parent company and place them under independent trustees and directors. Under the restructuring announced Thursday, company founder Robert Campeau lost control of the retailing operations. He will continue to run Campeau Corp.'s real estate and development interests, which are based in Toronto. Also last week, Campeau made a $100 million payment for merchandise shipped to its stores between Thanksgiving and Christmas. There had been speculation that the company could not make the payment on schedule. Observers said Campeau apparently wanted to keep good relations with its suppliers so they would ship spring merchandise. A decline in sales at the stores due to a merchandise shortage could make the stores less valuable should they be sold to raise cash or as part of a bankruptcy reorganization. In a joint statement, John W. Burden III, chairman and chief executive f Federated and Allied, and James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of the companies, said they expected the Chapter 11 filing to have a positive effect on their businesses by allowing the retailers to concentrate on sales rather than their financial problems. ``At the same time, under Chapter 11 protection, corporate management will have the necessary time to aggressively address the problems that exist at the corporate level with the burdensome capital structure that precipitated today's actions.'' Campeau already has put Bloomingdale's up for sale as part of its broad restructuring attempt. Burden and Zimmerman stated the company would continue receiving bids for Bloomingdale's as part of the Chapter 11 proceedings. Allied owns the Jordan Marsh, The Bon Marche, Maas Brothers and Stern's department stores. In addition to Bloomingdale's, Federated runs the Burdine's, Lazarus, Abraham & Straus and Rich's chains. Campeau also owns Ralphs, a Southern California supermarket chain spun off from Federated. The business was unaffected by the filings.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Thousands Reportedly Storm Police Offices; Honecker Faces Indictment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with eyewitness accounts, color from scene; Picks up 7th graf, `Chief prosecutor ...'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people today stormed the headquarters of East Germany's hated secret police, and a prosecutor said he will indict former Communist leader Erich Honecker for high treason. The charge, which also will be sought against the former head of the secret police, carries a minimum penalty of 10 years in prison and a maximum of death in ``exceptionally grave cases.'' The situation at secret police headquarters had gotten ``out of control,'' state television reported. The reports forced a hasty suspension of talks between the government and the opposition. ``We are the people! We are the people!'' the protesters shouted as they stormed the building. The official news agency ADN said tens of thousands invaded the building, while state-run television spoke of 100,000 people. Witnesses saw the protesters going through the offices, overturning furniture and scattering documents. Several people went into a store room, carrying away wine, battles of ketchup and other items. Protesters used stones and bricks to break through glass doors to get into the building, according to witnesses. ADN reported that some people were throwing furniture through office windows. The Communist-dominated government has reluctantly agreed to disband the secret police, following massive protests from East Germans. Chief prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph told officials at the government-opposition talks that Honecker and former national security chief Erich Mielke are being investigated for ``anti-constitutional association'' and high treason. Joseph did not say when a formal indictment was expected, although one is virtually certain under East Germany's criminal justice system once an investigation begins. Honecker and Mielke already had been under investigation for corruption and abuse of power. Honecker was removed as Communist Party leader on Oct. 18. He later was thrown out of the party and at one point was under house arrest at a luxury residential complex that had been reserved for party leaders. Mielke headed the secret police, which has become a target of bitter criticism since the Communists were forced to share power in East Germany's peaceful revolution. Communist Premier Hans Modrow today promised to publicize details of how the secret police force is being dismantled and he appealed for an end to strikes. Modrow made the comments at talks between the Communist-led government and an increasingly restive opposition. He had said he would not attend the talks but changed his mind, apparently bowing to opposition pressure. Manfred Sauer, a government official helping to oversee the dismantling of the secret police, told the talks that there had been 85,000 full-time secret police agents and 109,000 informants. That means that up until a few months ago, one out of every 80 people in this country of 16.3 million worked for or routinely cooperated with the secret police. Modrow also promised that ``all available data and acts regarding the dissolution'' of the secret police will be made public. He had planned to replace the secret police, known as ``Stasi,'' with a new force but the opposition bitterly fought the plan and Modrow abandoned it on Friday. He said a new security force was needed to counter the threat of growing neo-Nazi activity. But the opposition said that threat was greatly exaggerated and that a new security agency should be created after the election by a democratically elected government. Modrow initially rejected opposition demands that he attend today's session of the talks, but he changed his mind after facing criticism from pro-democracy groups over the weekend. He appealed for understanding and calm and called on representatives of the 16 political parties and groups present to cooperate in solving the nation's troubles. Those troubles are compounded by the emigration of more than 1,800 people a day to West Germany. ``Public life must not be disturbed by strikes,'' Modrow said during the session, broadcast live on television. In recent days, workers have staged warning strikes in various cities, including Erfurt and East Berlin, to pressure the Communists to share more power and abolish the hated secret police. Modrow said he also would attend next Monday's session of the talks, apparently in an effort to counter opposition allegations he was not taking the negotations seriously. An East German television commentator called Modrow's appearance ``a clever move'' aimed at defusing the growing challenges to his shaky coalition government. There have been doubts as to whether Modrow's coalition can survive until the democratic elections scheduled for May 6. He bowed to previous opposition pressure last week by scrapping plans to form a new secret police agency. Markus Meckel, a leader of the influential Social Democratic party, praised Modrow's appearance and said the premier's statement provided the basis to ``ensure the government's work and competence'' until the elections. The Social Democrats over the weekend called for German unfication and promised to open talks with West Germany if they win the May elections. East Germans demanding curbs on Communist power kept pressure on Modrow's government Sunday with more protests. Several hundred thousand people in several cities attended ceremonies commemorating the 1919 murders of two heroes of the German left. In another development, East Germans began paying higher prices for children's clothing and related articles, and Finance Minister Uta Nickel said apartment rents also were likely to increase. Ms. Nickel did not give specific figures in her interview with the labor federation newspaper Tribuene, but said the government intends to move ahead with dismantling massive government subsidies. And the Israeli newspaper Maariv and army radio reported that Israeli and East German officials plan to meet in the next few days to discuss establishing diplomatic relations. Officials at the Israeli Foreign Ministry said they were checking the report. East German officials were not immediately available for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger to Face Ethics Panel, Admitting `Lapses in Judgment'
DOC.TEXT: Sen. David Durenberger, conceding in advance some of the evidence looks bad, will face the Senate Ethics Committee early next month to give his side of real estate and book promotion deals the panel has been investigating. In the meantime, he has been apologizing and explaining ``lapses in judgement'' to the voters back home, where he won re-election barely a year ago. The Minnesota Republican is tentatively set to appear before the Ethics Committee Feb. 8, while it is still conducting a grand jury-type investigation to determine if there is ``substantial credible evidence'' that he broke Senate rules. The date was confirmed by Senate sources, insisting on anonymity. Saying he was ignoring his attorney's objections, Durenberger broke a yearlong silence on the case in late December. He held a series of news conferences to apologize to fellow Minnesotans, told a home-state newspaper that unreleased statements on his book deal appeared to back allegations against him and blamed his trusted friends for ``sloppy legal work'' that caused some of his problems. Then he stopped talking again. Durenberger has confirmed the Ethics Committee is investigating: _Whether $100,000 he earned in 1985-86 to promote two books should have been counted as speaking fees _ exceeding Senate limits on such honoraria outside income. _Whether it was proper to use special interest groups to underwrite ``dual purpose'' trips to Boston, where he met with a marriage counselor and also held sessions with the organizations that paid his way. _Whether he was right to charge the Senate rent when staying in a Minneapolis condominium he partly owned. In his Minnesota news conferences, Durenberger spoke in personal terms, saying his ethics problems began after he separated from his wife, sought out a Harvard educator-marriage counselor and had to deal with paying for his four sons' education. ``In retrospect, it is clear that I made mistakes and had lapses in judgment on these matters,'' he said. ``I am deeply sorry.'' Last week, Durenberger told the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch that he read a summary of witness statements on the book promotion, prepared by his attorney but not made public. He said of the promotion, ``It appears to be an effort to get around the honoraria limits because I'm out there speaking to the same groups I might be speaking to for honoraria.'' ``Some people allege that they didn't know that I was speaking pursuant to a relationship with a publisher. They thought I was responding to a request to give an honorarium speech.'' Durenberger's voluntary comments about such damaging statements prompted one Senate source, insisting on anonymity, to comment, ``Whose side is he on?'' The senator's spokeswoman, Carrie Collins, now says Durenberger will no longer comment on anything the Ethics Committee is doing. Durenberger is not the only senator under investigation by the committee. Also under scrutiny are Sens. John McCain of Arizona, Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, DeConcini of Arizona and former astronaut John Glenn of Ohio for their contacts in the case of a troubled savings and loan, and Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York in connection with housing deals. But the Minnesotan's case has reached the furthest stage of any inquiry since the panel recommended the expulsion of former Sen. Harrison A. Williams Jr. in 1982. Williams, who had been convicted in the Abscam political bribery cases, resigned as his colleagues were about to vote his ouster. After Durenberger appears before the committee, the panel must decide whether to issue a statement of possible violations, similar to an indictment. Such a finding would trigger an investigation akin to a trial in which the committee would decide whether an actual rules violation occurred. If one or more violations were found, the committee could recommend disciplinary action to the full Senate. Punishment under committee rules could include recommendation of expulsion, censure or a lesser penalty. Usually, colleagues would consider expulsion only in extreme cases, such as a felony conviction. In the book deal, Durenberger in 1985-86 made at least 40 speaking appearances under a contract with his publisher, with the fees to be split between the two. ``It's now evident that the distinction between promotional appearances and honoraria speeches became unclear,'' Durenberger said. ``Books were not always available or on display at promotional speeches and some audiences have now said they were confused by the distinction.'' Beginning in July 1985, Durenberger said, he began seeing his Boston area marriage counselor, but used the trips ``to seek out opportunities to meet'' with special interest groups that paid his way. Durenberger said he now believes ``the situation occurred too frequently'' and that he let his ``personal needs weigh too heavily on the timing and location of meetings I was properly conducting as a senator.'' The senator said his lawyers and tax advisers told him he could transfer his Minneapolis condominium to a partnership, pay rent to the partnership and use the Senate's per diem travel allowance to defray the cost of the rent. ``I should have recognized that using my Senate travel allowance to pay rent to a partnership in which I had any kind of interest would be viewed as improper,'' said Durenberger, who no longer owns a share of the condominium.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Guerrilla Leaders Reunited With Exiled Colleagues
DOC.TEXT: Aging leaders of the African National Congress who spent the past quarter-century in South African prisons had an emotional reunion Monday with the exiled leadership of their guerrilla movement. Walter Sisulu and Govan Mbeki, two of the eight who returned, were embraced at Lusaka's airport by sons they had not seen since they were convicted along with Nelson Mandela at a treason and sabotage trial in 1964. Their sons, Max Sisulu and Thabo Mbeki, themselves ANC officials, were among a crowd of about 1,000 people gathered in the rain at the airport to greet the eight when they arrived aboard a chartered Zambian Airways jet. ``Im thrilled. I counted down the hours all day,'' said Max Sisulu, 44, who fled South Africa in 1963. ``This is a historic moment for me and my family.'' ``Naturally, I'm very excited,'' said his 77-year-old father, formerly the ANC's secretary-general. Lusaka is the headquarters-in-exile for the ANC, which has been outlawed in South Africa since 1960. The movement began a bombing and sabotage campaign in 1961 aimed at ending white-minority domination. The eight visitors, all in their 60s and 70s, will spend a week in Lusaka renewing old friendships and helping to coordinate the ANC's political strategy. They then plan visits to Britain and Sweden. ``Today serves as a signal that we are getting closer to our goal of abolishing apartheid and establishing a democratic, non-racial South Africa,'' said Alfred Nzo, the ANC's secretary-general. ``Our immense joy today is tempered by the absence of some our people,'' he said, referring to ANC president Oliver Tambo, who is recuperating in Sweden from a stroke, and to Mandela, who remains imprisoned in South Africa but is expected to be released within weeks. The reunion, attended by Zambian officials and foreign diplomats, was to be followed by talks on how the ANC should respond to the rapidly changing political situation in South Africa. President F.W. de Klerk is urging the ANC and other opposition groups to join in negotiating a new constitution that would extend some form of political rights to blacks. The ANC has said it will not enter negotiations with de Klerk until Mandela and other political prisoners are freed, the ANC is unbanned, troops are withdrawn from black townships, and the government halts political trials. The eight visitors to Lusaka included six men released by de Klerk in October, all of whom spent more than 25 years in prison. The others are Mbeki, 79, released in 1987 after 23 years in jail, and Harry Gwala, freed in 1988 after more than 10 years in prison. The other visitors included Andrew Mlangeni, Raymond Mahlaba, Elias Motsoaledi, Ahmed Kathrada and Wilton Mkwayi. Of those five, all but Mkwayi were co-defendants along with Mandela, Sisulu and Mbeki in the 1964 treason trial. Thabo Mbeki, 47, head of foreign affairs for the ANC, is considered a leading contender for the presidency of the movement if Tambo is replaced. The visitors all were top ranking officials of ANC when sent to prison but no longer hold formal positions. ANC spokesman Tom Sebina said the issue of positions for them won't be discussed until the ANC's national conference in June. ``Our function is only to help and participate in whatever direction the (ANC) national executive takes,'' said Walter Sisulu. The eight arrived wearing business suits and scarves of green, gold and black _ the ANC's colors. They were to meet with Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda, a longtime supporter of the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: New Chinese Representative to Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Zhou Nan, a career diplomat regarded as a conservative and a tough negotiator, has been named by China as its next official representative to Hong Kong. Zhou, currently vice foreign minister, was appointed director of the Hong Kong branch of the official Xinhua News Agency, China's de facto ambassador to the British colony, Xinhua reported Monday. He replaces Xu Jiatun, 74, a popular figure who has served in the post since 1983. A Western political analyst in Hong Kong had said that Zhou's expected appointment may signal a hardening of Beijing's attitude toward Hong Kong. Since China's use of military force to suppress pro-democracy protests in June 1989, the Beijing government has accused Britain of allowing what it says are anti-communist political activities in Hong Kong. It also has criticized moves to quicken the pace of democratic reform in Hong Kong and blasted the British government for plans to grant residence permits to 50,000 Hong Kong families as an escape valve in case China does not live up to its promise to allow Hong Kong to keep its capitalist system after it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Zhou was China's main negotiator when Hong Kong Gov. Sir David Wilson visited last week for talks that apparently made little headway in resolving differences between the two sides. Zhou, 62, has worked in the Foreign Ministry since the 1950s. He has served overseas in Pakistan, Tanzania and at the United Nations, and has worked as vice minister since 1984. He was involved in the 1984 Sino-British talks leading to the agreement on the return of Hong Kong in 1997, serving as chairman of the Chinese delegation. He also was appointed chairman of the delegation to the Sino-Portuguese talks resulting in the agreement to return Macao to Chinese rule in 1999.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Names New `Today' Executive Producer
DOC.TEXT: NBC on Monday named Tom Capra, a veteran news producer and son of film director Frank Capra, as the new executive producer of the ``Today'' show, effective Jan. 29. Capra is currently news director at NBC-owned KNBC-TV in Burbank, Calif., and formerly worked as producer for both CBS News and ABC News. He succeeds Marty Ryan, who has run ``Today'' since June 1987. The move, which industry reports have said was expected, is the latest change at NBC's once-dominant morning program, which in recent weeks has been in a tight ratings battle with ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' Last month, Jane Pauley, ``Today'' co-host for 13 years, left the show for other NBC News projects. She was succeeded by Deborah Norville, who in September succeeded John Palmer as the program's news anchor. Capra was picked for ``Today'' after the collapse of negotiations to bring David Nuell, executive producer of ``Entertainment Tonight,'' to NBC for three jobs, including one as senior executive producer of ``Today.'' Nuell since has returned to the syndicated entertainment series.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged in Death of Child Force-Fed Chocolate Cake
DOC.TEXT: A man was held in the death of a 3-year-old who apparently suffocated when she was force-fed an entire chocolate cake, police said. Frank F. Johnson, 46, of Baton Rouge was booked Sunday on a murder charge, accused of failing to help Myra Griffin when the incident occurred Dec. 21, said Officer Jeff Wesley. Myra's mother, Marjorie Griffin, 23, of Baton Rouge, was charged with first-degree murder last month. She is accused of force-feeding the child. ``This was a cake she had made for the child, and she was determined the child was going to eat the entire cake,'' Wesley said. ``When the child refused to eat the entire cake, she force-fed it to the child. Allegedly.'' An autopsy found Myra suffocated because her stomach and throat were stuffed with so much chocolate cake that it blocked her windpipe, Deputy Coroner Chuck Smith said. Under Louisiana law, the killing of a child under the age of 12 is first-degree murder, a charge for which bond is not allowed.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Officials Ask Bush to Communicate with Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Eight former high government officials asked President Bush on Monday to write to Nelson Mandela, the jailed South African black freedom leader whom American officials are not permitted to see, as a step toward nudging both sides in South Africa toward negotiations. For Bush to contact Mandela ``could well contribute to his release and return to political life,'' the ex-officials said. Their call for a U.S. role as a broker in the dispute between South Africa's black majority and its white government was issued under the auspices of the Foreign Policy Institute. Affiliated with the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced Interntional Studies, the institute seeks consensus positions that can be endorsed by former officials representing a range of political philosophies. The South African statement was signed by Harold Brown, former secretary of defense; William T. Coleman Jr., former transportation secretary; Barbara Jordan, former Democratic congresswoman from Texas; Melvin Laird, former defense secretary; Edmund Muskie, former secretary of state; Herman Nickel, the Reagan administration's ambassador to South Africa; and former Republican senators Charles McC. Mathias of Maryland and Charles Percy of Illinois. The former officials praised Bush for meeting with anti-apartheid clerics and black leaders from South Africa, but said the time had come for the United States to go further and engage the leaders of the South African government and its leading black antagonist, the African National Congress, which Mandela heads. ``By word and deed, the president must communicate to people at home and abroad that he shares the deep concern of all Americans about the racial injustice of the apartheid system and its destructive impact on the entire region and that he has an active agenda to deal with it,'' the statement said. There need not be ``an American solution to South Africa's problems,'' the ex-officials said, but the United States can help break the logjam that has blocked negotiations. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III should ``engage all the major players in a dialogue on what is needed _ and what each is prepared to do _ to get to the bargaining table and to keep talks from collapsing,'' they said. As part of a policy of using both inducements and pressures on the white government of President F. W. DeKlerk, the ex-officials said the United States should be willing to reconsider its support of a freeze that has prevented South Africa from making loans from the International Monetary Fund. They called additionally for the creation by Congress of a National Foundation for a Democratic South Africa, whose appropriated funds would be matched by private contributions. It would use the money to help Black South Africans ``realize their individual and collective potential and to build a non-racial democratic society.'' U.S. firms that have pulled out of South Africa would be able to contribute their blocked South African currency accounts to the foundation and get U.S. tax credits in exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose Tax-Free Accounts to Encourage More Saving
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is getting ready to offer a new enticement to encourage Americans to be more thrifty, hoping to boost the country's low savings rate, President Bush will ask Congress to create a new ``family savings account'' that would allow people to earn tax-free interest and dividends on money that is squirreled away for a specified number of years, administration officials said. These officials, who spoke on condition that their names not be used, said the savings accounts would be part of the president's 1991 budget, due to be released on Jan. 29, and would also be featured in Bush's State of the Union address to Congress on Jan. 31. The administration is touting the proposal as a key to bolstering the country's lagging international economic fortunes, by increasing the pool of money available for investment and thus lowering the costs American businesses must pay to expand and modernize. However, many private economists remain skeptical, saying while the proposal would be a popular tax-break for the middle class, it would do little to boost overall savings. ``Our past experience shows that these accounts don't do very much good in boosting savings,'' said David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, a private economic consulting firm. ``The people who will take advantage of them would have saved anyway.'' Officials said that the Bush proposal is still being fine-tuned, but they gave the following details of what the final plan is expected to look like. It will allow families to contribute as much as $5,000 per year and individuals to contribute as much as $2,500 annually. The accounts would be limited to families with incomes below $120,000 a year and to individuals making below $60,000 annually. Unlike Individual Retirement Accounts, taxpayers would not be able to deduct their annual contributions from their taxable income. But the interest and dividends would accumulate tax-free. At the end of the required holding period, the accumulated savings could be withdrawn and spent without any tax bite from Uncle Sam. Sources said the administration was still mulling how long a period to require. Seven years was mentioned as the most likely choice, although there was some sentiment for a longer period, possibly 10 years. The holding period, whether seven or 10 years, would be a radical departure from IRAs, which require that the investment be held until the taxpayer turns 59{. If the money is withdrawn before that time, a 10 percent penalty is imposed. The new account has been promoted within the administration by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, whose department has been studying ways to boost America's competitive standing, noting that Americans managed to save only 4.4 percent of their after-tax income in 1988, just one-fourth of the Japanese savings rate. ``This is a straightforward effort to try to change behavior,'' said Sidney Jones, assistant Treasury secretary for tax policy. ``It is a very simple concept, very understandable and very forthright.'' The administration's plan, once it is unveiled, will compete for support with a rival plan pushed by Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Bentsen's plan would expand the coverage of the current IRAs. All workers were allowed fully deductible IRAs before passage of the 1986 tax overhaul. That law made them available only to workers not covered by a company pension and to covered workers with incomes under $25,000 and couples under $40,000. Partial deductions are allowed couples with incomes under $50,000 and individuals with incomes under $35,000. Bentsen and various private economists have questioned whether the administration's family savings accounts would do much to stimulate savings since taxpayers would receive no immediate benefit from their contributions, unlike the IRA. Critics say the administration chose a back-ended approach to supplying tax benefits in order to minimize the near-term budgetary impact. ``The administration hasn't got the nerve to propose the old-fashioned IRA which would increase next year's deficit so they are proposing to increase the deficit 10 years down the road,'' said Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution.

DOC.SECOND: PM-King Holiday Rdp, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0537,1049
DOC.HEAD: Nation Marks Birthday of Martin Luther King Jr.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 11th graf, ``There were plans,'' with 5 grafs to update with Liberty Bell, other observances, student protest; and Subs the last graf to CORRECT that just four states have no holiday but not all give workers a holiday.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: Worshipers at Martin Luther King Jr.'s church were urged today on the slain civil rights leader's birthday to keep alive his memory and his philosophy of non-violence. ``This is a man who is a deep current in our memory,'' said the Rev. Cecil Williams, pastor of Glide Memorial United Methodist Church in San Francisco. ``Let us live then not only his dream, but let us live the practice of non-violence and unconditional love.'' Williams spoke at the annual ecumenical service at Ebenezer Baptist Church. Church services, parades, and other celebrations were held nationwide during the weekend before the federal holiday, which for the first time falls on the slain civil-rights leader's actual birthday. He would have been 61 today. Also planned today in Atlanta was a ``March of Celebration'' parade, being televised nationally for the first time. A former King lieutenant, the Rev. Hosea Williams, stood in front of an Atlanta housing project to criticize the day's activities for making a travesty of King's dream of equality and justice. Williams, King's field organizer in the civil rights movement, complained that people were starving in the city while thousands of dollars were being spent on the parade. ``I am really upset with all this gaiety,'' he said. This year's holiday follows a series of bombings and threats, apparently racially motivated, in the Southeast, and a flareup of racial tensions in Boston after an apparent hoax in which a white man had claimed a black mugger fatally shot his pregnant wife. It also comes at a time of gains for blacks _ the election of David Dinkins, first black mayor of New York City, and the nation's first elected black governor, L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. ``Today, the sound of libery is being heard all around the world,'' said James Farmer, founder of the Congress for Racial Equality, as he pounded three times with his fist on the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia. ``Those who have been denied liberty love it most. Dr. King loved liberty and he fought and died for it.'' The New York Stock Exchange held a moment of silence at noon. In New Hampshire, one of just four states without some form of King holiday, about 200 Merrimack Valley High School pupils walked out of morning classes today in Concord to recognize Martin Luther King Day, which the school does not observe. ``This is our own personal way of remembering him,'' said senior Mike Krumenacker, one of three pupils who organized the impromptu gathering of about a third of the school's pupils. And in another of the four states, Arizona, thousands marched in Phoenix and Tucson today to honor King. A racially mixed crowd carried black balloons along a four-mile stretch of downtown Phoenix as they headed for a rally at the state Capitol. King, the son of an Atlanta Baptist minister, led non-violent marches in the South in the 1950s and 1960s in a quest to end discrimination against blacks and other minorities. He was assassinated on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tenn. On Sunday, Coretta Scott King delivered her annual ``state of the dream'' address at Ebenezer Baptist Church. King's widow applauded pro-democracy shifts worldwide and said the civil rights movement would not be deterred by the recent wave of bombings and threats against blacks.
