A federal judge and a black Savannah lawyer were killed in two bombings. ``In the last year, we've seen hundreds of thousands of people marching through the streets of Berlin and Beijing, Budapest and Pretoria, Moscow, Warsaw and Prague, all singing `We Shall Overcome' in a host of languages,'' she said. ``We're not going to be turned around by letter bombs or threats or any kind of violence,'' she said. ``Instead, we're going forward, with unity and courage and commitment.'' Also in Atlanta, more than 500 students and teachers at Booker T. Washington High School joined civil rights leader Rosa Parks to paint a mural dedicated to King. The mural displayed, ``Let Freedom Ring.'' In Boston, where blacks have complained about aggressive police tactics in their search for the killer of a pregnant white woman in October, about 25 activists planned to demonstrate at a King memorial breakfast today to protest the presence of Mayor Raymond Flynn. Tensions have been heightened after revelations that Charles Stuart himself probably killed his wife. He committed suicide this month. ``We don't feel Mayor Flynn should have a seat of honor at this occasion,'' said Sadiki Kambon, director of a group called the Community for Human Rights. ``The mayor came on the scene that (October) night and was told by police that an African male killed a white female,'' Kambon said. ``The mandate was `Get me someone,' and the police proceeded to roust black males in Mission Hill and the entire city.'' In New York, Dinkins told about 400 people at Judson Memorial Church that ``Dr. King took us to the dawn of a new era. It is up to us to push on into the bright light of day.'' Wilder, sworn in Saturday, said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' on Sunday that a black could occupy the White House ``in our time.'' In Seattle, the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president and co-founder of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, addressed 900 people Saturday night. ``Don't let them make a pious dreamer out of him,'' Lowery said. ``He was a non-violent revolutionary. ... The spirit of Martin Luther King demands that we be activists.'' Federal offices were closed today, and most states gave the day off to their workers as well. The four without any form of King holiday are Arizona, Montana, Idaho and New Hampshire, but some other states kept workers on the job but marked the day in some other way.

DOC.HEAD: Report Mandela Favors Retaining Market Economy
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Imprisoned nationalist leader Nelson Mandela favors retaining South Africa's free market economy after years of backing plans for a state-run economy, according to news reports Monday. Several Johannesburg newspapers quoted leading black businessman Richard Maponya as saying Mandela told him he was ``definitely inclined towards a free enterprise system'' rather than nationalization or state control of industries. The two men, who are close friends, met recently at Victor Verster Prison where Mandela is being held. The reports did not say when the two met. Mandela in the past has supported an economic program calling for the nationalization of mines, banks and other key sectors of the economy as ways to advance majority rule. The reports said Mandela sees free market forces as the best way of providing for the needs of the nation's rapidly expanding population. ``The message Mandela wanted me to take away from Victor Verster was his belief that the economy is the backbone of any nation,'' Maponya was quoted as saying. ``He said he did not believe in nationalization because it was clear such a policy ran counter to the need to keep the South African economy growing to provide jobs,'' Maponya said. Mandela, the nation's most prominent black leader, is expected to be released soon as part of the government's moves to abandon apartheid and negotiate with the country's black majority. Mandela is allowed to receive visitors such as Maponya and has held contacts with government officials. The African National Congress, the main black power group to which Mandela belongs, still supports nationalization. A change in Mandela's position on the economy could lead to a serious division within the ANC. Maponya said Mandela was concerned that blacks be able to take part in the economy to counter the growing problems of mass unemployment, poor housing and poverty. ``He was concerned as to whether black people were getting themselves geared up to take up opportunities as they arose,'' Maponya was quoted as saying. ``I told him of the training of quite a number of young entrepreneurs and he said this was a very good thing.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Rock superstar Bruce Springsteen, known for such hits as ``Born in the U.S.A.,'' and his girlfriend, Patti Scialfa, are expecting a baby, a spokeswoman said Monday. Marilyn Laverty, spokeswoman for Columbia Records, the singer's record company, confirmed a report in USA Today about the pregnancy but did not say when the baby is due or whether the couple will marry. Springsteen's manager, Jon Landau, did not immediately return a call seeking comment. Springsteen, 40, and Scialfa, his former backup singer, revealed their romance publicly in 1988 after Springsteen split with his wife, actress Julianne Phillips. The couple had no children.

A growing need for instant gratification is leading to the decline of American society, consumer activist Ralph Nader says. Nader, speaking Sunday at the University of Rochester's week-long conference on pleasure, said the pursuit of pleasure has put America, which is ``wallowing in one fad after another,'' at a disadvantage with more disciplined Japan. The Japanese ``have turned adversity into an asset,'' he said. ``We have turned abundance into a liability.'' Nader said the pleasure principle also works in politics. Candidates appeal for votes by using flattery instead of a real message, he said. ``In the 1980s we had political leaders whose primary message was `Go for the gold,''' he said. ``That was Ronald Reagan. He didn't give one speech like John F. Kennedy that inspired idealism in the young.''

Jeana Yeager, co-pilot of the first non-stop flight around the world, says she's ready to sail beyond the clouds. Yeager wants to become an astronaut in NASA's shuttle program, she said at an annual Amelia Earhart luncheon here Sunday. ``Our space program needs to move forward,'' Yeager said. ``(The shuttle) is just a first step.'' On Dec. 24, 1986, she and pilot Dick Rutan landed the tiny experimental aircraft Voyager at Edwards Air Force Base after a nine-day, 26,000-mile journey around the world _ a record for non-refueled flight duration.

Country singer k.d. lang says people have made her feel that she'd sell more records if she'd only change her androgynous look. ``The country industry is traditional regarding the looks and roles of men and women,'' lang says in the February issue of Glamour. But, she adds, ``It would be detrimental for me to compromise. I sing because of the way I am. I don't want to endanger my soul and my voice because of my physical looks. It wouldn't be worth it.'' And how does the woman with the short, spiky haircut describe her look? ``I like to pretend I'm a farmer and sort of dress for chores,'' she says. ``Always ready to feed the cows, drive the tractor, fix the truck.''

Seattle Mariners second baseman Harold Reynolds picked up the tab for more than 1,000 black athletes, politicians and community leaders attending a banquet to establish positive role models for black youths. ``The biggest thing is that a lot of troubled kids don't have a man in their life that they can talk to and get encouragement from,'' said Reynolds, who grew up without a father. Sunday night's dinner was organized by Role Models Unlimited, with Reynolds covering the $25,000 tab. ``I just want to get men together who can made a difference and see what can happen,'' Reynolds said. ``I think the answer to the problem is within these people. All I'm trying to do is get their attention.''

DOC.HEAD: Off-Duty Soldier Stabbed, 30 Palestinians Detained
DOC.TEXT: An off-duty Israeli soldier was stabbed as she walked along a narrow street in Jerusalem's Old City on Monday and 30 Palestinians were detained for questioning, police said. Reports from the West Bank town of Nablus, meanwhile, said that eight masked Palestinians marched through the central market in a show of force aimed at ending a rash of kidnappings of Arabs suspected of collaborating with Israel. The Israeli soldier, identified as Pvt. Halit Avni, 18, of Tel Aviv, was stabbed six times in the back and chest, police said. She was listed in stable condition, said Ruth Mekel, spokeswoman at Hadassah Hospital in Ein Karem. Sixty Palestinians were rounded up for questioning and half were later released, said police spokesman Uzi Sandori. Witnesses said Avni was wearing an olive drab army-issue snow suit when she was attacked as she hiked alone in the Arab quarter. Attacks in Jerusalem have been rare in the 25-month Palestinian uprising. On Sept. 20, a Jewish seminary student was stabbed in the same area. In May, a Moslem fundamentalist knifed two elderly Jews to death as they sat at a bus stop in Jewish west Jerusalem. In the Nablus march, four men fired five times in the air to draw attention, Arab reports said. They then announced through a loudspeaker that ``the general security unit warns any group against the kidnapping of innocent people.'' The warning by the security unit, responsible to the PLO Fatah faction's central command in Nablus, was the latest from Fatah leaders trying to end attacks on suspected collaborators. At least 170 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs in the 25-month uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip against Israeli occupation, most on suspicion of collaboration. At least 647 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 43 Israelis have died. In December, leaflets attributed to PLO leader Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction called for an end to killings without authorization from the PLO-backed leadership of the uprising. The security unit was sent to the streets after a series of kidnappings of suspected collaborators by Palestinian ``strike forces'' set up to enforce uprising rules, Arab reporters said. They said that at least 20 people were abducted and questioned in the past four weeks in the Nablus area and that some were beaten before being freed. The last killing of a collaborator in the city was Dec. 14, they said. Also Monday, a district court in Tel Aviv sentenced a Jewish settler from Yizhar in the West Bank to 5{ years in prison for wounding two Palestinians. The court was told that Rafi Salomon, 24, disguised himself in a red checkered Arab scarf and fired on Palestinians waiting at a bus stop near Tel Aviv. The incident occurred after an emotional funeral for another settler who had been stabbed to death by three Palestinian. In the Gaza Strip, 11 Palestinians were shot and wounded in stone-throwing clashes with Israeli troops, hospital officials said. The incidents occurred a day after Gaza schools reopened after a holiday break.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Dozens Reported Killed in Azerbaijan; State of Emergency Declared
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency declared; picks up 3rd pvs, State-run television...'
DOC.TEXT: Azerbaijanis and Armenians with submachine guns battled in one region of Azerbaijan in ethnic clashes that have claimed at least 32 lives, official media said today. Soviet officials declared a state of emergency in parts of the republic. The Kremlin flew reinforcements of internal security troops to Azerbaijan to try to stop the bloodletting, the worst between the two ethnic groups since their long-simmering feud in the Caucasus boiled over nearly two years ago. The Soviet Presidium, led by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, declared a state of emergency in the Nagorno-Karabakh region and several areas near it, the scene of open armed conflict between gunmen of the feuding nationalities, Soviet TV announced tonight. The text of the decree was to be published later, but Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov earlier told a correspondent from the Norwegian broadcasting company NRK that the Kremlin was considering imposing a military administration and a curfew to stop the fighting. He said the Soviet army would be sent in if necessary to reinforce internal security troops already in the region, who have been unable to halt the bloodshed. State-run television said 300 Azerbaijanis and Armenians fought in the Shaumyanovsk region of Azerbaijan, near the disputed region of Ngorno-Karabakh. It quoted a soldier as saying Armenians fought back with hunting rifles and Kalashnikov submachine guns when a group of Azerbaijanis tried to set fire to an Armenian farm. Attacks on the homes of Armenians living in Azerbaijan continue, with more killings and six more bodies found, the TV news program ``Vremya'' said. Four of the dead were Armenians, and the others were of unidentified nationality, it said. Sevinth Abdulayeva, the chief editor of Azerbaijan's official news agency Azerinform, said in a telephone interview that Armenians hiding in the woods were firing on passing cars in Shaumyanovsk and an adjoining region. She said the Armenians were receiving guns and ammunition ferried in by unmarked helicopters. Soviet media said authorities had lost control in some parts of the southern republic, where most of the victims were Armenians attacked by mobs of Azerbaijanis in the capital of Baku. Many Armenians were reported fleeing. The official Tass news agency said some Azerbaijanis were armed with machine guns and said that in one part of the republic, Communist and government officials were taken hostage. Soviet radio said high-level troubleshooters were dispatched to Baku, where the killing began Saturday night and continued Sunday, and to Yerevan, capital of the neighboring republic of Armenia. ``Armenia is in a state of battle readiness,'' Karen Shakhbazyan, an Armenian activist, said today by telephone from Yerevan, where Soviet television said people were reported massing outside government offices demanding the return of weapons confiscated from them earlier. A Russian witness in Baku described a street awash in blood and said victims there included two women tossed from balconies and an old woman who was shot point-blank when confronted by an unruly mob. She spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of reprisal. Soviet media said the ``pogroms of Armenian homes and murders'' continued Sunday. It gave no details. Azerbaijanis and Armenians are locked in a feud over who should govern Nagorno-Karabakh, a mainly Armenian enclave of 160,000 people controlled by Azerbaijan since 1923. Most Armenians are Christians; most Azerbaijanis are Shiite Moslems. Two ferries evacuated about 660 Armenians, mostly women and children, from Baku across the Caspian Sea to Krasnovodsk in the republic of Turkmenia and about 200 others were sheltered from attacks in the capital, Soviet TV said. In Yerevan, 300,000 people rallied Sunday night to demand authorities take more resolute action to protect their brethren. Shakhbazyan said at least 100 armed police massed at Yerevan's airport today hoping to fly to villages in Azerbaijan to defend Armenians under siege. Armenian journalists working for state-run agencies said the death toll in Baku had risen to 32. Others were killed in other parts of Azerbaijan, the official Tass news agency reported without giving figures. Radio Moscow said the strife was kindled in Baku, a major petroleum-producing center, when two Azerbaijanis visited an Armenian family Saturday and demanded they leave town. The Armenians had an ax, and the Azerbaijanis were hurt in a struggle and taken to a hospital. One died and the other was in serious condition, the radio said. The news enraged a crowd of about 150,000 that gathered later in Baku's central square, and speakers called for driving the Armenians out of the capital, a port of 1.7 million people. Late Sunday, Tass reported violence in the Shaumyanovsk and Khanlar regions, saying there were ``tens of dead and wounded from both nationalities.'' In Shaumyanovsk, Armenians including the entire Communist Party and government leadership were taken hostage, Soviet television said. Two helicopters were shot at with artillery. Highways and railroads to Nagorno-Karabakh were blocked and shipments of food and fuel were not reaching the district, Soviet TV said. It said four soldiers of the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for internal security, had disappeared and a fifth was killed. Tass said security troops and combat helicopters with paratroopers were sent to Azerbaijan on Sunday. It did not say how many troops were dispatched or how many were already stationed in the republic. The Armenian-Azerbaijani dispute is the bloodiest of the many ethnic conflicts facing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who leads a country of more than 100 nationalities. The last major rioting occurred in February 1988, when Azerbaijanis attacked Armenians in the city of Sumgait, near Baku. Thirty-two people died, most of them Armenians. More than 200 have since been reported killed.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First item for release 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: ``Read My Lips! Give kids the right to vote!'' says Terry P., age 11, in a letter to President Bush. He adds parenthetically: ``Give us at least two votes each. Then millions of kids would vote and get interested in politics.'' The letter was one of hundreds written by 6- to 13-year-olds at the request of David Heller, a psychologist and author, for his forthcoming book, ``Mr. President, Why Don't You Paint Your White House Another Color!'' Some letters that didn't make the book were printed in the current Parents magazine, shortened but with original grammar, spelling and punctuation intact. Jason, 9, wrote the president: ``I hope that you can stop all the wars. They go on too long and many people die. Maybe you could try something different. You could get on TV and scream as loud as you can for everybody to stop. That would get all the other countrys attention. They'll hear it with all the satelite dishes they got as spies. Hope it works.'' Ivan, 10, not wanting the first lady overlooked, wrote: ``Dear Mrs. Bush, I figured I would write to you since you probably get no mail. I want to tell you to keep up the good work so that more people know how to read. I love to read, except for science. Also say hello to your husband, George.'' ``I want you to know that we have your picture up in our classroom. Right next to Washington,'' Bobby, 9, wrote to Bush. ``I wonder if I sent you a picture of me, maybe you could put it up in your office?'' ``I'd give less money to the real army and spend it on army toys,'' said Mike, 8. ``Do you still get advice from President Reagan, or were you glad to see him and Nancy Reagan move back to California?'' asked Paige, 12.

The homemade strawberry and blackberry wine that Fairfax County Supervisor Gerald W. Hyland gave to fellow board members for Christmas had a real kick to it. The wine was not properly aged and proved to be much more potent that Hyland ever expected. A bottle given to County Executive J. Hamilton Lambert exploded and made a mess of his wine rack. ``I smelled it, but I didn't get to taste it,'' Lambert laughed. A cork flew out of a bottle given to Verdia L. Haywood, deputy county exeuctive for human services, while it sat on his kitchen table. Hyland joked that his wine could save him a trip to the state capital to promote glass recycling. ``These bottles eliminate themselves,'' he said.

The Southwest fills up every winter with snowbirds, people fleeing the cold and snow on the northern Plains, but now North Dakota is attracting reverse snowbirds. Many are retirees seeking peace and quiet. At age 75, Robert Sampson said he looks 10 years younger than before he moved to North Dakota. Every morning, he and his wife Jean walk two miles in a half-hour inside the City Auditorium. In New York City, where they lived for 12 years, ``everybody walked like we walk in this gym. Only they were looking over their shoulder,'' Sampson said. The couple lived in the state for four years in the 1970s and their daughter married a North Dakotan. North Dakota natives Eugene and Bertha Scherr spent 32 years in Milwaukee before returning to Linton in 1988. ``Our intention always was to return to North Dakota because this is home,'' Mrs. Scherr saib. Mrs. Scherr said she misses amenities like big-city shopping. ``But I'm getting better,'' she said. ``I crochet, sew and play cards. Then, when there's not much else to do, I'll drive out in the country and see all the wide-open spaces I hadn't seen in years.''

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Takes Office After Weekend Of Festivities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from speech. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `On Sunday...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's first elected black governor was applauded today by former colleagues as he addressed the state's budget crunch by saying he would resist new taxes and deficit spending. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder went to work after a weekend of inaugural festivities, delivering his ``State of the Commonwealth'' message to the legislature in which he once served. ``As one of the men we honor today, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., once observed, `The ultimate measure of a person is not where that person stands in moments of comfort and convenience, but where he stands at times of challenge,''' he said. In his first speech to the General Assembly, Wilder said he would not support a general obligation bond issue this year to deal with a projected $900 million revenue shortfall. He also said that he would not support the repeal of a state sales tax on non-prescription drugs at this time, even though he's supported it in the past, because the state could not afford the loss of revenue. ``Although the day for this long-awaited repeal shall come, that day is not yet upon us,'' he said. He got a long and loud round of applause when he was introduced, and his speech was interrupted by applause several times, such as when he called on officials to resist tax increases and proposed drug testing and treatment for prison inmates. Earlier, in an interview, the governor said it ``certainly is ironic'' that he was starting work on the day honoring the civil rights leader. Wilder, speaking on ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' said he fought for years as a state senator for a Virginia holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader. Though the King birthday is a holiday for state employees, it is not for the legislature. On Sunday, Wilder, a guest on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' was asked if a black could be elected president ``in our time.'' ``Yes, if what you say is `our time' is the forseeable future, yes, I do think there is a possibility,'' Wilder said. At his inauguration Saturday before more than 35,000 people outside the state Capitol, Wilder said, ``Despite our economic slowdown, we are living in the best of times. And they can be even better. And they will be better.'' Wilder, the grandson of slaves, also alluded to the history he made by being elected governor in the former capital of the Confederacy. ``We mark today not the victory of party or the accomplishments of an individual, but the triumph of an idea,'' he said, ``the idea that all men are created equally.'' Wilder, a Democrat who turns 59 on Wednesday, took the oath of office from retired U.S. Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., a Richmond native who headed the city's school board during the turmoil over integrating public schools. Wilder's 15-minute inaugural address was interrupted by cheers five times, once when he proclaimed ``freedom is meaningless when a woman's right to choose is regulated outside the dictates of her own faith and conscience.'' Wilder's support of abortion rights was a prominent issue in his fiercely fought campaign against Republican J. Marshall Coleman, who opposes abortion. A recount showed that Coleman lost by 6,741 votes, or less than half a percent, in the closest race for governor in the state's history. Before the inauguration, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and former tennis star Arthur Ashe joined Wilder at a prayer service. Later, Muhammad Ali was among the crowd of about 12,500 at a sold-out Inaugural Ball at the Richmond Coliseum. Tickets ranged from $50 to $7,500 for some box seats. The high costs prompted at least one protest sign in the inauguration crowd. It read, ``Is there a ball for Church Hill?'' _ a reference to the largely poor neighborhood in Richmond where Wilder grew up. But most in the crowd said they were inspired by the historic inauguration. ``The eyes of the nation are on Virginia,'' said Mildred Swann, a social services worker in her 40s, who recalled how she evaded the Ku Klu Klan as she tried to get fellow blacks in Mississippi to register to vote in the early 1960s. ``For me to see something like this in my lifetime _ there's some hope for the world,'' she said. When Wilder was introduced, she bowed her head and cried.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Pay Strike Begins
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 workers at three Ford Motor Co. Ltd. plants began wildcat strikes Monday, and the automaker responded by indefinitely laying off 1,000 workers who hadn't walked out. Ford said more than 700 workers at its Bridgend engine plant in South Wales put down their tools during the morning to protest the company's 10.2 percent pay hike offer, bringing the plant to a standstill. The 1,500 Bridgend workforce had already voted to hold a 24-hour strike Wednesday when their unions were scheduled to resume national contract negotiations with Ford. About 600 skilled maintenance workers at two assembly plants in Halewood in northwest England also launched an indefinite strike Monday, disrupting work, Ford said. Ford said the walkout forced it to lay off 1,000 workers in the metal stamping and body plant at Halewood. ``We are extremely dismayed that Bridgend employees have taken this strike action after we were assured by the trade union side that no industrial action would be taken at least until Wednesday's talks,'' a company spokesman. The walkouts follow the union leaders' rejection last Wednesday of Ford's offer of a two-year deal with a 10.2 percent increase in the first year and an increase of 7.5 percent, or the inflation rate plus 2.5 percent, in the second year. Ford employs 32,000 workers at 22 British plants. It said the majority of its workers earn an average $374 a week.

DOC.HEAD: Redoubt Quiet; Scientists Plan New Sensors
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano fussed and fumed quietly Monday, and scientists planned to install new seismic sensors on the peak's flanks, the Alaska Volcano Observatory reported. Late Sunday, the 10,197-foot volcano 115 miles southwest of Anchorage was emitting a steam plume to about 14,500 feet, said geologist C. Dan Miller. The plume contains little or no ash, and seismic activity in and beneath the volcano remained low, he said. He said the observatory planned to put three crews on and near the mountain Monday. One was to install two seismic sensors on the volcano's flanks, the second was to survey sections of the Drift River Valley to look at past mud flows to determine flooding hazards. A terminal for Cook Inlet oil is located at the mouth of the Drift River. Redoubt has caused flooding in the Drift River several times since it started erupting in mid-December. Federal scientists have warned the state that Redoubt could cause a flood big enough to carry large blocks of ice and rock crashing into oil storage tanks, or wash out a buried oil pipeline. The third crew plans to investigate deposits left by eruptions on Jan. 2 and Jan. 8, Miller said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used AM-Obit-Oberth, a0676 of Dec. 29, 1989, or AM-Deaths, first item, a0728, also of Dec. 29, under a Nuremberg, West Germany dateline are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: In reporting the death of rocket scientist Hermann Julius Oberth on Dec. 29, The Associated Press erroneously said he was born near Nuremberg, West Germany. He was born in the town of Nagyszeben, in Transylvania, an area that is now part of Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Mother, Baby to Be Freed After Jailing by Judge Known For Odd Sentences
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age mother jailed with her baby in a shoplifting case will be freed, a court ruled Monday, reversing a sentence imposed by a judge who said he wanted to deter women from getting pregnant to avoid prison. Tracey Scott, a 19-year-old unmarried supermarket cashier, was convicted for letting friends walk out of the supermarket with goods they did not pay for. She pleaded guilty to 10 charges of theft, and was sentenced by Northern Circuit Judge James Pickles to six months in jail. She went to prison two weeks ago with her daughter, Alesha, then 10 weeks old _ a sentence that caused an uproar in Britain. Coming from Pickles, known nationwide for his quirky sentences, the punishment was not entirely a surprise, however. In June, he drew controversy for jailing a witness who was too frightened to testify against a man accused of beating her up. The day after putting Ms. Scott in prison, Pickles let off two of the supermarket thieves with a sentence of 50 hours' community service apiece. What should have been a routine shoplifting case has generated editorials, angry letters to newspapers, discussion on radio call-in shows and debate in Parliament. Lord Mackay of Clashfern, the highest legal official, signaled his concern by immediately reviewing the case file. Members of Parliament have voiced dismay, with the opposition Labor Party's Barry Sheerman demanding that Mackay review Pickles' entire record. ``By making a lottery of the law, Judge Pickles treats the public with contempt. He must not be allowed to continue,'' said the tabloid newspaper Today. The Times of London said that ``Judge Pickles' decision again needs questioning in this case.'' Pickles maintained in his verdict that while he didn't suspect Ms. Scott of getting pregnant to avoid going to prison, he was afraid other women might get that idea. ``Would it be right,'' he asked, ``to let young women know that one way of possibly or probably avoiding custody would be to deliberately become pregnant between the time they have been detected committing a crime and the time they were being sentenced?'' Lord Lane, the lord chief justice, clearly thought not. Presiding at Monday's Court of Appeals hearing, he said Pickles' reasoning had left a ``most unfortunate'' impression. The offense was not serious enough to warrant imprisonment, Lane said. A high school dropout from a broken home, Ms. Scott had been a good worker at the supermarket in Huddersfield, northern England, and acted only to win popularity, he said. Pickles, the judge said, ``seems to us to have been concerned more with the public import of what he was doing and saying, rather than the justice of it.'' Ms. Scott is in Styal Women's Prison in Cheshire, and will have a hearing in London on Tuesday, when she will be formally released. Pickles, a judge since 1976, has flouted regulations by discussing his actions in the news media frequently with a blunt, populist tone. ``I don't like the notion of aristocracy or even monarchy. I don't accept anyone is different from me because they were born in a different bed,'' he told The Sunday Times in March. Last week, he vigorously defended the sentence for Ms. Scott, telling a TV interviewer: ``A judge decides what's right, what's just and what's fair, giving full reasons on both sides. And if he's wrong, he's wrong.'' Pickles, 64, insists he is humane _ he twice delayed sentencing Ms. Scott until he was sure a place was available for her and the baby in youth custody, where the regime is less strict. He has called for relaxing prostitution and drug laws, saying they encourage crime. In January, he freed on probation a man who had molested a 6-year-old girl. Pickles said the man would have been picked on by bullies in prison and that the arrest and court appearance likely would have a chastening effect. When he imprisoned Michelle Renshaw for seven days for contempt of court over her refusal to testify against her attacker, several lawmakers demanded his resignation. Pickles believes strongly in deterrent sentencing. When he realized no reporters were covering that sentencing, he had one summoned over the court public address system.

DOC.HEAD: Permanent Security Council Members Told To Block Khmer Rouge
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, convening a meeting Monday on Cambodia, called on the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council to make sure the Khmer Rouge never returns to power. Senior officials of the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and China met for two days of talks expected to focus on an Australian plan calling for a U.N. force to take over Cambodia's administration until free elections can be held. None of the warring factions have objected to the Australian proposal, which could become the basis for direct peace negotiations, said Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas. Alatas spoke in Thailand on Monday after completing meetings with the leaders of Vietnam, the Communist government of Cambodia and the guerrilla factions. The French Foreign Ministry said Dumas told the Paris meeting that the five permanent Security Council members ``have particular responsibilities for maintaining peace, and some have important influence on the protagonists'' in Cambodia. China is the chief supplier of the Communist Khmer Rouge, the United States backs the non-Communist rebels, and the Soviet Union supports the Vietnamese-installed government of Premier Hun Sen. Dumas said the meeting ``should seek by all means a solution to allow an end to the murderous conflict tearing apart Cambodia that prevents a return to power by the Khmer Rouge,'' the statement reported. No report on the meeting's progress was expected before Tuesday evening, after the representatives of the five countries meet again with Dumas at the end of their discussions. Participating in the meeting are Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Rogachev of the Soviet Union, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon, Chinese Vice Minister Xu Dunxin, British Deputy Foreign Minister David Gillmore, and the director for Asia in France's Foreign Ministry, Claude Martin. After a visit to Beijing last week, Rogachev said the Soviet Union and China agreed the United Nations should play ``a very major role'' in a settlement, raising hopes that China would pressure the Khmer Rouge to accept such a deal. Pressure for finding a settlement to the 11-year-old conflict has been building with reports of Khmer Rouge advances in western Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge army radio claimed Monday that many thousands of people were fleeing Battambang, Cambodia's second-largest city, after guerrilla attacks on government positions. The report could not be confirmed, and Western diplomats say the Khmer Rouge often exaggerates the success of its attacks. Khmer Rouge forces also detonated plastic explosives in the capital, Phnom Penh, on June 5-6. They also said they had forced the Cambodian leadership to flee to Vietnam, a claim the government denied. A peace conference on Cambodia last summer broke down over proposals for a four-party interim government that would include Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge, which was responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths during its 3{-year rule. Vietnam chased the Khmer Rouge from power when it invaded in late 1978. Hun Sen, a former Khmer Rouge guerrilla, refused to consider Khmer Rouge participation. Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the three-party resistance coalition, insisted on including them, saying they would continue the war if kept out. Since Vietnam said it withdrew it last troops in September, pressure has been growing on the United States, Britain and France to switch at least some of their support from Sihanouk to Hun Sen as the best means of preventing the Khmer Rouge from again gaining power.

DOC.HEAD: Intellectuals Stunned By Hearty Welcome For Gringo Invader
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The hearty Panamanian welcome for the U.S. invaders surprised intellectuals and university students, who are trying to figure out whether they belong to a nation or a glorified American colony. ``Our generation does not believe in anything anymore,'' said Ivonne Bruneau, a student at the University of Panama. The intellectual and political community is also trying to figure out where the nationalist spirit went wrong. ``Nationalism was identified with support for a government'' _ the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, said Raul Leis, an independent sociologist and political scientist. ``It was like someone grabbing a clean flag with dirty hands. If you were a nationalist, you had to support Noriega; if you were democratic, it meant you opposed Noriega and were not nationalist. ``Eventually we tended to identify `democratic' with the United States, which opposed Noriega,'' Leis said. The U.S. soldiers who invaded Dec. 20 to oust Noriega were cheered and embraced by Panamanian civilians, some of whom offered them food and invited them to their homes for New Year's Eve. ``Go ahead and touch him,'' one mother told her young son, pointing to a U.S. soldier in battle gear. ``It's like your GI Joe (doll).'' ``This is a honeymoon,'' said sociologist Marco Gandasegui, director of the Center for Latin American Studies. ``But like all honeymoons, it will end.'' Ms. Bruneau said, ``The Americans did something we could not do or were not prepared to do. To my generation, it was a good change after more than 20 years of military government.'' The United States is often referred to as Panama's midwife. President Theodore Roosevelt engineered its separation from Colombia in 1903, and in return obtained concessions that resulted in construction of the Panama Canal. Until 1977, the United States had sovereign control over the Canal Zone, a 10-mile-wide strip of land along the canal that divided the country in two. Panama's national currency is the U.S. dollar. Nearly 35,000 Americans live here, and until July, more than 10,000 soldiers and their dependents lived off base in Panama City. ``There has been a process of assimilation of Panama into U.S. culture,'' said Cecilio Simmons, dean of the School of Public Administration and member of the Democratic Revolutionary Party that was created by Noriega's mentor, former dictator Omar Torrijos. ``There are sectors of the populations that would like to become a protectorate of the United States. Our oligarchy is closely tied economically to U.S. interests. Our professionals are attracted by the so-called American way of life.'' ``Then there are our own mistakes _ the corruption of the previous regime, that twisted the meaning of nationalism,'' he added. Nationalists struggled for decades to rid the country of the Canal Zone, where they were treated as foreigners in their own land. The process culminated with the signing of the Panama Canal Treaties, under which the canal becomes Panamanian on Dec. 31, 1999. Noriega represented that strain of nationalism, but corrupted it and grew weaker each day. In May elections, current President Guillermo Endara beat Noriega's candidate by a 3-1 margin. Those who oppose the invasion are almost embarrassed that Noriega's Defense Forces _ so vocal in their pledges to fight to the death _ surrendered so easily. There were no casualties among the higher officers. Leaders of many nationalist parties have gone into hiding and are not making statements about the invasion. ``They are too concerned about their dollar accounts being frozen if they say something,'' said one university professor bitterly. Nevertheless, the first public sign of discontent came Jan. 9, a holiday called Day of the Martyrs. It commemorates Panamanians who died in anti-U.S. riots in 1964. While 8,000 gathered at a Mass to celebrate the overthrow of Noriega and his surrender to U.S. authorities to face drug charges, 150 people staged a protest march to a cemetery where some of the martyrs are buried. They said they did not support Noriega, but they also did not support intervention. The appeal of economic aid to a country in a severe financial crisis was also a factor in the favorable reaction, according to some Panamanians. The fact that Endara's government was installed by a U.S. invasion has not hurt him yet, but eventually may become a liability. ``The United States will have to help considerably to maintain the support of the people and help this government that has no experience at all,'' said another university student, Luis Botello. ``If the promised help does not come through, the U.S. image will suffer.'' ``The time will come when the U.S. presence will begin to bother people,'' Ms. Bruneau said.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen Hit by Mother Teresa's Ambulance Still in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Two policemen injured when the brakes failed on an ambulance operated by Mother Teresa's hospital remained hospitalized Monday, doctors said. Two other pedestrians died after they were struck in Saturday's accident. Doctors treating the two constables said on condition of anonymity they were still under medical care but gave no other details. Police initially reported that Mother Teresa was in the ambulance when the accident occurred. But police and the 79-year-old Nobel Peace Prize winner's fellow Roman Catholic nuns said Sunday she was not in the vehicle. ``There was confusion because she reached the scene within minutes,'' an officer said on condition of anonymity. The accident occurred on a busy street a few hundred yards from the building where Mother Teresa lives. Several nuns wearing blue and white saris identical to Mother Teresa's attire were in the ambulance, adding to the confusion. The ambulance was carrying medical supplies but no patients when the accident occurred. Police said its brakes failed and it struck two pedestrians who had just stepped off the sidewalk into the street. The ambulance then veered onto the sidewalk and struck the two constables, according to the police reports. Mother Teresa accompanied the injured to a nearby hospital, where two of them late died, the police report said. Mother Teresa, who was born in Yugoslavia, won the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize for her work among Calcutta's destitute and dying. The Missionaries of Charity, the Roman Catholic order she founded in the city in 1959, has 3,000 nuns working in 87 countries. The frail nun suffered a heart attack in September and resumed work last week. Members of her order said Sunday that Mother Teresa's health was stable but that she was saddened by the deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Navigation On Monongahela River To Resume By Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: Navigation of the entire Monongahela River should resume by Wednesday evening, 16 days after 62 runaway barges wreaked havoc on the waterway, an Army Corps of Engineers spokesman said Monday. Twenty-four miles of river between the Maxwell Locks and Dam near Brownsville, and Dam No. 7 at Greensboro, has been closed for a week so engineers could lower the water level to remove 34 barges lodged at Maxwell. As of Monday, engineers were able to remove 10 barges and pieces of two others, including a barge that sank under four other empty barges and blocked Gate 2 at the Maxwell Locks, said Corps spokesman John Reed. Restoration of the water level will begin Tuesday and should be high enough for navigation by Wednesday night, he said. The 24 remaining barges, which are upstream of the Maxwell Dam, do not interfere with navigation and should be removed by mid-February, Reed said. The barges at Maxwell are from a group of 37 that broke away from a coal processing plant. They were either empty or loaded with coal. In all, 62 barges broke loose from their moorings along a 58-mile stretch of river Jan. 1 after ice jams melted and began flowing downriver. More then 30 barges sank.

DOC.HEAD: Rail Reductions Put `Canadian' on Last Ride West
DOC.TEXT: The domed Canadian, the famous scenic train on one of the world's longest rail lines, headed west Monday on its last journey as part of large reductions in passenger service nationwide. The transcontinental daily run was among 17 of 38 lines on the VIA Rail passenger system that were eliminated after last-minute court challenges failed. Chris Holloway, director of Transport 2000 Canada, a federation that lobbies for improved transportation, said the cutbacks were ``devastating.'' ``It's an emasculation of the service,'' he said. The reduction of about 50 percent in passenger train service was announced in October as part of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's effort to trim the federal budget deficit. The government will reduce annual subsidies to VIA Rail from $550 million in 1988 to $301 million by 1992. The reduced service took effect Monday and the train system laid off 2,761 of its employees, or about 38 percent of its workforce. Holloway, in an interview from Ottawa, said the government was wrong in contending that not enough Canadians ride the trains to justify continuing the subsidies at current levels. ``That's balderdash; that's simply not true,'' he said. ``No national rail passenger service operates without a deficit.'' About 450 protesters chanting ``Save the trains'' gathered Sunday at Toronto's Union Station for the departure of the Canadian, which will complete its last 2,700-mile trip Wednesday when it arrives in Vancouver, British Columbia. Hundreds more participated in demonstrations in at least 10 other towns and cities, and the last passenger train run from Sydney in Nova Scotia to Halifax was canceled because protesters padlocked themselves to the locomotive. The elimination of the Canadian line touched off an emotional debate that recalled the route's critical role in forging the Canadian confederation in the 19th century. ``I think it's wrong _ it's going to hurt national unity,'' Julia Conley, 64, told protesters at Union Station in a voice quavering with emotion. Two people were killed Sunday when the Canadian collided with a pickup truck at a crossing in a residential area near Pembroke, Ontario, about 60 miles west of Ottawa, police said. The train resumed its run a short time later. ``It's quite a way to end it all,'' said conductor Don Green, who is retiring after 34 years. ``I haven't seen something like this in 15 or 20 years.'' The Canadian has operated daily on a southern route that dated more than a century and often includes the spectacular scenery of the Canadian Rockies and prairies. The route is featured on countless posters and postcards. A parallel northern route, called the Supercontinental, was reduced from daily service to three times a week. VIA Rail will rename that train the Canadian, although the route is considered far less scenic than its counterpart. The VIA Rail cuts also affect a couple of regional routes, eight remote ones and a major chunk of service along the populous Montreal-Toronto corridor that extends to Quebec City and Windsor, Ontario.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Find 16 Bodies in Sunken Ferry, Death Toll Could Exceed 100
DOC.TEXT: Rescue crews Monday recovered a ferry that sank with at least 150 people on board and found 16 bodies in the hull, the government said. News reports said the final death toll may exceed 100. The Ajmeri, a single-deck wooden ferry, capsized Sunday after colliding with another vessel on a river near the town of Munshiganj, 20 miles southeast of Dhaka. The ferry had a licensed capacity of 60 passengers but the government-owned Bangladesh Times said the vessel carried 300 people; the independent Ittefaq newspaper put the number at 150. Ittefaq said at least 50 people riding on the ferry's roof swam to safety but that about 40 suffered injuries. Police divers called off the search for bodies at dusk Monday, but hundreds of relatives of the missing thronged the river banks. ``Have you seen my husband?'' asked Ranu Ali, a middle-aged woman, speaking to rescue workers. ``He was on the ferry.'' When told her husband, Ahmed Ali, was not among the survivors, she began sobbing. Local government officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said divers would resume the search at dawn Tuesday. But one official said river currents had probably carried most of the bodies away and that he doubted more would be found. The Ajmeri sank in 50 feet of water at the confluence of the Dhaleswari and Shitalkhya, two of the hundreds of rivers that crisscross the country. Shipping Minister Korbal Ali told Parliament the ferry was brought to the surface about 15 hours after it capsized. ``Only 16 bodies have been found so far in the hull,'' Ali said. He did not say how many people were aboard the ferry when it sank or whether the death toll was expected to rise. River ferries are an important means of transport in Bangladesh and crowding on the vessels has been compounded recently because a transport strike has halted bus services.

DOC.HEAD: Memo to Congress: To Get on TV, Run for President
DOC.TEXT: Television news pays a lot of attention to members of Congress who run for president but ignores most of the rest of them, a study says. For example, Democratic Rep. Richard Gephardt rated a few mentions on the evening news for his congressional work on the federal tax code _ including a hotly debated bill that bore his name _ but it took his bid for the presidency in 1988 to make his face and name familiar on TV. Likewise, Sens. Albert Gore Jr., Lloyd Bentsen, Paul Simon and Dan Quayle found that mention on the three networks _ CBS, NBC and ABC _ was the result of their political aspirations rather than the nuts-and-bolts doings in Congress. ``As an everyday member of Congress, they might not ever be mentioned,'' said the man behind the study, Joe S. Foote, a former congressional staffer and now chairman of the radio-television department at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale. In 1987-88, the study found that 10 percent of the members of the Senate accounted for nearly 50 percent of all network Senate coverage. Less than 3 percent of the membership in the House made up about 90 percent of the network House coverage during the same two-year period. Quayle was not far from never-mentioned status as the junior senator from Indiana in the 1985-86 session. He got just six mentions on the nightly news. But that number skyrocketed to 172 in 1987-88, the congressional session that included his election as vice president. Quayle wasn't a formal candidate until George Bush made him one, but the pattern was the same among Democratic presidential hopefuls: _Gephardt of Missouri, an unsuccessful Democratic presidential candidate in 1988, was mentioned 25 times during 99th Congress of 1985-86. During the 100th Congress, he totaled 253 mentions _ meaning use of his name in a report, a film clip or an interview. _Gore of Tennessee rose from 27 mentions in 1985-86 to 209 in 1987-88. _Simon of Illinois rated 15 mentions in 1985-86, but 200 in 1987-88. _Sen. Joseph Biden of Delaware was mentioned 35 times in 1985-86, then 104 in 1987-88. Foote based his study on the Television News Index and Abstracts at the Vanderbilt University News Archive in Nashville, Tenn., which tracked mentions on the evening news programs of the three networks. Cable News Network was not included. The senator mentioned most often on network television news was Bob Dole of Kansas, who not only ran strongly against Bush for the Republican presidential nomination but was his party's leader in the Senate. Already well known, he had 276 mentions in 1985-86, then 486 in 1987-88. Gore ranked second in the 100th Congress with 209 mentions, Simon was third with 200 and Bentsen of Texas, the 1988 Democratic vice presidential candidate, was fourth with 199. During 1985-86, Bentsen had managed just 14 mentions. In this arena, at least, Bentsen edged out Quayle, who was fifth among senators with his 172 mentions in 1987-88. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, was sixth with 155 mentions and Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., Senate majority leader at the time, was seventh with 144 mentions. At the bottom of the list with no mentions from 1987 to 1988 were Sens. Quentin Burdick, D-N.D.; Wendell Ford, D-Ky., and Harry Reid, D-Nev. Gephardt led the list of House members with 253 mentions; former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, was second with 196, and Jack Kemp, the former New York congressman who was thwarted in his bid for the GOP presidential nomination, was third with 193 mentions. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., co-chairman of the congressional Iran-Contra committees, received 89 mentions in 1987-88. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, was fifth with 59 mentions. During that period, 44 percent of the House members were never even mentioned on the nightly news programs. ``As the 1980s passed by, congressional backbenchers found it was harder and harder to break into the national spotlight as defined by ABC, CBS and NBC,'' Foote said. The result is that some of the newer and younger members of Congress have ``fewer and fewer opportunities to influence public opinion,'' Foote said. ``We rarely hear their ideas.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes To Scrap Communists' Guaranteed Monopoly
LaserPhoto XSOF1
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted unanimously Monday to abolish the Communist Party's monopoly on power, opening the way to free elections, and it reaffirmed the abolition of harsh restrictions on the ethnic Turkish minority. National Assembly deputies agreed to remove constitutional clauses, as other Soviet bloc countries have done, that for 40 years enshrined the party as ``the guiding force in society and the state.'' Foreign Minister Boyko Dimitrov told reporters if was ``a first step, but a very important, symbolic step. ... You shouldn't move forward toward democracy by banning other parties.'' Alexander Dimitrov, a deputy, said in the debate: ``We should not forget that there is no Socialist and no bourgeois democracy. There is either democracy or there isn't.'' Fledgling opposition groups, loosely allied in what they call the Union of Democratic Forces, were to begin negotiations with the Communists on Tuesday about further reforms and the elections tentatively scheduled for May. About 200 people shouting ``Down with the Communists'' demonstrated outside Parliament on Monday, supporting opposition demands for their own offices and a newspaper. Petar Beron, an opposition spokesman, insisted the demands be settled before the negotiations started. More than 50,000 people held a rally in freezing temperatures Sunday to press opposition demands for two-stage legislative elections that would give non-Communists a chance to organize. They also called for removal of a constitutional clause defining Bulgaria as ``a socialist state ... headed by the working class.'' Parliament postponed action on those demands. Andrei Lukanov said a special committee should be named to draft changes in that and about 25 other constitutional articles by the end of February. Such amendments are needed to hold free elections, but Lukanov said adoption of a new constitution should be left to the new Parliament. He is second in the leadership to Petar Mladenov, who became president and party chief after Stalinist leader Todor Zhivkov's downfall in November. Lukanov said he favored removing the reference to the leadership of the working class because no class should be privileged. He also said, however, that the party has popular support and Bulgaria should remain Communist. ``As a parliament, we can't decide such a fundamental question . .. on the basis of a one-hour debate,'' he said. ``Only the people can decide this,'' in a referendum. Under Mladenov and Lukanov, the Communists clearly hope to use their long dominance to preserve the standing lost by their comrades in Poland, Hungary East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Romania. Like other East Europeans, ``we want democracy ... without some kind of preconditions,'' Lukanov said, but added: ``We believe in socialism, despite some deformations. ... We will fight for that and think it's our historic task to do so.'' Opposition was crushed or strictly controlled by Zhivkov, who was forced out Nov. 10 after 35 years in power. In debate Monday, deputies stridently condemned the Zhivkov years and calmly voted to overturn the one-party rule that provided their own power and privilege. A deputy who did not identify himself declared: ``If the working class really had that leading role, it would never have permitted our prisons and camps to be crowded by thousands of peasants, our brothers and fathers.'' Mikhail Genovsky, an elderly member of the Bulgarian Agrarian Party, the only other political party Zhivkov permitted, said: ``The blood that has been shed, we cannot forget.'' ``Todor Zhivkov said we could have only 120,000 members,'' he said. ``We had to ask local Communist Party officials for permission for every new member.'' On the ethnic question, Parliament approved a declaration adopted by a broad forum of Communists, opposition and ethnic leaders last week supporting the decision to restore language, religious and educational rights to the 1.2 million ethnic Turks, most of whom are Moslems. Many Bulgarian nationalists opposed a decision by the leadership Dec. 29 to restore the rights abolished in 1985 after an assimilation campaign that forced ethnic Turks to take Bulgarian names. Last week's compromise endorsed the decision but also said Bulgarian is the official language in this nation of we oarian is the official language and affirmed Bulgaria's ``territorial integrity.'' Parliament gave approval in principle Monday to amnesty for about 8,500 prisoners, including two dozen ethnic Turks jailed for defending their minority rights. It would be the third amnesty since Zhivkov fell. Vasil Mrachkov, the former prosecutor-general, told the deputies 60 ethnic Turks were included in the first two.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Announce Plan to Increase Minority Access to Banking Industry
DOC.TEXT: Community leaders and banking officials unveiled a $1 billion plan Monday to increase the availabilty of loans, mortgages and construction funds to minority communities across the state. The Massachusetts Bankers Association is ``a permanent working relationship that will have a profound impact on this city and this state's ability to grow and develop,'' said Boston City Councilor Bruce Bolling. Studies by the Federal Reserve found that more mortgages were issued in white Boston neighborhoods than in black ones. The plan follows nine months of negotiation between bankers and representatives of minority neighborhoods in Boston and the state's other major cities. ``What we discovered in the process was that there was an awful lot we bankers didn't know about the reality of the inner city,'' said Richard Pollard, chairman of the MBA and BayBank Boston. ``And what the community leaders realized was that there was a lot they didn't realize about the reality of banking.'' The program will include a loan consortium to finance affordable housing developments, create a financing pool for small business and economic development in low-income minority neighborhoods, and increase bank investment in minority neighborhoods. Willie Jones, head of the Community Investment Coalition, said the banks could have glossed over bias in lending institutions by simply throwing money at the problem. He credited them with instead establishing a program that could help low-income families for the next two decades. ``We have the confidence that the banks are stepping to the mark to address the problems facing our community,'' he said. The MBA said half of its plan will be financed by banks based in Boston and that eventually 100 banks will participate. Specific commitments were to be unveiled later in the week. The statewide plan will not include a pool of money for mortgages at interest rates below going market rates. Boston bankers agreed to provide $30 million for such mortgages in the city. The plan includes: _A $100 million loan program for affordable housing development. _A $100 million mortgage program for neighborhoods targeted for revitalization. _Establishment of the Massachusetts Bankers Minority Enterprise Investment Corporation.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Issues Plea for Fiscal Conservatism, Proposes Reserve Fund
With AM-King Day Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder called for fiscal conservatism Monday in his first ``State of the Commonwealth'' speech as the nation's first black governor. Wilder delivered the speech on Martin Luther King Day to the legislature he once served, and from which he pushed for the state holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader. The state faces a $900 million deficit for 1990-92. Wilder, who was sworn in Saturday, said his cautious approach to dealing with an economic slowdown brought to mind the words of King. ``As one of the men we honor today ... once observed, `The ultimate measure of a person is not where that person stands in moments of comfort and convenience, but where he stands at times of challenge,''' Wilder told the state's General Assembly. Wilder urged the General Assembly to resist tax increases and promised to trim the state budget enough to establish a reserve fund. He said he would not seek a sales tax exemption on non-prescription drugs _ a measure he has long favored _ and would not support use of general obligation bonds for state projects this year. On social issues, Wilder said he would convene conferences on rural development and the drug problem. He called for drug testing and treatment for prison inmates and supported the death penalty for drug-related murders. Wilder's 24-minute speech, which was interrupted by applause nine times, drew generally favorable reviews from the Democratic-controlled General Assembly. ``Some of the conservatives in this state should be turning backflips over this speech,'' said House Majority Leader Thomas W. Moss Jr. of Norfolk. ``It's the best Republican speech I've ever heard spoken by a Democrat,'' said Sen. Joseph B. Benedetti, a Richmond Republican. Wilder did not give a specific figure for his proposed reserve fund and did not say where he would find the money as the General Assembly wrestles with a projected $900 million revenue shortfall in the 1990-92 budget. Wilder told reporters after the speech that he would present his proposed budget amendments by Friday. ``A biennial budget is a budget for two years _ not for one,'' Wilder told lawmakers. ``And I think the time has come for us to practice that in fact as well as in theory.'' Twice during the 1980s, Wilder said, the state ended a fiscal year with no reserve for appropriation in the second year of the biennium. He said the $25.8 billion, two-year budget proposed by former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles falls $200 million short of providing enough money for salary increases for teachers and state employees in the second year. Wilder drew applause early in his speech when he relayed his first principle of fiscal discipline: ``We should resist the urge to enact general tax increases.''

DOC.HEAD: END CONGRESS-EXPOSURE-hOUSE - 3 TAKES
Infiniti Ads Spark Oldsmobile Parody
DOC.TEXT: You've seen the commercials, the ones showing pastoral scenes of waves, fields and forest, with a man's soothing voice asking existential questions about eternity and values. Although no car is ever seen, most viewers know it's a commercial for the Japanese luxury car Infiniti _ except in New England, where not all is as it appears. A series of advertisements that ran from Christmas Eve to Jan. 2 parodying the Infiniti spots has had New Englanders talking, laughing and watching. ``Questions. What are we for? Why am I here?'' asks a voice narrating one of the parodic spots, as the camera fixes on a still forest scene. The voice continues: ``especially when Oldsmobile is having a great sale right now.'' The camera cuts to a plug from an Oldsmobile spokesman, a few shots of cars, and the theme song ``This is not your father's Oldsmobile,'' used in Olds national advertising. When the scene returns to the forest, the voice asks: ``What is a factory-to-dealer incentive anyway?'' It trails off, wondering: ``How much wood could a woodchuck chuck, if a woodchuck could chuck...'' The commercials mimic the Infiniti spots almost exactly. Even the voice, that of a professional, sounds like the copywriter who laid down the track for Infiniti. ``Somebody had to do it,'' said Ron Lawner, executive vice president, creative director at the Boston office of the New York-based Della Femina McNamee-WCRS Inc., where the commercials were made. Lawner said many people called his office commending the series, which advertised an Oldsmobile holiday sale for a regional dealers' association. ``The nature of the content was supposed to be provoking, to get them talked about, when everybody is having the same sale,'' Lawner said. To the makers of the Infiniti ad, imitation is the best form of flattery. ``I think it's a terrific parody. They did a terrific job of playing around with our ad,'' said Chuck Kushell, executive vice president, general manager at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Inc. Advertising in Los Angeles, where the Infiniti ads were made. Sidney Zussman, president of The New England Oldsmobile Dealers and owner of West Street Motors in Methuen, said his group loved the ads. ``People came in the door saying `I saw your ad and it's the funniest thing we've seen yet,' and hopefully they're in a better mood to purchase a car,'' Zussman said. The parodies, which cost ``in excess of a quarter of a million dollars,'' helped Oldsmobile sales in New England, up 25 percent during holiday markdowns, Zussman said. The Infiniti ads cost about $600,000 to produce, Kushell said. Oldsmobiles range from $17,000 to $25,000, while Infinitis range from $23,500 to $38,000.

DOC.HEAD: Monday's East Bloc Developments at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Monday's East bloc developments:
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people stormed secret police headquarters, looted and tore up offices and hurled furniture out windows in a rampage that state TV said put the country's democratic reforms ``in gravest danger.'' Communist premier Hans Modrow went to the building in East Berlin, but was meet with catcalls. Treason indictments were reported being prepared for ousted leader Erich Honecker and the head of his secret police.
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Azerbaijanis and Armenians fought with submachine guns, helicopters and armored vehicles as brutal ethnic strife that claimed at least 37 lives raged in the Soviet Caucasus. A state of emergency was declared in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, and other nearby areas.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted unanimously to abolish the Communist Party's monopoly on power, opening the way to free elections, and it reaffirmed the abolition of harsh restrictions on the ethnic Turkish minority.
DOC.HEAD: CZECHOSLOVAKIA
DOC.TEXT: Talks on Soviet military withdrawal began in Prague, and sources said Czechoslovakia wants all the estimated 75,000 Red Army troops to go home this year. Czechoslovak officials seek a commitment that at least half will leave by mid-May.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA
DOC.TEXT: The government said charges of abetting genocide, murder and undermining the national economy will be brought against former officials from the regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, his family and members of his dreaded Securitate special police.
DOC.HEAD: ELSEWHERE
DOC.TEXT: _ In Paris, 34 countries took the first steps toward creating a new development bank to help East European countries shed their Communist systems and move toward free market economies. _ In London, the Morning Star, Britain's Communist daily newspaper, published a front-page appeal to readers for $240,000 to buy new equipment, saying it is suffering a financial crisis because Moscow has halved its daily order of 12,000 issues. _ In Vienna, top military officers from 35 nations _ including Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, and his Soviet counterpart, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev _ began arriving for first-ever discussions on the defense policies that guide the superpowers and their allies. Session begins Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Launches D.C. Statehood Drive
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, declaring that statehood for the District of Columbia was a ``mainstream'' issue, launched a new effort Monday to gain the district's admittance to the union. ``D.C. statehood is a mainstream issue,'' Jackson said. ``We need to go to work ... mobilizing people all over the country. We want democracy and not tyranny.'' Jackson said the campaign, which began on the national holiday honoring slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King, ``would give substance to the dream'' that King espoused. Jackson, who moved to the district last year, was joined at the opening of the Rainbow Coalition's D.C. Statehood office by local and national politicans, local labor leaders and mayoral hopeful Sharon Pratt Dixon. The campaign will focus on persuading those who voted for Jackson in the 1988 Democratic presidential primaries to rally behind the statehood effort, the two-time presidential hopeful said. Roughly 7 million voters backed Jackson in the primaries. The civil rights leader said he has already met with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley to push the statehood issue. He said statehood supporters will write to each member of Congress and senator by Feb. 1 to determine who supports the idea. The Republican and Democratic parties will also be asked to help, and Jackson expressed confidence that he will be able to meet with President Bush to discuss the statehood issue. ``Surely, if he can send our men and women to fight and die for democracy in Panama, he will not deny democracy where he lives,'' Jackson said. ``If Mr. Bush can stand for Puerto Rican statehood, surely he can stand for D.C. statehood, too.'' In his State of the Union address last January, Bush promised to have party officials explore the possibility of making Puerto Rico a state. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown, a former Jackson aide and D.C. resident, noted that statehood for the nation's capital was a plank in the 1988 Democratic platform. ``We'll be behind it,'' said Brown. ``We will be putting our resources behind this _ mostly organizational help.'' Jackson has been rumored as a possible mayoral candidate, but has publicly said he would not oppose Mayor Marion Barry in the upcoming election. Barry indicated he may include funds for two ``shadow'' senators and a ``shadow'' representative in the budget he will send to the city council next month. Those elected to the largely ceremonial, non-voting positions would lobby for statehood in Congress. The district currently has one, non-voting delegate to the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Gordon Jackson, the Butler in ``Upstairs, Downstairs,'' Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `As Hudson ... post-World War I' to before, during and after World War I. Picks up 5th, `He was ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON4, NY24
DOC.TEXT: Scottish actor Gordon Jackson, known to television viewers around the world as the crotchety butler Hudson in the TV series ``Upstairs Downstairs,'' died after a brief illness, his agent said Monday. He was 66. Jackson died Sunday at Cromwell Hospital in London with his wife, Rona, at his side, agent Michael Anderson said. No cause of death was given. Jackson's long career in about 60 films made his face and gentle, rolling Scots accent familiar to two generations of moviegoers, but it was his lead role in ``Upstairs, Downstairs'' that brought the widest fame. As Hudson, the tall, ginger-haired actor presided over the often chaotic ``downstairs'' servants' world with a stern hand but soft heart; his old-fashioned sense of duty and propriety was a bulwark to the aristocratic Bellamy family ``upstairs'' during the times of changing values before, during and immediately after World War I. He was made an OBE, or officer of the Order of the British Empire, in 1979 for his services to the theater and films. He won a British Actor of the Year award in 1974 and an American Emmy award in 1976 for his work in the series, which was filmed from 1970 to 1975 and constantly is on reruns. In the Australian TV miniseries ``A Town Like Alice'' _ also shown to U.S. audiences on the ``Masterpiece Theater'' program _ Jackson played Mr. Strachan, the British lawyer who helped a young client make a life for herself after her release from Japanese captors in World War II. Jackson was born in Glasgow in 1923 and had begun an apprenticeship with Rolls Royce in Edinburgh, but turned to acting as a teen-ager, with no formal training. His rueful expression first typecast him as a coward and a weakling, but maturity brought him more interesting roles. His first professional acting job came in 1941. He played a Scottish soldier in the film ``The Foreman Went to France,'' the story of Britons trapped in France in 1940 by the German invasion. His film credits included ``Whisky Galore,'' the 1948 film shown in the United States as ``Tight Little Island'' about the efforts of Scottish islanders to hide a salvaged cargo of whisky from the authorities during wartime rationing. He appeared in ``Tunes of Glory'' (1960), ``Mutiny on the Bounty'' (1961), `The Great Escape'' (1962), ``The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie'' (1968), and ``The Shooting Party'' (1984). From 1977 to 1981, Jackson also played the tough undercover police chief Cowley in the British TV thriller series ``The Professionals'' and was in the 1988 TV movie ``Noble House.'' On stage, he played a host of Shakespearean characters in London's West End. Actor Tom Conti said: ``Gordon Jackson was one of the very few actors I have ever met who hated to talk about himself. ``For all the recognition he enjoyed from his early days in movies ... he remained modest and unassuming. He was a man honest and decent of the most generous spirit.'' Actress Pauline Collins, who played a housemaid in Hudson's ``downstairs'' territory, said: ``Since the day I first met him 20 years ago Gordon has been the most loving, laughing and giving friend of my life. ``He was an actor of huge generosity of spirit and always the central heart of any company he graced.'' Her husband and co-star, John Alderton, said: ``Gordon was the sweetest, gentlest man I have ever met. ... All those millions worldwide who loved his work will feel his loss no less than those who had the great good fortune to have known him.'' Jackson once said of himself: ``My trouble is that I'm underconfident and I'm too tentative. I'm not a go-getter and I never have been. ``It's only when the curtain goes up and the cameras start to roll that I don't enjoy this business.'' Besides his wife, he is survived by two sons. Funeral arrangements were not immediately announced, but a memorial service was expected.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir: Israel Must Keep Occupied Lands For Growing Jewish Population
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Monday that Israel must keep the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, the heart of the Middle East conflict, to settle Jewish emigres from the Soviet Union. His suggestion renewed the country's debate over trading land for peace and raised fears among Palestinians. Up to 300,000 Soviet Jews are expected to move to Israel over the next three years. ``For a large immigration we need the Land of Israel, a large and strong Israel,'' Shamir said. ``We will need a lot of place to absorb everybody.'' The statement, made Sunday night before a group of old-timers from Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc in Tel Aviv, was broadcast Monday on Israel radio. Likud members and other hard-liners use the term ``Land of Israel'' in references to the Jewish state and the occupied territories, which Israel captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. Hard-liners view the West Bank and the Gaza Strip as an integral part of the nation and have recently begun suggesting that territories serve as homes for Soviet immigrants. They have long argued that Israel keep the lands for biblical and security reasons. Shamir came under immediate attack from the left-leaning Labor Party, his partner in Israel's coalition government and an advocate of trading some of the occupied land for peace. ``I do believe that a great Israel is an Israel that lives in peace, not ... in conflict,'' said Finance Minister Shimon Peres, leader of Labor Party. ``A great immigration needs a great Israel, and to have a great immigration we need an Israel that has the greatness of peace.'' Now, about 70,000 Jewish settlers live amid about 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied lands. Palestinians have waged a 25-month revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied territories and have demanded an independent homeland. Palestinian analysts say part of the anxiety stems from potential competition for jobs held by about 120,000 Palestinians in Israel. ``I'm afraid that we're not only talking about jobs but about taking over our lands, resources,'' Palestinian activist Saeb Erekat said in an interview. ``The immigrants will be taking over the future of the Palestinians and not only their jobs.'' Calls for settling Soviet immigrants in the occupied territories also have raised tensions with foreign fund-raisers and the U.S. administration, which has repeatedly said that Jewish settlements in the occupied lands are an obstacle to peace. Israel expects about 50,000 Soviet Jews this year, and officials predict up to 300,000 could arrive over the next three years. They are seeking at least $350 million in donations from American Jews to help cover the costs of settling immigrants and have asked the U.S. government to guarantee $500 million in housing loans. The Jerusalem Post reported Monday that Israel may also ask for a one-time U.S. government grant of $500 million for resettlement, in addition to the annual $3 billion in U.S. military and economic aid. The White House had said it would not assist any resettlement projects in the West Bank and Gaza, and the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, an institution that helps handle new arrivals, says it will not funnel Jewish donations to the occupied lands. Last year, about 12,000 Soviet Jews immigrated to Israel, joining 250,000 Soviets who have settled in Israel since the late 1960s. Settlement activists say 380 immigrant families moved to the occupied lands in 1989 and their goal is to settle 500 more new families, mostly Soviet immigrants, this year.

DOC.HEAD: Snow In West And East, Warm In Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow was scattered across the West on Monday, and rain and snow were scattered over the Northeast, while parts of the Midwest warmed to record highs. Snow showers extended from eastern Idaho across western and central Wyoming, east-central Nevada, southwestern Colorado and northwestern New Mexico. A snow advisory was in effect into Tuesday over the Shasta-Siskiyou area of Northern California. Snowfall amounts from late Sunday into Monday morning included 5 inches at Williams, Ariz.; 4 to 5 inches at Flagstaff, Ariz.; and 2 inches at Red Mountain Pass, Colo. Rain fell across southwestern California and was scattered over west-central Washington state.
