In the Northeast, snow extended over northern and central New England, changing to rain across southern New England and New York state's Long Island. Showers over central New York state changed to snow over south-central and northeastern sections of the state. From Sunday night into Monday morning, 3 to 5 inches of snow fell in extreme northwestern New Jersey, with as much as 2{ inches across eastern Pennsylvania. Record highs Monday were 41 at Alpena, Mich.; 54 at Cedar Rapids, Iowa; 62 at Fort Dodge, Iowa; 38 at Marquette, Mich.; 55 at Mason City, Iowa; 43 at Minneapolis-St. Paul; 49 at Rochester, Minn.; and 63 at Topeka, Kan. Des Moines, Iowa, tied its record of 55; Fort Smith, Ark., tied its record of 72; Lamoni, Iowa, tied its record of 57; and Omaha, Neb., tied its record of 57. North of the warm air, snow also fell across east-central North Dakota and northwestern Minnesota. During the weekend, locally heavy rain across southern California's San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties, northwest of Los Angeles, including 5.53 inches at Gibraltar Dam, 4.37 inches at San Marcos Pass and 3.12 inches at San Luis Opispo, the National Weather Service said. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 3 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 80 at Harlingen, Texas. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 19 below zero at Houlton, Maine.

DOC.BYLINE: New Chicago Schools Superintendent Takes Office ^By LINDSEY TANNER
DOC.TEXT: A new superintendent took over the nation's third-largest school system Monday, promising to make it a national model of public education. Ted Kimbrough assumes control of a system that has a double-digit dropout rate, low standarized test scores and what some critics say are bureaucrats fighting a reform effort aimed at improving it. Much is expected of him. At a ceremony for winners of a student essay contest honoring Martin Luther King Jr., Kimbrough declined to outline an agenda, but said he is committed to working with a key element of the reform _ 540 councils made up of parents, teachers and principals that were elected in October with the power to hire and fire principals, spend money and develop school improvement plans. But he said for the councils to work they must must be resourceful and act on their own, and if they don't, ``Then I don't think (reform) will work.'' Despite the warning, he said, ``Public education here in Chicago probably will set a model for ... public education in the rest of the country.'' Kimbrough also faces low employee moral at the school board, where hundreds of positions are being eliminated in a bid to decentralize the bureaucracy. A possible $51 million deficit in the 1990-91 budget and an interim board that will be replaced in May by a new 15-member board must also be dealt with. Kimbrough, a 54-year-old a Chicago native, was named superintendent in October. He headed Compton, Calif., schools for the last seven years and also served as an administrator with the Los Angeles Unified School.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leader Says Blacks, Jews Must Work Together
DOC.TEXT: Ron Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told an audience of blacks and Jews Monday that they must ensure their relationship does not deteriorate despite honest differences. ``Differences that can anger and even enrage cannot be allowed to divide us,'' Brown told an observance at the Israeli Embassy of Martin Luther King's birthday. ``We must realize that the differences between our communities are not recognized by David Duke and the Ku Klux Klan; that race hatred and religious persecution walk hand-in-hand,'' he said. Duke is a former Klan leader serving in the Lousiana Legislature. He has ties to neo-Nazi groups and is president of the National Association for the Advancement of White People. Brown, the first black to be elected to the Democratic Party's chairmanship, was the featured speaker at the fifth commemorative observance held at the embassy. He said that just as King took his message outside his church and into the streets, ``We must leave behind this gathering of elites, and carry a message to those in our communities who are not here _ the poor and disaffected, the uneducated, the prejudiced and the angry people who search for targets and scapegoats. ``That message is this: it is not Jews that have bombed and threatened civil rights leaders, and it is not blacks who are painting swastikas on synagogues,'' Brown said. ``We do not threaten one another.'' He recalled for the audience that Jews and blacks ``stood together for justice, sat at lunch counters, rode in buses across the south, marked on Washington, picketed, organized and voted together. ``Two-thirds of the whites who went to Mississippi for freedom summer, two-thirds of those students who put their lives on the line, two-thirds were Jewish,'' said Brown. Moshe Arad, the Israel ambassador to the United States, said there was a unique bond between King's ``deep faith and ardent commitment'' and the dteachings and values of Judaism. ``Perhaps that is why so many Jews flocked to his banner, and enlisted in his cause, and supported his movement,'' Arad said. ``We in Israel, no less than the Jews of America, have long cherished Dr. King,'' the ambassador said.

DOC.HEAD: Leader: Estonian Communists Not Ready to Split from Soviet Party
With AM-Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Estonia's Communist Party said Monday that his group was not ready to split from the Soviet Communist Party, at least until a party conference in October. ``Really a lot will depend on the October party conference. We are political pragmatists in the sense that everything that is useful we shall use, that which is harmful we shall throw out,'' the party chief, Vaino Valjas, told a news conference in Helsinki. ``Splitting (from the Soviet Communist Party) is not an aim in itself,'' Valjas said. Valjas refused to comment on recent secessionist trends in Lithuania and said Lithuanian leaders should answer such questions. Later, in a speech to Finland's leading foreign policy forum, the Paasikivi Society, Valjas said his party would have to ``realize itself as a parliamentary party.'' ``If it wants to retain its influential position in society it must be actively involved in the democratic developments and in carrying out perestroika,'' Valjas said. He criticized Soviet economic leaders for ``wrong methods of leadership ... and ignoring market economy laws.'' ``The negative developments are continuing. Work is inefficient and financial difficulties are increasing. The crisis phenomena have piled up over a long time,'' he said. Valjas said Estonia would continue to seek economic independence. He welcomed foreign aid and cooperation with overseas businesses. Valjas met with President Mauno Koivisto Monday on the second day of an unofficial week-long visit at the invitation of the Paasikivi Society.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces Charges Against Ceausescu Regime Figures
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the Ceausescu regime, members of the dictator's family and officers of the security police will be charged with genocide, murder and undermining the economy, the government said Monday. Previously, it has said accusations that they committed and abetted such crimes were being investigated, but not that charges would be filed. Dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who ruled Romania for 24 years and put many members of his family in powerful positions, was overthrown Dec. 22 by a popular uprising supported by the army. He and his wife Elena, the second most powerful person in the country, were executed three days later. Chief prosecutor Gheorghe Robu said Monday investigations had been slowed, in part, because ``major problems arose in the writing of statements, since many of the ex-officials can hardly write, even though a good part of them held a doctorate in science.'' The ruling National Salvation Front, which took over after Ceausescu fell, also said Monday it would make the final choice of a date for free elections, after consulting with all opposition parties. Opposition groups have urged that elections, planned for April, be delayed so they can have more time to organize. Dragos Munteanu, a spokesman for the Front, told a news conference Monday he believed parliamentary elections should be held as soon as possible, but added that a delay was possible. Among those scheduled for trial this week is Ceausescu's playboy son Nicu, who was Communist Party boss of Sibiu, a city in Transylvania, Robu said in an interview carried by the official news agency Rompress. No dates or locations were given for any of the trials. The genocide charge refers to those Romanians killed by Ceausescu's special Securitate police during the revolution, and to victims of his regime. Undermining the economy relates to hardships caused by the decision to pay off the foreign debt of $11 billion from 1982 to last year, at the cost of severe shortages at home. Amnesty was announced Monday for crimes committed before the Ceausescu was ousted. It excluded former functionaries, murderers, rapists and terrorists, which has become the common term for Securitate members. Trials of 11 Securitate members are to begin Friday in Timisoara, where the revolution began a week before Ceausescu was overthrown, Rompress said. Over the weekend, police in Timisoara said the trials would start Monday. There was no explanation of the delay. Munteanu, the government spokesman, told reporters the fact that the Communist Party was banned Friday and made legal again Saturday showed the need for quick elections. He said the confusion was the result of inexperience, and declared: ``When I speak about learning democracy, even the government has to learn it. We don't have real statesmen and politicians. They have to learn.'' A referendum will be held Jan. 28 on whether to outlaw both the party and capital punishment, which was abolished after the Ceausescus were executed. At his news conference, Munteanu defended Dimitri Mazilu, vice president of the provisional government, against opposition demands that he be removed because of alleged former connections with the Securitate. Even if Mazilu had been a Securitate officer at the beginning of the Ceausescu regime, Munteanu said, ``conversions happen.'' ``For the last five years he has been an outstanding spokesman against Ceausescu's regime,'' he told the reporters. Visitors from the United States, West Germany and Britain met with Romanian officials Monday. Rep. Chester G. Atkins, a Democrat from Massachussetts, said he would propose hearings on restoring Most Favored Nation status to Romania. The trading advantage was granted because of Ceausescu's independent stance in the Soviet bloc, but withdrawn two years ago because of human rights violations.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Bogeys On Holiday Golf Outing
DOC.TEXT: President Bush took advantage of a holiday and mild temperatures to get in 18 holes of winter golf Monday, but the outing ended on a sour note. Bush got at least a quadruple bogey on the last hole. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Fred Zeder, head of the Overseas Private Investment Corp., joined the president on the 3{-hour tour around the Andrews AFB links. On the par 4 18th hole, Bush's fourth shot landed in a bunker short of the green. He blasted out of the sand trap, sailing the ball over the green and up a hill where reporters were clustered. ``Oh, a little downhill. A little backspin downhill,'' said the president. ``All you do on a shot like this is keep your head down and plant your feet firmly,'' said Bush, explaining his technique. He swung hard, and the ball jiggled forward about six inches. On his second swing it sailed over the pin, to the far edge of the green. ``That says it all,'' said Bush, marching off and picking up the ball without bothering to hole out. He needed to sink a 15-foot putt to escape with an 8 on the final hole. ``Don't use profanity. Do not pay off in front of the cameras,'' Bush advised Zeder as they walked off the course within range of microphones and cameras. But it was not Zeder but Bush's partner, Scowcroft, who was doing the paying off, pealing several bills out of his wallet and handing them to Zeder before they left the course. No one divulged the final tally. Bush spent most of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday weekend at Camp David, the presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland, before flying to Andrews by helicopter to play golf under sunny skies and a temperature of 57 degrees. As the sun set, his Marine One helicopter returned him to the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Placed Under Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
LaserPhotos CS1,CO2,NY30
DOC.TEXT: Debt-swamped Campeau Corp. of Canada sought refuge in bankruptcy court for its U.S. department stores Monday, keeping open famous chains such as Bloomingdale's, Lazarus and Rich's while struggling to reorganize. The filing for Chapter 11 protection in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati was the biggest ever by a retailing business, affecting 258 department stores that employ 100,000 people and are visited by millions of consumers nationwide. Officials of Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. quickly sought to reassure customers, employees and merchandise suppliers that business would go on as usual. They said all regular customer services, such as credit card sales and merchandise returns, would continue, as would payments to suppliers and employees. ``The big problem is corporate, not in the stores,'' said Anne Berg, a spokeswoman for Federated's Atlanta-based Rich's chain. ``I think the public will understand. The problem is not with Rich's; we're solvent.'' The filing reflected Campeau's problems paying the multibillion-dollar debt accumulated in acquiring Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988, two of the biggest retailing industry takeovers of the decade. Even before Monday, Campeau was planning a restructring that would enable it to pay debts, and was negotiating with creditor banks over billions of dollars in loans coming due. Under Chapter 11, the companies get a reprieve from creditor bills and can continue operations while reorganizing their finances. All business decisions regarding the companies must be approved by Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who took the case. Bankruptcy protection should benefit Campeau's stores by allowing retailers to concentrate on sales rather than the parent company's financial difficulties, John W. Burden III, chairman and chief executive of Federated and Allied, and James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of the companies, said in a statement. ``At the same time, under Chapter 11 protection, corporate management will have the necessary time to aggressively address the problems that exist at the corporate level with the burdensome capital structure that precipitated today's actions,'' the statement said. Federated and Allied also announced Monday that they had negotiated agreements in principle with bank syndicates for financing to cover cash needs, including $400 million for Federated and $300 million for Allied. Both deals are subject to approval by the syndicates and by the court. On New York City's Upper East Side, Bloomingdale's trendy flagship store took the unusual step of opening 10 minutes late so employees could hear the announcement of the filing over store intercoms. Business otherwise appeared normal, except for reporters interviewing customers outside the front door. ``We're trying to keep a lid on it,'' said Bloomingdale's spokeswoman Katie Locke. Some Campeau stores quickly put signs on merchandising floors or took out full-page ads in local newspapers to reassure customers. At Federated's Cincinnati-based Lazarus store group, which operates 43 stores in five states, employees were told by letter that they would be paid on schedule and that the company would make good on any corporate checks workers had trouble getting cashed, said Lazarus chairman Mark Cohen. Cohen said he called suppliers Monday to assure them the company intends to continue business as usual. ``Everyone I talked to has been positive and upbeat,'' he told a news conference. Numerous suppliers contacted Campeau Monday, and said they wanted to resume shipping merchandise as soon as possible to stores, Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger said in Cincinnati. She declined to identify the suppliers. Jockey International _ the hosiery, underwear and sportswear maker _ issued a statement saying it wanted to continue supplying merchandise to the Federated-Allied stores, mainly to avoid inconveniencing its own customers. The decision to file for Chapter 11 protection was made late Sunday by the boards of Campeau, which is based in Toronto, and the Cincinnati-based Federated and Allied units. Federated already was trying to sell the Bloomingdale's chain as part of a restructuring effort. Burden and Zimmerman said the company would continue entertaining bids for Bloomingdale's. Cohen said the reorganization could take months or years. Analysts have said a Chapter 11 filing could benefit Federated and Allied by reassuring suppliers they would get paid if they continued shipping merchandise. Suppliers would receive precedence over many other creditors. On Sunday, Campeau said it had won a five-day reprieve from a group of banks on a Monday deadline for deciding whether the company was in default on a $2.34 billion loan arrangement. The banks, led by Citibank, earlier had granted a two-week extension. Last Thursday, Campeau announced a restructuring under which U.S. retailing businesses will be separated from the parent company and run independently and in which company founder Robert Campeau was removed from involvment in retailing. The bankruptcy court, which was closed in observance of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, opened at Campeau's request to accept the Chapter 11 filing, then closed again, the company said. Allied owns the Jordan Marsh, The Bon Marche, Maas Brothers and Stern's department stores. Besides Bloomingdale's, Federated owns the Burdine's, Lazarus, Abraham & Straus and Rich's chains. Campeau also owns Ralphs, a Los Angeles-based southern California supermarket chain spun off from Federated. Ralphs' business operations are unaffected by the Allied and Federated Chapter 11 filings, Campeau Corp. said.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Says Hundreds of Unarmed Civilians Killed in Liberia
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of unarmed civilians have been killed by rebels and government troops in northeast Liberia, Amnesty International said Monday. The human rights organization called on the Liberian government to halt the ``extrajudicial'' executions by the soldiers and hold an inquiry into the killings. Liberian Justice Minister Jenkins Scott confirmed last week that the army killed civilians while hunting for dissidents who crossed into the Nimba region from neighboring Ivory Coast in an attempt to overthrow President Samuel K. Doe. But he said the soldiers were acting in self-defense against people in civilian clothes who attacked them. Doe, who came to power in a violent 1980 coup, said the rebels killed more than 200 unarmed civilians in the two weeks after they entered Nimba on Dec. 24 before his forces brought the situation under control. According to the Liberian authorities, about 16 Liberian officials were also killed after the rebels attacked the villages of Butuo and Karnplay near the border. Africa Watch, a Washington-based human rights group, said Liberian soldiers killed at least 200 civilians after the attempted coup. Scott gave no figures on the number of civilians killed by the army. Amnesty International gave no exact figure on the number of civilian deaths by the rebels or military, except to say hundreds had been killed. It quoted refugees and other unofficial sources as reporting that the rebels destroyed villages and killed dozens of civilians. Once government forces retaliated, it said, the army burned villages and killed large numbers of unarmed civilians unconnected with the rebels. The chief of Butuo, who fled to the Ivory Coast, claimed that armed forces sent to recapture the village burned it down and shot to death the village commissioner, David Boley, and his wife on Dec. 29, Amnesty International said. The chief, who was not identified, claimed he and the Boleys were questioned about the rebels, stripped and shot as they lay on the ground, the rights group said. The chief survived because he was left for dead. Amnesty International said as many as 20,000 refugees had fled from Nimba to the Ivory Coast and Guinea. Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny said about 8,000 to 10,000 people had entered his country this month. Following a previous coup attempt in November 1985, Amnesty International said hundreds of civilians were killed by government forces in the Nimba region. Several opposition leaders, including Robert Phillips, were detained in Monrovia. Phillips, who was subsequently acquitted of assisting the coup attempt in a treason trial, was one of several people murdered in recent weeks in Monrovia, apparently by unidentified men searching for rebels and suspected of being members of the security forces, Amnesty International said.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Organization Says Hong Kong Mistreating Boat People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with Foreign Office comment from London. Picks up 5th, `It quoted...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Vietnam-Returnees, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Monday security forces in Hong Kong have beaten Vietnamese boat people and the British colony's government forced some to return home despite their ``genuine fear of persecution.'' A report by the human rights group, which is based in London, urged the Hong Kong government to stop forcible return of Vietnamese to their Communist homeland. The Hong Kong government called the report unfounded and said it was committed to the forced repatriation policy. In London, the Foreign Office said: ``We reject these allegations. ... We will not send any genuine refugees back. Any allegations of ill treatment will be fully investigated.'' Amnesty accused the Hong Kong government of mistreating the first 51 boat people forcibly returned, who were sent back to Vietnam in December. It quoted witnesses as saying security forces dragged them from the Chi Ma Wan detention center in a raid Oct. 31, using kicks, beatings and choke holds. Hong Kong's secretary of security, Geoffrey Barnes, said ``a minimum of necessary force was used on that occasion.'' ``There is no truth whatsoever in the accusation that people at Chi Ma Wan were ill-treated or rendered unconscious,'' he said. The refugees were then taken to another detention center, the Phoenix House. Early Dec. 12, hundreds of security forces in riot gear brought them to the international airport. During that operation, reporters did not see any evidence of brutality. The report also charged the government with stopping investigations of official misconduct in the camps, citing two incidents when 200 boat people were allegedly beaten and kicked by security forces last year. In one detention center, it said, unruly boat people are routinely locked in empty subdivided cargo containers for several days. The report said many Vietnamese feared that if they spoke up about abuses, they faced ``possible retribution by the police and risked unfavorable treatment in the screening process.'' Amnesty International criticized the screening process to separate refugees with the right to find a new country from ``economic migrants,'' who will be forced back to Vietnam. ``The fundamental rights of people who face a genuine risk of persecution are being violated,'' the report said. Of the 40,000 Vietnamese awaiting screening, an estimated 85 percent face forced repatriation. They make up the bulk of boat people who arrived after June 1988, when Hong Kong stopped automatically granting refugee status. Under the screening process, boat people are given a hearing with an immigration officer. They can appeal the decision once. As of Tuesday, 7,567 Vietnamese had been refused refugee status, and 1,889 had lost appeals. So far, 997 have voluntarily returned to Vietnam. Amnesty International said that during the screening process, boat people receive no legal advice and are often interviewed by immigration officers with scant knowledge of the human rights situation in Vietnam. One case involved a young Vietnamese who was refused refugee status even though he allegedly was fleeing a five-year term of ``political imprisonment'' in Vietnam. An emergency intervention of the office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees provided the man refugee status. However, Barnes defended the screening process, saying Hong Kong has given the ``benefit of the doubt'' to many refugees. But he said the colony would proceed with forced repatriation. ``It would be wrong and cannot be humane to leave them in detention indefinitely,'' he said. Vietnam has promised not to prosecute or mistreat the boat people for fleeing their homeland. But the Amnesty International report said it fears that local officials may persecute those who return.

DOC.HEAD: 1000s Storm Secret Police Headquarters, Honecker Indictment Seen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to include citizens' committee, regular police sealing off building. Picks up 9th, `Official media'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of East Germans stormed secret police headquarters Monday, tore up offices and hurled furniture from windows in a raid state television said put democratic reforms ``in gravest danger.'' Another television report Monday night said a citizens' committee and officers of the regular police sealed off the headquarters after the protest ended. Also Monday, chief prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph said he planned treason indictments of Erich Honecker, 77, the Stalinist leader forced out three months ago, and Erich Mielke, 82, head of his secret police. State television said the situation got ``out of control'' at the headquarters of the once-dreaded secret police agency. ADN, the official news agency, said ``several people brought bricks with them.'' ``The democracy that is just now developing is in the gravest danger,'' the television said in a warning repeated throughout the evening. Hans Modrow, the Communist premier, rushed to the building in East Berlin's Lichtenberg section but was met with catcalls and whistles when he tried to address the crowd. ``You were not elected by the people!'' the crowd shouted when Modrow called for restraint and warned against violence. The Rev. Rainer Eppelmann, an opposition leader, said he regretted the violence, but called the storming an ``alarm signal'' for the government. ADN said ``tens of thousands'' of people stormed the building. Television spoke of 100,000. Official media said about 500,000 East Germans demonstrated against the Communists and secret police in at least a dozen more cities. About 150,000 people staged a noisy anti-Communist protest in the opposition hotbed of Leipzig. They also chanted ``Germany United Fatherland!'' and dozens waved West German flags. Another 150,000 rallied in Karl-Marx-Stadt, and 150,000 more took to the streets in Dresden, ADN said. Protests were also reported in Potsdam, Erfurt, Schwerin, Rostock, Halle, Cottbus, Neubrandenburg, Stralsund, Magdeburg and Frankfurt an der Oder. In Cottbus, about 50 people broke from the main group of several thousand protesters and clashed with police guarding secret police headquarters there, ADN said. The protesters threw stones and broke windows in the building before police dispersed them, the agency said. Thousands of workers staged politically motivated warning strikes in East Berlin, Gera, Jena and Zwickau. Protesters in East Berlin shouted ``We are the people! We are the people!'' as they rushed into the secret police building. Witnesses said they scattered documents and looted wine, food and clothing from storerooms and closets. The protesters filled stairways with papers, ripped out drawers from offices and broke windows. Several ripped down a picture of Honecker and trampled it. About 60 police on hand at the time did not try to stop them, according to the reports. Witnesses saw some looting, but many in the crowd also appeared calm and good-natured as they milled through the headquarters. The protesters dispersed by late evening. The agency is being dismantled, and it was not clear how many people were working at the headquarters Monday. No one was reported hurt, but the West German TV network ZDF quoted unidentified East German officials as saying protesters ``threatened workers.'' Demonstrators smashed glass doors to enter the building, witnesses said. The New Forum pro-democracy group had originally organized Monday's protests and had repeatedly called for demonstrators to avoid violence. The seventh weekly negotiating session between the Communist Party and opposition, where the government official assigned to dissolve the agency had made a report, was suspended after the attack. The indictment of Honecker and Mielke would be the most drastic action to date against leaders of the disgraced regime that ruled for 18 years. High treason carries a maximum penalty of death in ``exceptionally grave cases'' and a minimum of 10 years in prison. The two are among 30 former leaders being investigated for corruption, abuse of office and other serious offenses. Honecker is recovering from surgery for a malignant kidney tumor. Since his downfall, East Germans have demanded those guilty of abuses be punished. Modrow promised Monday to open secret police files and give the opposition a greater consultative role in the government. He appealed for an end to warning strikes. Manfred Sauer, the official assigned to dismantle the secret police, dominated Monday's meeting with the most comprehensive disclosure yet about the secret police. He said one of every 80 East Germans had worked for the agency or supplied it with information, and that 3,200 employees were assigned to tapping telephones and opening mail. Sauer said the state security apparatus cost about $2 billion to run last year _ about 1.3 percent of the national budget. Honecker expanded the secret police, he said, and by the end of the 1980s there were 85,000 agents and 109,000 steady informants in a country of 16.3 million people. Sauer told the meeting ``all directives against dissidents were stopped by the government ... on Nov. 29.'' He said 30,000 agents were fired, new jobs would be found for 22,500 and 20,000 would be dismissed ``within the shortest time possible.'' He said those remaining would be needed to dismantle the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Battles Rage in Caucasus; Kremlin Declares State of Emergency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with army, KGB to be used, Armenians converge on Azerbaijani village, Nagorno-Karabakh resembles `war zone.' CORRECTS Shaumansky to Shaumyansky. Picks up 8th, `The government ... with minor editing thereafter to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOS20,27
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Azerbaijanis and Armenians fought with submachine guns, helicopters and armored vehicles as brutal ethnic strife that claimed at least 37 lives raged in the Soviet Caucasus, official reports said Monday. Facing the most violent flareup in the ethnic conflict since he became Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet Presidium declared a state of emergency Monday night in Azerbaijan's disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region and in nearby areas of Azerbaijan and the neighboring republic of Armenia. Horrified Tass reporters wrote people were burned alive overnight as attacks against Armenians continued in Baku, Azerbaijan's capital. ``Again the blood of innoncent people was spilled,'' they said. Monday night's decree means Red Army units and KGB troops now will be used to protect residents of the strife-torn area and vital installations like railroads, the official Tass news agency said. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov told Norwegian radio earlier that army units would be sent if needed to keep the conflict from growing into civil war. The Kremlin sent high-level troubleshooters and more internal security troops to the mountain region 1,240 miles southeast of Moscow to try to end the fighting. It was the worst combat involving predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis and the mostly Christian Armenians since their long-simmering territorial feud boiled over nearly two years ago. Tass said Armenians and Azerbaijanis with submachine guns were waging ``open armed clashes' in Azerbaijan's Khanlar region, near Nagorno-Karabakh. In the nearby Shaumyansky region, 300 gunmen fought in a single battle, Soviet TV news said. A soldier told the broadcast Azerbaijanis attacked an Armenian village to set a farm on fire, but the Armenians fought back with hunting rifles and assault rifles in a 1{-hour firefight. Four Azerbaijanis were killed, he said. Tass said Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian district of Azerbaijan, ``looks like a front-line zone today. Trenches are being dug in villages ... self-defense posts being reinforced.'' It said ``terrorists'' with hand grenades and machine guns were coverging on the Azerbaijani village of Adzhikend, and that artillery guns used to break up hailstorms were brought in to shoot at helicopters. The government newspaper Izvestia said the belligerents were using helicopters without markings and armored vehicles captured from military bases. The violence, which exploded Saturday night with an anti-Armenian riot in the oil-producing center of Baku, is ``reminiscent of news from the warfront'' in World War II, Soviet TV commentator Igor Kudrin said grimly. Izvestia said at least 33 people had died the past three days in anti-Armenian rampages in Baku, a city of 1.7 million, but that the figure could rise as other ransacked apartments were inspected. Attacks on the homes of Armenians were continuing, with more killings, Soviet TV said. It said 34 people, mostly Armenians, had been injured. ``Last night in Baku was as horrible as the previous one,'' Tass special correspondents N. Demidov and V. Gondusov wrote from the city on the Caspian Sea. ``Once again, the fires of pogroms burned. Again the blood of innocent people was spilled.'' They said people, presumably Armenians, had been burned alive in front of Baku's railway station. Less than 20 yards from a police station, ``like ugly black dolls, two blackened bodies were cast on a trash heap,'' the Tass reporters said. The Azerbaijani Communist Party tried to issue condolences to relatives of riot victims, but the Kommunist printing works in Baku wouldn't print them, saying sympathy should also be expressed for Azerbaijanis whose family members died at the hands of Armenians, according to Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow. Two ferries evacuated about 660 Armenians, mostly women and children, from Baku across the Caspian to Krasnovodsk, a city in the republic of Turkmenia, Soviet TV said. They were flown to Yerevan, Armenia's capital, aboard two Tupolev-154 jetliners, said Karen Shakhbazyan, an Armenian activist in the city. About 20,000 ethnic Armenians, most of them elderly, live in Baku, although the ethnic violence the last two years has caused a return of Azerbaijanis and Armenians to their home republics. ``Armenia is in a state of battle readiness,'' Shakhbazyan reported from Yerevan. He said 200,000 people rallied Monday on Theater Square and that at least 100 armed police massed at the airport hoping to fly helicopters to Azerbaijan to defend Armenians there. Shakhbazyan said businesses in Yerevan formed ``defense committees'' of volunteers. In Leninakan, a city hit hard by the 1988 earthquake, 10 machine guns and 100 assault rifles were seized from an Interior Ministry troops detachment, he said. Tass reported Armenian fighters had taken hostages in the Azerbaijani city of Gyandzha, and Izvestia said unidentified people broke into an agricultural institute and grabbed 80 automatic weapons, two machine guns, a mortar and 27 bayonets kept for students' military training. In Shaumyanovsk, Armenians including the entire Communist Party and government leadership were taken hostage, Soviet TV said. The Kremlin dispatched Yevgeny M. Primakov, a non-voting member of the ruling Politburo and chairman of one of the two chambers of the Supreme Soviet legislature, to Baku, and Nikolai N. Slyunkov, a full Politburo member, to Yerevan. Previous attempts by Moscow, including placing Nagorno-Karabakh under its direct administration, failed. The mainly Armenian enclave of 160,000 people has been controlled by Azerbaijan since 1923, but now wants to be part of Armenia. The state of emergency declared Monday also empowers local officials to ban demonstrations and strikes, impose curfews, censor the media, confiscate weapons and disband unofficial organizations. Moscow-based correspondents were told Monday by Foreign Ministry officials they would not be permitted to travel to Azerbaijan or Armenia. Reinforcements of Interior Ministry troops and combat helicopters carrying paratroopers were dispatched to Azerbaijan Sunday, Tass said. It did not give figures. Troops arriving at the airport in Kirovabad, an Azerbaijani city with a large Armenian population, could not move out because the road were blocked by civilians and hundreds of cars and trucks, Tass said. In Baku ``supplies to the troops are being sabotaged,'' it said. When convoys of security forces tried to move closer to the Azerbaijani capital, a signal rocket was fired by Azerbaijani militants, bringing crowds onto the road who blocked it until they were pushed aside, Tass said. According to Izvestia, not a single railroad train reached Armenia through Azerbaijan Monday as the rail blockade renewed last week by Azerbaijan to press its demands for sovereignty over Nagorno-Karabakh continued. A total of 224 trains are immobilized on Azerbaijani territory and 109 more have no locomotives to move them, Izvestia said. Armenia depends heavily on rail supplies via Azerbaijan, and Shakhbazyan said fuel was running short in Yerevan because of the blockade. For the fifth straight day, Interfax said, no freight cars carrying goods or fuel entered Stepanakert, the administrative center of Nagorno-Karabakh. Since Gorbachev became Soviet leader in March 1985, his greater tolerance for dissent has encouraged many Soviet ethnic groups to make demands they long suppressed. That has often led to violent conflict in the nation of more than 100 nationalities, many of whom harbor age-old grudges. The last major rioting sparked by the Nagorno-Karabakh feud was in February 1988 when Azerbaijanis attacked Armenians in Sumgait, near Baku. Thirty-two people died, most of them Armenians. More than 200 have since been reported killed.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Talk of the Gestapo, Toast With Stolen Champagne
With AM-East German, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Protesters who tore up the secret police offices Monday used the scornful nickname Stasi for the agency they equate with the Nazi Gestapo, and some toasted each other with champagne stolen from its storerooms. ``Stasi out and into the factories!'' they chanted. ``The people are here now!'' Stasi is a shortened form of Staatssicherheit, the agency's proper name, which means ``state security'' in German. Tens of thousands of East Germans stormed the building at about 5:30 p.m. Monday, releasing pent-up anger against the force that cracked down on dissent for four decades. East German television said 100,000 took part. They ranged in age from teen-agers to people in their 50s and some who appeared older. Some spray-painted slogans on the walls. ``Stasi _ Gestapo _ KGB _ Securitate _ Bloodsuckers,'' read one that associated the East German agency with its Nazi, Soviet and Romanian equivalents. No injuries were reported and some raiders appeared in a nearly festive mood. State television said ``the offices had virtually not been functioning any more'' because the agency was being disbanded. How many employees were in the building was not known. Thousands roved through the building, throwing furniture from windows and scattering documents grabbed from filing cabinets. One group found a portrait of Erich Honecker, the 77-year-old Stalinist who ran the country for 18 years until October. They tore it off the wall and stomped on it. At least one West German flag was seen being carried through the halls. About 60 police were on the scene, but did not interfere. One smoked casually as he watched the mayhem. Honecker used the secret police to spy on citizens, crack down on dissent and intimidate opponents of the Communist government. They had wide powers and sent thousands of political prisoners to jail. Dismantling of the agency has been a major opposition demand, and the government says it is accomplishing the task. The pro-democracy group New Forum organized as protest of the secret police for Monday, but had urged demonstrators to avoid violence. Hans Modrow, the Communist premier, tried to address the protesters and finally managed to be heard despite loud whistling. When he finished his appeal, about an hour after trouble began, the raiders began to disperse.

DOC.HEAD: Holdup Attempt Goes Awry, 44 Wounded in Post Office Blast
DOC.TEXT: A holdup attempt went awry Monday when an explosive that robbers used to blast open a safe went off prematurely, injuring 44 people in a crowded post office, police said. Among the wounded were retirees lining up to receive their monthly pension payments, police said. The payments had just began when at least three people armed with rifles and pistols rushed into the post office, fired shots in the air and shouted, ``This is a robbery!'' police said. The robbers planned to use the bomb to blast open a safe where more than $500,000 had been deposited for the payments, Police Chief Luciano Cannarozzo said. But the bomb went off early, apparently injuring one of the bandits, Cannarozzo said. The blast knocked down a wall and buried most of the money. At least 44 people were hospitalized, police said. The bandits escaped in two cars, police said. Because most of the money was buried in the blast, the haul was believed to be total only a few thousand dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Offers Resignation after Predecessor's Assassination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with Velazquez confirming he offered his resignation, minor editing to conform. Picks up 9th, `Lopez Albujar...'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Gen. Julio Velasquez said Monday he has offered to resign because of the assassination of the former defense minister last week in a Lima parking lot. Governnment sources said President Alan Garcia, who met Sunday at Government House with Velasquez, refused to accept the resignation. The former minister, Enrique Lopez Albujar, was the most prominent victim in Peru's 10-year-old guerrilla war. Officials blame Tuesday's slaying on Shining Path rebels, who have brought their battle against the government from the Andean highlands where they originated to the nation's capital. The pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement also claimed responsibility for the slaying, but counterinsurgency experts continue to believe the Shining Path is responsible because of the manner in which the assassination occurred. Lopez Albujar was killed Jan. 9 when at least four leftist terrorists shot him with sub-machine guns and pistols as he arrived alone in his car at the office where he worked following his retirement last year from the armed forces. He was alone because his driver and a bodyguard arrived late to work that day. Velasquez said he presented a letter of resignation Friday to Garcia because he considered himself ``politically responsible'' because it was his ministry's duty to insure Lopez Albujar's safety. ``Official sources said that President Garcia is not willing to accept the decision of the defense minister,'' La Republica newspaper reported earlier Monday. Lopez Albujar was army commander in 1987 when Garcia named him as Peru's first defense minister, a cabinet post created to consolidate authority over the three armed forces. He retired in May and was replaced by Velasquez. Garcia last week publicly criticized the failure to provide sufficent protection to Lopez Albujar but said people who could be terrorist targets should also take precautions. More than 17,000 people have died in Peru's political violence since the Shining Path launched its guerrilla war in May 1980. The Tupac Amaru band, a much smaller group, took up arms in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares Portions of Florida Disaster Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf 6: ``The area,'' to note citrus areas not covered
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared portions of Florida a major disaster area Monday from the pre-Christmas freeze that devastated citrus and other crops. He signed the disaster declaration before leaving Camp David to spend the rest of his Martin Luther King Day holiday golfing at Andrews Air Force Base. John Herrick, a White House spokesman, said the disaster declaration covers the counties of Broward, Collier, Dade, Hendry, Lee, Monroe and Palm Beach. It makes those left jobless by the disaster eligible for unemployment compensation and other federal assistance. The freeze struck Dec. 23, with portions of Florida getting snow for the first time in years. The area concerned in Monday's declaration is most of southern Florida, mostly a vegetable-growing area. Gov. Bob Martinez, who said he was ``very pleased,'' said he would ask for similar help for citrus areas in central and northern Florida once the extent of damage there has been documented. The White House said federal aid will be coordinated by Thomas P. Credle of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's Atlanta office. Bush himself visited Orlando, Fla., Jan. 8 and promised farmers at the American Farm Bureau convention that they would not be left alone in recovering from the freeze. Bush went golfing with Secretary of State James Baker III, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Fred Zeder, president of the Overseas Private Investment Corp. and a longtime Bush friend.

DOC.HEAD: Closure of Soviet Plant May Delay Disposal of Chemical Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Raises penultimate graf to 4th graf: ``An administration,'' to bring higher the point that the offer was made.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6, WX7
DOC.TEXT: The closure of the only Soviet facility capable of destroying chemical weapons is jeopardizing plans to eliminate superpower stocks of those arms and prompting suggestions the United States provide newly developed technology to accomplish the task. ``We could do ourselves and the human race an awful lot of good if we would offer this to the Soviets,'' said Rep. Larry Hopkins, R-Ky., who made the suggestion to Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Defense Minister Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov. The State Department ``has let this thing slide'' Hopkins said in a telephone interview Friday. He is the only Westerner to have visited the Soviet facility, 550 miles southwest of Moscow, and wrote the law requiring the United States to destroy 80 percent of its chemical weapons by 1997. An administration official, speaking on condition he not be further identified, said the offer was made to the Soviets, that they made no response, and there was ``no activity'' on the issue. The facility was shut down before it even began operations after demonstrations by environmentalists and the little-publicized development has left the Soviets without the means of destroying their chemical weapons. The superpowers are trying to negotiate a bilateral chemical weapons treaty by the end of the year, and this month U.S. and Soviet officials exchanged what they call ``base-line'' data on their stockpiles and production plants. The data remains classified, said an administration source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Exchange of the information was part of a superpower deal cut last September with the aim of lending momentum to talks among 40 nations for a global convention banning production of chemical arms. The global ban faces many obstacles, however, and the superpowers still are debating whether to destroy their entire stockpiles, as proposed by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, or to leave them at about 6,000 tons apiece, as proposed by President Bush. Both proposals were made at the United Nations last September. ``We do not believe that they are able right now to destroy the amount they claim to have, which is 50,000 tons,'' Sheila Buckley, the top Pentagon chemical arms negotiator, said in a recent speech. ``We may be able to share some of that technology with the Soviets, if they are interested. It is not clear yet that they are,'' she said. In March, the U.S. Army plans to begin testing a disposal facility on Johnston Atoll in the Pacific Ocean about 800 miles southwest of Hawaii. The facility will burn the substances at 2,700 degrees Fahrenheit. If it works as planned, the Army will build similar plants to destroy the rest of the U.S. chemical arsenal, stored in eight states: Maryland, Kentucky, Alabama, Utah, Indiana, Oregon, Arkansas and Colorado. Construction started last September at the Tooele Army Depot in Utah, where 42.3 percent of the U.S. stocks are stored. U.S. chemical weapons stockpiles are estimated at 30,000 tons by private analysts, and administration sources said that number was ``in the ballpark.'' At Chapayevsk, the Soviets planned to destroy two chemicals also in the U.S. arsenal, the nerve agents Sarin and VX, by mixing them with caustic agents and then burning the residue. U.S. officials used similar methods to destroy 3,250 tons of mustard agents in 1974-75 at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, near Denver, but discarded the technology because it left large quantities of toxic waste, said Col. Walter L. Busbee, head of the U.S. chemical weapons disposal program. While the United States burns its older weapons, dating from 1969 or before, it is making a smaller quantity of newer weapons that would also be destroyed if a global convention goes into effect. Although the Soviets have closed their only disposal facility, Kremlin spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said last Sept. 18 that other plants would be built. No new construction has been announced, and it could take years. Hopkins, in a letter last September to Baker, said ``it is clear that they will now have to begin rebuilding a disposal capability from scratch.'' That could mean ``a three- to five-year setback in the Soviet effort,'' he said. ``Without outside assistance, it is very possible the USSR simply might be technically incapable of meeting the required disposal schedule under negotiation.'' A non-government expert on the issue, Elisa D. Harris, said that ``unless we help them build a facility with proper containment, it may be several years before they can start meeting their commitments under a bilateral accord.... It does seem to me that the people who helped come up with the president's proposal in September must have been aware of the problems that the two sides confront.''

DOC.HEAD: Economic Decline Must Halt Within a Year: Soviet Official
With AM-Soviet-Unrest
DOC.TEXT: A top Soviet official said Monday that economic reforms in his country must succeed within a year or ``the leadership's credit with the population will vanish.'' Leonid Abalkin, a vice premier and the Soviet's top economic reform official, told reporters here, ``If the situation on the consumer market does not stabilize before the end of the year, other pretenders will try and seize power.'' Abalkin, who began a two-day private visit to the Netherlands, did not identify those thought to be waiting in the wings to unseat the reform-minded faction in the Soviet leadership. Speaking through a Dutch interpreter, he warned that ``those who repeat the mistakes of the past years will not be able to play a vanguard role in the reform process any more.'' Referring to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet official added, ``If there are great troubles with the economy, if goods disappear from the stores, a leader will lose his influence with the population.'' Abalkin said that ``regrettably, many mistakes have been made recently,'' citing errors or delays in the field of tax reform, and management and planning system changes. A radical plan to overhaul the ruined Soviet economy into a market-oriented system _ a plan Abalkin helped co-author _ failed to be adopted by Gorbachev's government late last year. Instead, a five-year economic plan submitted to the Supreme Soviet, the nation's working parliament, relied heavily on central planning, now held to be one of the major stumbling blocks to meaningful economic reform. Abalkin said that the strongly watered-down reform program was ``the product of compromises and consensus. ... I think it's a great victory that it has been achieved in such difficult times.'' He warned however that ``this plan must not remain another paper project, there must be real changes in the economy. ``If this government thinks that that is impossible, it should no longer take responsibility in the face of the parliament and the people,'' Abalkin said.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt's Foreign Minister Leaves Unexpecdtely for US
DOC.TEXT: Egypt's foreign minister left for Washington early Wednesday seeking a way to resolve differences by Israel and the PLO that continue to block Middle East peace talks. The unexpected trip by Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid comes after two visits to Cairo in a week by Yasser Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman. Abdel-Meguid told reporters at Cairo International Airport he is carrying a message to President Bush from President Hosni Mubarak, who has been trying to start a dialogue between Arafat's organization and Israel. He did not elaborate except to say he would exchange views with U.S. officials on the situation in the Middle East. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said Monday that Abdel-Meguid and other senior officials, including Osama el-Baz, director of Mubarak's political office, ``are going to try and push forward Middle East peace efforts'' with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Israel has repeatedly declined to meet with the PLO leadership, saying it is an organization bent on destroying the Jewish homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Church, Politicos Plead With Drug Barons to End Colombian Terror
DOC.TEXT: The Catholic church and leaders of Colombia's three biggest political parties urged drug traffickers Monday to end their terrorism here and suggested they could get lenient treatment from the government. A communique signed by two cardinals and the political leaders was the first sign Colombia is being worn down in the bloody war against traffickers and may be leaning toward a negotiated settlement between the drug lords and the government of President Virgilio Barco. It came as Colombia prepared for President Bush to attend a drug war strategy meeting with Latin leaders Feb. 15 in the coastal city of Cartagena. Meanwhile in the small northwestern town of Pueblo Bello, gunmen forced 31 people into a dump truck and kidnapped them, national police said Monday. A wave of abductions, apparently by drug traffickers, has swept Colombia, but Gov. Elena Herran de Montoya of Antioquia state said police told her Sunday's mass kidnapping was the work of a leftist guerrilla group, the People's Liberation Army. Monday's plea for an end to terrorism was signed by cardinals Mario Revollo Bravo and Alfonso Lopez Trujillo, and by former President Julio Cesar Turbay, head of the governing Liberal Party; former President Misael Pastrana, head of the Conservative Party, and Diego Montana Cuellar, leader of the Marxist Patriotic Union Party. Drug traffickers would ``get less rigorous treatment than if they insist in their criminal ways,'' they said, urging traffickers to stop their violence and release people kidnapped in the last two months. Barco's office refused to comment, but it would be unlikely such a communique would be signed by the leader of his Liberal Party without his approval. His government began a crackdown on drug traffickers last Aug. 18 when they killed a leading presidential candidate, Carlos Galan. The government extradited 11 suspected traffickers to the United States and killed the second-ranking member of the Medellin cocaine cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. The traffickers responded with 262 terrorist acts that killed 209 people and injured 1,243, including bombing a Colombian airliner and secret police headquarters. The latest kidnappings brought to 85 the number of people abducted in the last 45 days, the Department of Administrative Security _ Colombia's secret police _ said in a news release Monday. Kidnap victims included a congressman, ranchers, businessmen and Diego Montoya, son of Barco's general secretary. In a broadcast interview with the national radio network Caracol, Ms. Herran de Montoya she did not say why police blamed guerrillas in the Sunday abductions or what the kidnap motive was. Pueblo Bello, 310 miles northwest of Bogota, the capital, is in the Uraba region. Both leftist rebels and right-wing death squads, apparently run by drug traffickers, have been active there. Most of the 31 kidnapped were peasants, national police headquarters in the state capital of Medellin said. While rounding up victims, the abductors burned a rice warehouse and a tavern, police headquarters in Medellin said in a communique broadcast by the national radio network Caracol. Millions of dollars worth of bananas are shipped from the Uraba region to the United States each year. The region has been torn by violence as labor unions try to organize banana plantation workers. Right-wing death squads killed two union organizers in the region last year. Such death squads throughout Colombia killed more than 1,000 people in the last four years. A government investigation last year found that more than 100 death squads exist in Colombia, most run by drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Plenty of Sales at Bloomingdale's, But No `For Sale' Sign
With AM-Campeau, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY30
DOC.TEXT: Bloomingdale's opened 10 minutes late Monday, the first sign that the trend-setting store on Manhattan's Upper East Side was part of a gigantic proceeding in bankruptcy court. ``It's the first time in our history we've opened late and the first time in our history something like this has happened,'' said Ann Stock, a spokeswoman for the 104-year-old flagship store on Manhattan's Upper East Side. The delay occurred because at 10 a.m., when the store normally opens, employees were still listening over intercoms to the announcement that Bloomingdale's parent, Campeau Corp., was filing for bankruptcy protection. Outside, the first shoppers waited in a light rain for the doors to open, and soon it was business as usual. Shelves were full, escalators crowded and aggressive sales people enticed buyers upstairs to buy furs and purses while others lurked at corners to spray customers with new perfumes. Only at the third-floor public relations office and outside the front door where reporters interviewed customers did anything seem amiss. ``We're trying to keep a lid on it,'' said spokeswoman Katie Locke. Bloomingdale's had already been for sale, and corporate officials said bids for the chain would still be accepted. In the store, though, the only sale signs were those typically put up after the holidays. There was the ``White Sale,'' the ``Half-year Sale,'' the ``One-half Yearly International Rug Sale'' and hundreds of small signs telling customers to take 20 percent to 40 percent off ticketed prices. Customers, in fact, were told they could buy rugs or furniture worth $300 or more without beginning payments until May. ``Obviously this will allow us to go forward with business and that's what's really in everybody's heart,'' said a harried Ms. Locke. Campeau, owner of several major store chains, asked a U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati on Monday for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in the biggest such filing ever for a retail business. ``Chapter 11 signifies a new beginning and is certainly the best alternative for us at Bloomingdale's. It provides us with a fresh start and enables us to go forward,'' Bloomingdale's chairman Marvin S. Traub and president Jeffrey Sherman said in the announcement read over store intercoms. Traub and Sherman said Campeau's decision ended months of uncertainty, allowed stores to operate normally, provided a framework for creditors to be paid and, most importantly, allowed merchandise shipments to continue ``in a healthy atmosphere.'' Campeau said its Chapter 11 filing would free retailers to concentrate on sales rather than their financial problems. About 14,000 people work at the Bloomingdale's flagship store, six other stores in New York and New Jersey, two in Boston, two in Philadelphia, two in Washington and one each in Miami, Dallas, Chicago and Boca Raton, Fla. Outside the Manhattan store, Lysia O'Keefe of Sydney, Australia, said she was a little surprised to hear of Bloomingdale's troubles. ``Everyone seems to know Bloomingdale's,'' she said. ``Everyone who comes to New York comes to Bloomingdale's.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Son of Jane Fonda, Tom Hayden Arrested in Parking Lot Vandalism
DOC.TEXT: The teen-age son of actress Jane Fonda and her estranged husband, Assemblyman Tom Hayden, was arrested Monday on charges of painting graffiti in a parking lot, authorities said. Troy Hayden, 16, was picked up by his father at the West Los Angeles police station after the youth was booked for investigation of vandalism and breaking a 10 p.m. curfew, said Sgt. Rick Walker. The younger Hayden and a group of boys were arrested about 1:30 a.m. next to the San Diego Freeway, Walker said. ``He and seven other young gentlemen were applying graffiti to phone booths and posts at a park-and-ride,'' Walker said. Detective Ed Purcell said that after an investigation the matter would be handed over to the probation department, where it would be decided whether a trial is warranted for the juvenile violations. ``They look at all the factors, depends on background and previous history,'' Purcell said. ``My guess is that it won't go to trial.'' Tom Hayden, a Democrat from West Los Angeles, and Miss Fonda declined to comment. The two filed separate divorce petitions in December, and agreed to share custody of their son. The divorce is not yet final. Miss Fonda's daughter, Vanessa Vadim, was arrested last year in New York for investigation of obstructing governmental administration, loitering for the purpose of purchasing drugs and disorderly conduct. Miss Vadim's father is film maker Roger Vadim.

DOC.HEAD: American Tourist Throws Self into Jet Engine in Apparent Suicide
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ An American tourist was killed after throwing himself into the engine of a taxiing jetliner at Piarco International Airport, police said. Airports Authority chairman Winston Suite said the bizarre death Sunday night was an apparent suicide. Police said Daniel John O'Brien, 31, of Roselle, Ill., near Chicago, scaled an airport wall in the nude, attacked four security guards and stole their four-wheel-drive vehicle. He drove the jeep onto the tarmac to a British Airways 747 that was readying for takeoff, smashing the vehicle's top. Guards said O'Brien scrambled out the wreckage, smeared grease on his bleeding shoulder, then ran back to the jetliner and threw himself into the engine. O'Brien had been vacationing with a friend on Tobago, Trinidad's sister island in the Caribbean, and was to fly home Monday. Other details were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Plant Outside Mexico City Shut Down by Union Dispute
With AM-Britain-Ford
DOC.TEXT: Dissident Ford Motor Co. workers and the country's top labor leader met Monday but failed to resolve a dispute that has left one worker dead and paralyzed Ford's Cuautitlan plant for a week. ``There is no agreement but we continue negotiating,'' Fidel Velazquez, the 89-year-old secretary general of the Mexican Labor Federation, said after the meeting. Workers are demanding union democracy and the ouster of Hector Uriarte, secretary-general of the company union at Ford's three Mexico plants and a parts warehouse. Cuautitlan workers, who wanted to get rid of Uriarte when he came up for re-election last June, say they were barred from the voting. ``We want a representative union,'' said Salvador Fuentes Reyes, one of the dissident leaders who met with Velazquez. About 200 waited outside federation headquarters during the meeting, carrying banners. One read ``Brother, your union will not be in vain.'' Ford, meanwhile, has the government's Federal Mediation Board to ``reanalyze labor relations,'' spokesman Carlos Bandala said. Velazquez described it as a request to fire the workers. He said he does not know how much the loss of production of 450 cars and trucks a day is costing the company. The Cuautitlan plant, 15 miles north of Mexico City, is Ford's largest employer in Mexico with 3,800 workers, and manufactures about 100,000 cars and trucks a year for the domestic market. However, Ford says the Hermosillo plant, which employs 2,400 and is currently retooling for new models, can make 180,000 vehicles a year for export. On Jan. 8, workers say, thugs who arrived in Mexican Labor Federation buses, wearing company uniforms and identification badges, began shooting and beating employees who arrived at 6 a.m. for the morning shift. One was killed and nine others were injured by gunfire or blows. Carlos Bandala, a spokesman for Ford, said the company had filed a complaint ``to clarify this situation and fix responsibilities.'' The company has said it will not issue paychecks or reopen the plant until there is security for workers. Bandala said there also must be an agreement between the workers and the federation.

DOC.HEAD: Sixteen Hurt when Commuter Plane Crashes in Northeastern Nevada Snowstorm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `McBride said...,' to restore dropped first reference to helicopter pilot.
DOC.TEXT: A SkyWest commuter plane clipped a mountaintop while trying to land during a snowstorm Monday and plunged down a steep hillside, injuring all 16 people on board, officials said. Most of the passengers, however, walked away from the crash. Four were admitted to Elko General Hospital and 12 others were treated and released, according to a nursing supervisor. All four of those hospitalized were in fair condition, but she refused to discuss their conditions or give any names. She said the worst injury was to the captain, who was admitted with a broken leg and possible chest injuries. Federal Aviation Administration officials said the plane, Flight 5855, was on a hop from Salt Lake City to Elko when it went down at about 9:30 a.m. west of the airport in this northeastern Nevada town of 8,800. The wreckage was spotted by a helicopter pilot who returned to Elko to fly medical personnel to the scene and to airlift the most seriously injured to the hospital. Rescuer Pete Schory of Salt Lake City said passengers were wandering around when he landed at the crash site. No one aboard had been thrown from the plane and the fuselage of the aircraft was intact on the northeast face of the mountain, Schory said. Metal debris littered the crash scene and the tail section of the plane had torn free about 50 yards uphill from where the fuselage came to rest. ``Right now, I'm feeling that the outcome is wonderful,'' said SkyWest President Jerry Atkin. ``The thing you hope for in these situations is for all survivors. It's certainly unpleasant to have such a thing happen, but I'm very pleased with the outcome.'' There was no immediate clue as to the cause of the crash, Atkin said from St. George, Utah, where the airline is based. He said the airplane involved was less than a year old. The Metro III twin-engine turboprop commuter plane, carrying 14 passengers and two crew members, crashed when the pilot was attempting an instrument landing during a snowstorm. Ted McBride, the rescue helicopter pilot, said the plane apparently just clipped the top of a 6,463-foot summit about four miles from the airport, 1,328 feet below. He said if the plane had been just a few feet higher, it would have cleared the mountain. The plane then became airborne briefly before skidding about a quarter of a mile down the steep slope. Nicole Blohm of Elko, a passenger aboard the plane, said it was snowing heavily and she saw just a few glimpses of ground below her before the crash. Monday was the third anniversary of another SkyWest crash. A SkyWest commuter plane on final approach to the Salt Lake City airport collided with a smaller aircraft on Jan. 15, 1987, killing all 10 people in both planes and showering debris on a residential area. SkyWest serves 44 cities in eight Western states: Nevada, Wyoming, Montana, Idaho, Colorado, Utah, Arizona and California, Atkin said. It has 500 flights a day and serves more than a million passengers a year. The Metro III commuter plane is made by Fairchild Aircraft Corp. in San Antonio, Texas, and seats up to 19 passengers. The model has been in service since June 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: Opposition Election Campaign Sets Stage for U.S. Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to CORRECT Richardson being in Nicaragua sted Panama. Picks up 4th, `Richardson acknowledged...
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega accused Nicaragua's opposition Monday of plotting to set the stage for a U.S. invasion ``like Panama'' by quitting the race and making the Feb. 25 elections look fraudulent. The National Opposition Union, or UNO, denied the charge and U.N. election observer Elliot Richardson said he was assured the coalition was in the race to stay. In a voice hoarse from campaign appearances, Ortega said of UNO, ``They're not playing fair, because they're working so as to create in Nicaragua a situation similar to that of Panama ... and drag the United States into it.'' Ortega said he told Richardson, a former U.S. attorney general who was in Nicaragua to represent U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, that he feared such a ploy could set the groundwork for U.S. troop intervention, comparing it to what happened last month in Panama. Richardson acknowledged Ortega's concerns but said UNO officials assured him the coalition was not pulling out. He also said ``significant improvement'' had been made in the election process, but more had to be done to insure a free and fair election. Richardson told a news conference after a three-hour meeting with Ortega that campaign violence has declined and the opposition had more access to government-controlled media. But he said the U.N. mission will continue to monitor complaints about rural opposition candidates being intimidated. He also expressed concern about reports of attacks by the U.S.-backed Contra rebels in the countryside. Opposition spokesman Danilo Lacayo denied UNO was withdrawing from the race. He called Ortega's denunciation another tactic by the leftist Sandinista government to create the impression the opposition is weak, ``taking advantage of the fact that the candidates are out of the country.'' The campaign of the 14-party opposition coalition has been stalled by personality clashes, defections and complaints over lack of money. UNO broke with its campaign routine and did not hold any weekend allies for next month's national elections, in which Ortega is seeking re-election against UNO candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of La Prensa, Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper. ``The main concern that I expressed has to do with the attitude of the U.S. government, with the Contra activity and also the risk being run should UNO withdraw from the electoral process,'' Ortega told reporters after meeting Richardson. ``The UNO people have expectations to create a situation like Panama.'' Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega annulled Panama's May 7 elections when returns showed President Guillermo Endara, then the opposition candidate, was winning by a landslide. That was one of the incidents that eventually led the United States to invade Panama Dec. 20 and oust Noriega, now jailed in Miami awaiting trial on drug-trafficking charges. Since then, the Sandinistas repeatedly said the United States plans to invade Nicaragua next. Bush administration officials just as insistently denied this. Mrs. Chamorro fractured a knee in a fall at her home on New Year's Eve and has not campaigned since. She went to Houston for medical treatment, then to New York and Washington on Monday, where she was joined by her son-in-law and campaign manager Antonio Lacayo. She was expected back in Nicaragua Tuesday. UNO vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy was out on a five-day trip to California and returned to Nicaragua Friday. Opposition sources said privately there has been been bickering between Godoy and Antonio Lacayo; among Godoy and UNO's political council of representatives from the 14 parties; between the council and Alfredo Cesar, an adviser to Mrs. Chamorro; and between Cesar and Godoy. Last week, UNO accused the government of blocking about $2 million in campaign aid the U.S. Congress approved in October, but over the weekend La Prensa reported a government minister agreed to release the money. Last week, a dozen minor UNO candidates pulled out of the race, citing reasons that ranged from feeling neglected by national leadership to complaints they had not been paid campaign expenses. The Sandinistas came to power in July 1979, after overthrowing Anastasio Somoza, a right-wing dictator backed by the United States. The United States later began supporting the Contras fighting the government. Ortega advanced the election date from November and promised a free vote after he and four other Central American presidents signed a regional peace accord Aug. 7, pledging to disband the Contras, based in southern Honduras.

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Protest in Mongolian Capital
DOC.TEXT: Up to 5,000 people demonstrated for reform in the third street rally in the wintry Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator the past month, a foreign source said Tuesday. The source said the demonstrators, led by the newly formed Mongolian Democratic Union (MDU), attacked former ruler Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal and criticized the Mongolia's Communist Party Politburo, or the Mongolia People's Revolutionary Party. The demonstrators were peaceful and ``good-humored'' and police made no attempt to interfere, the source said. The temperature was about 4 degrees below zero during the gathering Sunday on the steps of a movie theater in central Ulan Bator. The MDU, a group thought to be made up of reform-minded intellectuals and artists, also led open-air rallies on two Sundays in December. The December demonstrations drew far fewer people, with crowds estimated at several hundred to 1,000. The group reportedly has adopted a draft charter and petitioned the nation's parliament for official status. The source said demonstrators at the most recent protest carried banners calling for Tsedenbal to be put on trial and urging a faster pace of perestroika, or reforms like those championed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Tsedenbal, purged in 1984 after more than three decades in power, has been criticized by the current government for his forced collectivization policies and his ``bureaucratic centralism.'' Mongolia, a nation of 2 million people spread across the vast deserts and grasslands of eastern Asia, has cautiously followed the reform policies taken by its protector state, the Soviet Union. The government has acknowledged the pace of reform has been too slow, and members of parliament have called for fundamental changes in price and wage systems in the state-controlled economy. The source said it was not clear whether political upheaval in East Europe was influencing events in distant Mongolia and it was probably ``wrong to rush toward expectations'' of dramatic changes in the country. Other sources agreed that while the momentum for reform was picking up, advocates of change appeared willing to work within the system and not directly confront the ruling party. There was no word on the protest by the government.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Man Kills Girlfriend, Baby, Other Woman, Self
DOC.TEXT: An man killed his girlfriend, their baby daughter and the girlfriend's sister before taking his own life Monday, police said. Donald Lee Whigham, 28, of Smyrna ``left home with the intent of taking the lives of the mother and their child, and then his own,'' said Stanley Hook, police chief of this northwest Atlanta suburb. ``There was an argument between the baby's mother and the subject,'' Hook said. ``The other sister went back in there to remove the baby, and she couldn't get out.'' Whigham's girlfriend was identified as Tara Gossett, 18; their child was Destiny Amber Gossett, 4 months old, Hook said. Also killed was Ms. Gossett's sister, Tracy Gossett, 20. Smyrna police answered a trouble call about 11:30 a.m. at an apartment complex where Tara Gossett and her baby lived with Tracy Gossett, her boyfriend, their child and another man, Hook said. Police found the Gossett sisters and Tara's daughter shot to death in one bedroom. Whigham was in the front seat of his car outside, dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, Hook said. Tracy Gossett's baby, her boyfriend and the other man who shared the apartment also were home at the time of the shootings, Hook said. One of the other men was shot at by the gunman but was not hurt, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Office Minister Visits Romania
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave flew to Bucharest on Monday for talks with the new Romanian leadership, the Foreign Office said. Waldegrave, the Foreign Office minister in charge of Eastern Europe, will meet the ``new emerging leaders of Romania,'' the spokesman said, and later Tuesday is to fly to Bonn for two days of talks with West German officials. Waldegrave made no comment before leaving London's Heathrow Airport aboard a regularly scheduled Swissair flight, but another Foreign Office minister called for a cautious approach to the changes convulsing Eastern Europe. ``In our delight at the proclamation of liberal democratic values ... across Eastern Europe, we should remain alert to the risk that in one country or another, there could still be a lurch backwards,'' Foreign Office Minister Francis Maude told the Anglo-German Association in London. ``Our enthusiasm for change must therefore still be tempered by caution,'' he said. Minister for Overseas Development Lynda Chalker, meanwhile, reassured developing countries that Britain's assistance for Eastern Europe will not be at their expense. ``We have a special responsibility to assist the progress of economic reform,'' Mrs. Chalker told the Royal College of Defense Studies. ``Its importance for African, Asian, Pacific and Caribbean countries is in no way lessened by the new program of economic reform in Eastern Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: East-West Military Officers Prepare for Discussions
DOC.TEXT: Senior military officers from 35 nations on Tuesday will open the first East-West talks in history on the defense policies that guide the superpowers and their allies. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, was an early arrival in Vienna. The Soviets' head military man, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, also is due to attend.
