DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp. won a five-day reprieve from a group of banks that could force the retailing giant to file for bankruptcy protection by declaring it in default on a $2.34 billion loan. The banks agreed Sunday to extend a grace period for Campeau before deciding whether it is in default on the loan, a banking industry source said. The extension until Friday gives Campeau breathing room to come up with a plan to avoid a bankruptcy filing for its retailing operations, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp.

General Motors Corp. said it had reached a tentative agreement with a Hungarian government-owned automaker to invest $150 million in a plant under construction in the Eastern European nation. The deal, announced Sunday, would make GM the first U.S. automaker to invest in Eastern Europe, which has undergone tremendous political and economic liberalization in recent months, said R.L. Theis, GM's Detroit-based international spokesman. The agreement between General Motors Europe and RABA, Hungary's state-owned manufacturer of trucks, diesel engines and axles, involves a joint venture to build engines and cars at a plant in Szentgotthard, near the Austrian border, beginning in 1992.

General Motors Corp. said it will offer early retirement incentives, limit new hiring and reduce advertising spending in a sweeping cost-cutting plan tied to an industry slump. The program has no target or deadline, spokesman Terry Sullivan said Friday. It is separate from GM's ``Action Plan'' of 1987 that aims to slash up to $13 billion in costs by the end of this year.

Ford Motor Co. said it plans to sell its Ford Aerospace Corp. subsidiary and concentrate on its core businesses, attempting to divest the defense contractor at a time the Pentagon is eyeing major spending cuts. The decision announced Friday to sell Ford Aerospace, a 17,000-worker operation that gets about two-thirds of its business from defense contracts, marks the second recent move by a Big Three automaker to sell a major non-automotive subsidiary.

A fourth theme park, a Soviet pavilion and seven new hotels will be among major projects to be built during a decade of rapid expansion at Florida's Disney World, Disney Chairman Michael Eisner announced. The 1990s also will feature the entertainment conglomerate's venture into time-share vacation units, and it plans to open 29 new attractions at its three existing Florida parks: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center and Disney-MGM Studios, Eisner said Sunday.

Soaring energy costs pushed wholesale prices up 0.7 percent in December, bringing inflation in 1989 to an eight-year high of 4.8 percent, the government said. The sharp, seasonally adjusted monthly rise helped spook financial markets, which read it as a sign the Federal Reserve would not lower interest rates anytime soon. Markets also were reacting Friday to stock plunges earlier in London and Tokyo.

Retail sales increased just 5 percent in 1989, the slowest gain in seven years, and holiday spending was the weakest since 1985, the government reported. Analysts said the figures released Friday reflected a slide in consumer spending, an area of strength at times in the economy last year. ``It seems that consumer spending is dead in the water,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago.

UAL Corp. Chairman Stephen M. Wolf remains actively involved in talks with employee unions over a possible buyout, the company's board of directors said, disputing reports Wolf had been replaced in the discussions. The board ``has not precluded and, in fact, continues to encourage Mr. Wolf to lead an ESOP proposal, and that process is continuing,'' UAL spokesman Rob Doughty said Friday, reading a prepared statement.

A former Boeing Co. marketing executive was sentenced to two years in prison for passing classified Pentagon budget documents to the aerospace giant and other defense contractors. Richard Lee Fowler, 64, a onetime civilian Air Force budget analyst who worked for Boeing from 1978 to 1986, contended he didn't know he was breaking the law when he obtained more than 100 classified documents. In another case Friday, a San Diego, Calif., defense consultant was sentenced to a year in prison for his role in a scheme to funnel bribes to a Marine Corps procurement official.

The stock market on Friday had its worst sell-off since its Friday the 13th tumble last October. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 71.46 points to 2,689.21. The dollar weakened in European trading. Gold prices jumped as much as $4 a troy ounce. Bond prices fell sharply. Grain futures prices closed mixed and soybeans were lower.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Lower At Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices declined at midday Monday but were rebounding from lower levels as bargain-hunters entered the fray. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 23.4 points lower at 2,356.7 around noon, compared with an earlier low of 2,352.8 points. At its best, the index briefly touched the 2,361.7 level. Midday volume totaled 207.2 million shares, down from 256.9 million Friday. Dealers attributed most of the market's early descent to a price markdown by market makers rather than concerted sell orders. ``The market has kept its nerve and trading is by no means all one-way,'' said one dealer. ``A lot of people are on the outlook for a cheap line of stock.''

DOC.HEAD: EC Jobless Rate Reaches Seven-Year Low, Below 9 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's unemployment rate fell to a seven-year low of 8.9 percent during November, EC's statistics agency Eurostat announced Monday. The decline in November _ from 9 percent in October and 9.7 percent in November 1988 _ put the jobless rate below 9 percent for the first time since 1982. Henning Christophersen, the EC's Economic Affairs Commissioner, said the drop showed the ``investment and growth-oriented policies'' of the 12-nation trade bloc were working. Eurostat said that national unemployment rates either fell slightly or were unchanged in November except in West Germany and Denmark. The rise in West Germany reflected the movement of East German workers to the West seeking jobs, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Confident Bhopal Settlement Will Stand
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. said today that a $470 million settlement for victims of the 1984 gas-leak disaster in Bhopal, India, remains binding even though the country's new government has disavowed the settlement. ``We are confident the settlement will stand. There is simply no basis for overturning it,'' Joseph E. Geoghan, Union Carbide vice president and general counsel, said in a statement. Last week, the new government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh said its predecessor was wrong to agree to absolve Union Carbide of criminal liability in the gas disaster. It also called the settlement inadequate. Justice Minister Dinesh Goswami said the new government would support the gas victims and activists in Supreme Court petitions challenging the right of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's government to settle the case. But Geoghan called the settlement ``extremely fair'' and said it is a binding agreement. ``The new administration may not disavow the settlement because it disagrees with it,'' he said. At least 3,598 people were killed and another 20,000 injured when methyl isocyanate gas leaked from a Union Carbide pesticide plant plant on Dec. 3, 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Weekly Space-Oriented Newspaper Premiers
DOC.TEXT: A new, four-color weekly newspaper devoted to news about the business and politics of space began publishing Monday after three months of putting out ``preview'' editions. ``Space News,'' edited by Theresa Foley, is a publication of the Times Journal Co. of Springfield, Va. The company also publishes the Army Times, Navy Times, Air Force Times, Federal Times, Defense News and Journal Newspapers in suburban areas of Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: What Chapter 11 Means for Campeau
With PM-Campeau
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp.'s decision to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors for its two U.S. retailing subsidiaries today means the debt-swamped businesses can operate, and many consumers may never notice a change. None of the 260 stores operated by Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. is expected to close although some may be sold as part of any future restructuring, which will have to be approved by a bankruptcy judge. Under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, companies are shielded from creditors while they remain in business and attempt to reorganize their finances so all debts eventually can be repaid. Many companies emerge from Chapter 11 as smaller but financially sound businesses. In Campeau's case, the Chapter 11 filing's immediate result would be to keep stores open and supplied. Many businesses had been reluctant to continue shipping merchandise to Campeau stores because they weren't sure they'd be paid, but the filing will establish a timetable for payment that should help reassure these suppliers. It is unclear how the filing may affect Campeau's 110,000 employees in the United States, some of whom presumably could be laid off in any bankruptcy restructuring. Uncertainty over whether Campeau would be able to repay the $8 billion in debts it has acquired through takeovers of Federated and Allied in the 1980s was the main reason the parent company sought bankruptcy court refuge for its U.S. units.

DOC.HEAD: National Westminster Bank Reorganizes Board
DOC.TEXT: National Westminster Bank PLC, one of Britain's largest commercial banks, on Monday named a new deputy chairman as part of a series of changes that include reducing the size of its board to 19 members from 28. The new deputy chairman will be Christopher Tugendhat, currently a board member who is chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority and a former vice president of the European Community Commission. He will replace Philip Wilkinson ,who is to retire June 30. Anthony Touche, Leslie Young and Lord Boyne also will retire. The retirements had been expected. Natwest said the board's decision to reduce its number will take effect from the annual general meeting April 24. ``A board with fewer members will be able to address issues in depth so as to determine our corporate objective and policy,'' said Chairman Lord Alexander. The former chairman, Lord Boardman, stepped down last year. Boardman had planned to retire at the end of 1989. Instead, he resigned in September after Natwest and its investment banking arm were strongly criticized by the Department of Trade and Industry for their role in the 1987 sale of Blue Arrow PLC shares to finance that company's takeover of Manpower Inc., the U.S.-based employment services company. The brokers involved failed to disclose the amount of stock they continued to hold after the shares failed to sell. Natwest said it was also creating a new British advisory unit to help shape the bank's British strategy. Sir Hugh Cubitt, David Money-Coutts, Barry Reed and Alan McLintock are directors who will leave the main board to form the nucleus of the new unit.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's 1989 Inflation 20.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices rose 20.7 percent in Israel during 1989 despite an austerity program aimed at reducing inflation, the government said Monday. Israel's Central Bureau of Statistics said prices rose 1.1 percent in December, compared with 1.3 percent in November and 1.6 percent in December 1988. The December increase in the Consumer Price Index, which measures price changes in a fixed market basket of goods, brought the total for the year to 20.7 percent. This compared with 16.4 percent in 1988 and 16.1 percent in 1987. The price performance was still far better than the 1984 peak when inflation reached 445 percent. Finance Minister Shimon Peres had pledged to bring the nation's inflation rate down to ``one-digit figures'' in 1989 when he announced a major austerity program at the start of the year. That program included two devaluations of the shekel against the dollar and cuts in subsidies for consumer goods.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Communist Tabloid Launches Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The Morning Star, Britain's Communist daily newspaper, published a front-page appeal to its readers Monday for $240,000 to buy new equipment. The appeal was ``the only solution to the enormous crisis faced by the paper as the result of the drastic halving of the copies previously ordered by the Soviet Union,'' the newspaper said. The Morning Star's Soviet distributor cut in half its daily order of 12,000 copies on Dec. 25 after the Kremlin ordered it to meet efficiency guidelines. The tabloid, which marked its 60th anniversary this month, will lose an estimated $660,000 of its annual income of $2.8 million because of the Soviet cut. Up to 25 jobs will be cut and the newspaper will be reduced to eight pages from 12 until it can buy better printing equipment, it said. ``A clarion call is going out to all the democratic and progressive forces which the paper has served so long and so faithfully, urging them to come to its aid,'' the paper said. It said the appeal has raised $3,200, half from an employee who had planned to bequeath the money in her will, and the other half from a lifelong reader. The newspaper's circulation, now at 23,500, peaked in 1947 at 143,000.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Has Problems, Short Term and Long
DOC.TEXT: These are times that challenge the determination and creativity of American car companies, not just over the short-term, which is known to be a tough testing ground, but in the long run too. General Motors' profit on each car made in North America over the past decade has averaged $50, which is nothing to write about in the annual report, but still it has lost market share. How do you work out of that dilemma? Ford and Chrysler, and GM as well, developed big interests in the defense industry during the 1980s, not knowing that the economic and geopolitical map of the world would be scattered like a jigsaw puzzle, undermining spending. Now all the car companies, foreign and domestic, are facing a Congress that seems determined to raise the gasoline mileage performance of their products, the better, it is claimed, to consersve fuel and keep the air clean. The market, meanwhile, has become anemic. Instead of announcing record-high sales, as they had become accustomed to, the car companies now are announcing sales declines and production cutbacks. In the 1989 final quarter, domestic-make sales dropped to a 6.2 million annual rate, the lowest quarterly figure in nearly seven years. And January production estimates are only 4.5 million units, 2 million below earlier plans. Over the longer term, the picture might improve _ but probably not by a great degree, according to a 10-year outlook from the University of Michigan's Transportation Research Institute. The market through 2000 is likely to be a mature one, it says, with more offerings competing for a relatively fixed set of customers. How did the institute reach that conclusion? By interviewing 250 industry executives. As a result of those interviews, it concludes that manufacturers will be forced to reduce costs, improve quality and offer better services to buyers, an assignment that might chill the most confident executive. It will mean, says the study, that manufacturers might have to extend power train warranties up to 10 years or 100,000 miles on some models, and that the average total life of cars will climb to 12 years by 2000 from 11 in 1990. At the same time, prices will be held down. They might climb in the next year or so, the institute believes, but then level off so that a U.S.-made car costing $14,000 in 1990 would sell for $15,900 in 2000. Of course, all car companies will be expected simultaneously to continue with the same old assignment of improving sales month by month and year by year, even if the market as a whole doesn't accommodate those goals. The study estimated that passenger car sales in the United States will grow less than 1 percent a year over the decade, to 10.9 million units in 2000 from 10.1 million in 1990. Light truck sales also will grow slowly, but less so. Unless the Big Three surprise the institute _ and, apparently, themselves too _ their best efforts still will mean a loss of market share over the decade, to 61 percent of passenger car sales in 2000 from 64 percent in 1990. The estimates have unusual validity in the car market, because the data on which they are made come, so to speak, from the horse's mouth. i.e., from automotive executives, engineers, suppliers, consultants and academics. The particular study that developed these figures is the fifth in a series of 10-year forecasts directed by David E. Cole, professor of mechanical engineering and director of the institute's Study of Automotive Transportation. The message it flashes couldn't be more clear: Carmakers who thought they had done everything possible to produce high quality cars at the lowest price will have to exert even greater effort. The buyer is in the driver's seat.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing figures.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished lower Monday on the London Stock Exchange, although well above the day's lows. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 13.9 points, or 0.59 percent, to 2,366.2. Its midmorning low had been 2,352.8, and it closed near it high for the day. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was off 12.2 points at 1,896.9, and the Financial Times 500-share index closed at 1,292.92, down 8.47. Volume amounted to 359.6 million shares, compared with the 523.9 million shares on Friday. The market opened sharply lower following downturns in the U.S. and Japanese equity markets last week. But prices recovered later on what analysts said was bargain-hunting. A midday report that British retail sales rose more than expected in December limited the recovery in prices, however, by adding to fears that the government's anti-inflation strategy will fall apart without another increase in interest rates.
