Declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of about 5 to 2, with 405 stocks rising, 1,064 falling and 437 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to a moderate 104.04 million shares at midafternoon. the selling that began Friday after two disappointing economic reports continued into today's session. ``They don't see any reason to take an aggressive stand on the buy Analysts said side,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. The government reported Friday that wholesale prices surged 0.7 percent during December while retail sales rose a sluggish 0.2 percent. The combination of accelerating inflation and a softening economy unnerved many investors and stock prices fell sharply, with the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling more than 71 points. Trading was relatively light today as many institutional buyers took the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday off. Financial markets in Japan were closed for a holiday, and many U.S. traders were waiting to see how stocks would fare when Tokyo trading resumed Tuesday. The Japanese stock market had its worst decline in two years on likely to be similar to last week,'' Ishikawa said. ``The yen will remain weak, and the plunge in government bond prices will not stop any time soon.'' Former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe and seven other lawmakers from the governing Liberal Democratic Party are in Moscow. Abe met Monday with Gorbachev. Another worry is inflation. The weaker yen, which makes imports of raw materials and fuel more expensive, has increased inflationary pressures, prompting the Bank of Japan to boost interest rates to curb price rises and support the yen. ``It is too optimistic to see the current plunge as a transitional, adjustment process,'' said Josen Takahashi, chief economist with Mitsubishi Research Institute. ``There's nothing positive in the securities market because of the current inflationary pressures,'' he told the newspaper Asahi Shimbun. Takahashi said inflationary pressure in Japan has created a ``triple low'' phenomenon _ a simultaneous decline in securities, yen and government bond prices. Despite market expectations that the Bank of Japan will continue supporting the yen, possibly by boosting the official discount rate, traders said they expect the Japanese currency to stay weak because of political uncertainty over national elections expected in February. Their major concern is whether the pro-business Liberal Democrats will maintain their majority in Parliament's lower house. The party lost its control in the less-powerful upper house last year after a series of money and sex scandals involving party lawmakers and the introduction of an unpopular 3 percent sales tax. The central bank also is expected to maintain its high interest rate policy in order to control inflationary pressures resulting from the weaker yen, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Backers of Consortium of U.S. Computer Chip Makers Fold Venture
PRECEDE San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 10 new grafs to UPDATE with Kane confirming venture failure at morning news conference; ADDS byline, Picks up 9th graf pvs, Observers cited ....
DOC.TEXT: SANTA CLARA, Calif. _ A U.S. venture that was designed to regain control of the vital computer chip industry from Japanese dominance is being folded because it failed to attract investors, officials announced today. U.S. Memories Inc. was hailed as a $1 billion cooperative venture by American companies, but in its seven brief months of life, it failed to make a single computer chip or earn a single dollar. ``I am extremely disappointed by these turn of events,'' said Sanford L. Kane, president of U.S. Memories, at a news conference at Santa Clara headquarters. ``What happens today does not bode well for an industry that has made a technical decision rather than a tactical one.'' Kane told reporters that the joint venture will be terminated, largely because of a lack of support from the electronics industry. The venture had not found a new investor since its formation last June by seven big-name backers _ International Business Machines Corp., Digital Equipment Corp., Hewlett-Packard Co., Intel Corp., Advanced Micro Devices Inc., National Semiconductor Corp. and LSI Logic, according to a Saturday report by the San Francisco Chronicle. The New York Times and The Washington Post had quoted unidentified industry sources indicating the venture would announce its demise today. The consortium was planned to challenge Japanese leadership in the making of computer memory chips called DRAMs, or dynamic random access memories, often compared to crude oil in their importance to industry. Despite today's announcement, Kane said the venture had produced some positive results. ``We did achieve some significant things in the process,'' Kane said. ``We showed that with some creativity and support and teamwork we could come up with a solution within the American framework. We clearly increased the impact of the seimconductor industry and DRAMs in particular.'' Spokesmen for Intel and Advanced Micro Devices had told the San Francisco Chronicle they still supported the plan. Observers cited by the Chronicle said the consortium may simply stop actively seeking investors or announce a restructuring plan. But they said these developments are unlikely. ``It looks like the end,'' said T.J. Rodgers, chief executive of San Jose-based Cypress Semiconductor, a critic of the consortium plan. The failure would be regarded as a major setback for advocates of collective action to improve U.S. competitiveness. ``It's a true strategic setback,'' said Ralph Thomson, chief executive of International Business Catalysts, a Palo Alto consulting firm that focuses on trade and technology. U.S. Memories in June announced its plan for construction of a $1 billion plant to make the 4-megabit DRAM chips. The plant was to be paid for by $500 million in equity financing from chip makers and users and $500 million in debt, with fund raising expected to be completed last year. By November, several major computer companies _ including Sun Microsystems Inc., Unisys Corp., Apple Computer Inc. and Tandy Corp. _ said they would not join as investors. Computer industry officials told the Times that the end of U.S. Memories was decided Wednesday at a meeting in Dallas attended by the seven founding companies and others considering joining the venture. The Times said the project failed in part because the memory chips have become more widely available as Samsung of South Korea, Siemens A.G. of West Germany and Motorola Inc. of the United States have begun manufacturing the chips. There had been a shortage of the chips in 1988. By the mid-1980s, all but two of the U.S. companies that pioneered the DRAM industry had left the field in the face of competition from the Japanese, who now supply the majority of memory chips.

DOC.HEAD: Coors Launches Sparkling Water Product
DOC.TEXT: For the first time since Prohibition, a division of Adolph Coors Co. is selling a non-alcoholic beverage, a new product called Coors Rocky Mountain Sparkling Water, company officials said Monday. The product goes on sale this week in Colorado, Arizona and Northern California cities mainly in the San Francisco area, Coors spokesman Heidi Buehler Nogues said. ``Bottled water is the fastest-growing beverage category in America,'' John Recca, brand development manager, said in a news release. ``The timing is right for us to take advantage of our legendary water source.'' The product is made by Coors Brewing Co., which is a business unit of the Golden-based Adolph Coors Co. Coors Rocky Mountain Sparkling Water will be packaged in 6.5-ounce, six-pack bottles and in 28-ounce bottes, officials said. It will be available in original, lemon lime and cherry flavors. In the past five years, the bottled water marketplace has grown about 10 percent, primarily because of the consumer interest in health and fitness, Coors said. A key to Coors' product is the use of pure, Rocky Mountain spring water, an ingredient that has made the company's beers famous for 50 years, Coors said. ``The new product also provides the company with a good opportunity to diversify its beverage line and provide consumers with new choices,'' Coors officials said. ``This is especially important with the growing national trend toward moderate alcohol consumption.'' During the 1920s, the manufacture, sale and transportation of alcoholic beverages was banned in the United States. Buehler Nogues said Coors sold malt beverages which did not contain alcohol. The law was repealed in 1933.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Leader Urges More Japanese Investment in Poland
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki on Monday urged Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan to increase investments and economic involvement to help Poland's reform efforts. Mazowiecki also thanked Kaifu for his government's decision to contribute $150 million in credit to a stabilization fund to back the zloty as the part of the transition to a convertible Polish currency, but said more could be done. ``I positively assess the state of political relations between our countries. However, economic cooperation does not catch up with them. We want Japan to occupy a considerably higher position both on the list of trading partners and as regards economic involvement in Poland,'' Mazowiecki said at a lunch for Kaifu. ``We want this to this to be coupled with the transfer of patterns of Japanese organization of production and high quality of labor, recognized worldwide, to the Polish economy,'' the PAP news agency quoted Mazowiecki as saying. Kaifu is the first major leader from Asia to visit Poland since Mazowiecki was elected to lead Poland's first non-communist government in over four decades on Aug. 24. The United States and West Germany have led the developed countries in pledging aid to help the troubled Polish economy and assist radical economic reform efforts. In addition to its pledge to the currency stabilization fund, Japan has agreed to provide Poland with $25 million worth of food aid and $15 million to help train Polish managers. Japan is considering a possible $350 million guarantee for government investments as well as a $500 million guarantee by the Japanese EXIM Bank for Japanese investments in Poland. The conditions of the guarantees have yet to be worked out. Poland is also hoping for Japanese support during negotiations by the Paris club on Poland's $40 billion foreign debt. Poland would like a three-year relief on interest payments on the debt so that precious hard currency can be used for investment purposes and to stabilize the currency. Kaifu assured President Wojciech Jaruzelski of further economic support for Poland as economic experts discussed terms of future Japanese credit guarantees during an earlier meeting. Kaifu also met with Sejm speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewciz and Senate speaker Andrzej Stelmachowski on the final day of a two-day visit to Poland, the PAP news agency reported. PAP said that Kaifu told Jaruzelski that Japan would increase its support for the changes underway in Poland, particularly in the field of financial cooperation. After his meetings in Poland, Kaifu traveled to Budapest on the last leg of a seven-country, 10-day tour of Europe. Kaifu was met at the airport by his Hungarian counterpart Miklos Nemeth, the state Hungarian news agency MTI said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices rose modestly in broad-based buying Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade while wheat and soybean futures retreated slightly. Corn's advance apparently was related to last week's Agriculture Department crop report, which pegged both the 1989 U.S. corn harvest and the nation's corn stockpile at levels that were lower than the market had expected. ``It looks like some users got caught short,'' said Dale Gustafson, an analyst in Chicago with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Soybean futures were pressed by reports of weekend rainfall in southern Brazil, a major soybean-producing area. Forecasts for rain later this week in winter wheat areas of the United States weighed on the wheat futures market. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 3 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.99 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 1} cents higher with March at $2.44 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with March at $1.43{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3 cents lower with January at $5.63} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau's U.S. Grocery Chain Avoids Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.TEXT: Ralphs Grocery Co. has avoided the financial woes gnawing at Campeau Corp.'s other U.S. companies, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., Ralphs' chief said Monday. ``It's business as usual,'' Chairman and Chief Executive Byron Allumbaugh said after Allied and Federated sought protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law. ``Nothing has occurred that will in any way change or alter the way Ralphs does business,'' Allumbaugh said. Ralphs, with 142 stores, is the third largest supermarket chain in Southern California. Toronto-based Campeau, the huge retailer burdened with billions of dollars of debts, acquired Ralphs as part of its 1988 takeover of Federated. But Ralphs became an independent corporation under the Campeau umbrella in July 1988, and is unaffected by the bankruptcy filings. ``We are a separate corporation from Federated, with our own debt, our own bank financing,'' Allumbaugh said. ``Ralphs needs no funds from Campeau and the Campeau Corp. is prohibited from removing any funds from Ralphs.'' Most Ralphs customers are unaware the company is part of Campeau, and Ralphs has no immediate plan to advertise to reassure them, he said. As part of the spinoff from Federated, Ralphs management bought a stake in Ralphs by paying Federated $1.02 billion, which the managers borrowed. The cost of paying down that debt has kept Ralphs in the red, a circumstance expected as part of the deal. But analysts say the grocery chain has had no problems paying interest on the nearly $1 billion debt that remains while remodeling and adding stores as needed. For example, Ralphs had $40 million on hand to pay the $11.3 million in debt due at the end of this month, said Andrew Leinoff, an analyst at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei in Montpelier, Vt. When rumors of the impending Allied and Federated filings began circulating last week, Allumbaugh and Ralphs bankers and financial strategists met with suppliers to reassure them of the grocery chain's solvency. Allumbaugh told the suppliers that Ralphs has been able to cut its net losses from $72.6 million in fiscal 1988 to about $31 million in fiscal 1989, which ends Jan. 28. The company projects a net loss of $7 million in the coming year, followed by a $17 million profit in fiscal 1991, he said. ``For the year ending this month, we had an operating cash flow of $189 million, and the cash interest on our debt is about $130 million. So we have about $59 million of free cash flow to reinvest in our business,'' Allumbaugh said. For Ralphs customers, the Allied and Federated bankruptcy filings are a ``non-event,'' Allumbaugh said.

Prices fell broadly on Wall Street today as traders, stung by Friday's sharp losses, shied away from the stock market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 13.44 to 2,675.77 as of 3 p.m. EST. Declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of 11 to 4, with 402 stocks rising, 1,095 falling and 432 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to a moderate 118.89 million shares with one hour of trading left. Analysts said the selling that began after two disappointing economic reports on Friday continued into today's session. ``They don't see any reason to take an aggressive stand on the buy side,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. The government reported Friday that wholesale prices surged 0.7 percent during December while retail sales rose a sluggish 0.2 percent. The combination of accelerating inflation and a softening economy unnerved many investors and stock prices fell sharply, with the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling more than 71 points. Trading was relatively light today as many institutional buyers took the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday off. Financial markets in Japan were closed for a holiday, and many U.S. traders were waiting to see how stocks would fare when Tokyo trading resumed Tuesday. The Japanese stock market had its worst decline in two years Friday, contributing to Wall Street's dismal performance. The most active issue on the NYSE today was Philip Morris, which fell ] to 38]. Rorer Group shot up 13[ to 62] after announcing it was negotiating with another company on a possible merger. Among blue chip issues, AT&T was down { to 42}, IBM was unchanged at 97~, and General Electric fell { to 62|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.32 to 187.00. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 3.68 to 368.55.

DOC.HEAD: Chase, First Chicago Report Lower 4th-Qtr Income
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp. said Monday that its profit fell 36 percent in the final quarter of 1989 compared with the previous year, while another large banking company, First Chicago Corp., reported an 11 percent drop in quarterly net income. Results for all of last year also were depressed from 1988 levels, reflecting in part moves to reduce exposure to shaky Third World debt. Chase said it earned $175 million, or $1.47 per share, in the three months ended Dec. 31. That compared with earnings of $275 million, or $2.93 a share, in the 1988 period. Chase attributed the fourth quarter decline mainly to the fact that it received $217 million in interest payments from Brazil in 1988, and nothing in the latest quarter. During the latest period, Chase used less income tax benefits than the previous year, $25 million vs. $60 million. The fourth-quarter results also include increases in consumer and investment banking fees and trading account income. For the year, the New York-based bank lost $665 million, or $7.94 a share, after earning $1.06 billion, or $11.55 a share, in 1988. Chase's annual loss reflects a decision made in the third quarter of last year to take an after-tax charge of $1.26 billion to carry out a recapitalization plan that included a $1.15 billion addition to its loan-loss reserves for Third World debt. Its total provision for possible credit losses was $1.74 billion for all of 1989, up sharply from $750 million for 1988. In the fourth quarter, Chase's loan-loss provision totaled $130 million, down from $300 million in 1988. First Chicago netted $122.9 million in the fourth quarter, or $1.77 a share, down from $137.3 million, or $2.07 per share, in the previous year. But the company said its operating income was up 4 percent over a year ago, $115 million vs. $110.4 million in 1988. The Chicago bank's income for 1989 totaled $358.7 million, or $5.10 a share, compared with earnings of $513.1 million, or $8.20 a share, in 1988. Full-year operating income, however, was up 8 percent to $451.2 million, or $6.56 per share, from $417.3 million, or $6.57 a share. First Chicago said its allowance for credit losses was $1.28 billion at the end of the year, compared with $1.4 billion at the end of the third quarter and $1.31 billion at the end of 1988. Its provision for credit losses rose to $75 million in the fourth quarter from $50 million. Total net charge-offs were $199 million, up from $128 million in 1988. First Chicago's exposure to Third World debt was reduced by about $350 million during the fourth quarter to around $1.3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Reports Nationwide Problems in Placing Long-Distance Calls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led as developments warrant.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said its phone system experienced problems nationwide Monday connecting long-distance calls. Callers to many areas received a recording saying that all circuits were busy and that calls could not be put through. ``It seems to be affecting major cities in various parts of the country,'' said AT&T spokesman Burke Stinson, at the company's Basking Ridge, N.J. offices. ``No one has a theory yet what's causing it,'' he said. ``We've got our people on the case.'' He said the problem first was noticed shortly after 2:30 p.m. EST. ``It's sort of ubiquitous throughout our network,'' said Daisy Ottmann, an AT&T spokeswoman in Basking Ridge. ``It's a technical problem,'' she said. ``It's not a cable cut. It's not a natural disaster.'' She said the problem might be in the computer software that operates the phone switching equipment. She said the phone company's equipment automatically blocks calls from entering the phone network when there is a problem such as Monday's. That, she said, accounts for the recordings callers were receiving.

The stock market declined broadly today as traders remained pessimistic following two negative economic reports on Friday. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 22.19 at 2,667.02.

DOC.HEAD: Former Saudi Oil Minister Launches Energy Studies Center
DOC.TEXT: The former Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, launched on Monday the Center for Global Energy Studies which he said was aimed at encouraging cooperation among oil producers, companies and consumers to avoid another oil crisis. ``International cooperation between multinational companies, the consuming countries' governments and OPEC producers, particularly in the (Persian) Gulf, is essential and should be fostered by all means possible,'' Yamani said in launching of the London-based center. There are 13 members in OPEC, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Debate and cooperation are essential to avert another crisis, he said in his speech to the British Institute of Energy Economics. ``If no action is taken now, the world may well be headed towards another damaging oil crisis,'' he said. Oil prices rose to more than $30 a barrel in the 1970s and tumbled to below $10 a barrel in the mid-1980s. The price of the February contract of West Texas intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, has been between $22 and $23 a barrel in recent days on the New York Mercantiler Exchange. Oil capacity needs to be increased but oil producers need financial help to do this, Yamani said. The center aims to contribute toward the ``development of a trilateral spirit of cooperation by bringing together the different issues and reconciling opposing points of view so as to increase our understanding of energy,'' he said. Yamani was Saudi Arabia's oil minister from 1962 until 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
With BC-Coal Production-List
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 17 million tons during the week ending Jan. 6, up 39 percent from the 12.2 million tons produced in the previous week, the Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 16.3 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Wyoming ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.3 million tons produced. West Virginia was second at 2.69 million tons and Kentucky was third at 2.68 million tons, the agency said. The week's production was 4.3 percent higher than the 16.3 million tons produced in the first week of 1989. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher in Thin Trading; Gold Rises
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies Monday in light trading, as holidays in Japan and the United States sharply reduced worldwide activity. Gold prices also advanced. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $414.80 a troy ounce, up from $414.50 late Friday. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose to $413.70 a troy ounce from $413.20 last Friday. Dealers said trading activity was reduced due to the Martin Luther King Day holiday in the United States and a national holiday in Japan, both of which closed banks _ the biggest players in the world foreign-exchange market. Most New York banks limited their activity to executing a few orders for corporate customers, and there was no clear trend to the dollar's movements, said Charles Annunziato, a trader at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``It's such a thin market, maybe it's not a reliable guide,'' said the chief corporate dealer at a Swiss bank in London, who asked not to be named. Dealers in Europe said the dollar's rise was fueled by a weakening of the West German mark against the Japanese yen and against the British pound. The mark was pushed lower by an initial drop in Frankfurt, West Germany, share prices which was sharper than many traders had expected following Friday's fall on Wall Street. The mark has derived support in recent months from foreign investor interest in West German shares. With markets closed in Japan, the dollar was trading in London at 145.50 Japanese yen late Monday, up from 145.35 yen in Tokyo last Friday. By the end of trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 145.55 yen, down from 145.74 yen there late Friday. In London, the pound fell to $1.6620 from $1.6705 late Friday. Later, in New York, a pound cost $1.6630, more expensive than late Friday's $1.6610. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6967 West German marks, up from 1.6860; 1.5110 Swiss francs, up from 1.4975; 5.7635 French francs, up from 5.7410; 1,261.75 Italian lire, up from 1,256.00; and 1.1657 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1573. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6965 West German marks, up from 1.6785; 1.5120 Swiss francs, up from 1.4940; 5.7625 French francs, up from 5.7155; 1.9015 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8870; 1,261.375 Italian lire, up from 1,252.00; and 1.1622 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1560. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $412.00 a troy ounce, down from $416.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $412.40, down from $416.75 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 49 cents to close at a bid $412.10. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.24 a troy ounce, down from $5.36 bid late Friday. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $5.242 a troy ounce, down from $5.330 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Junk Bond Prices Fall After Campeau Filing
With AM-Campeau Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond prices fell Monday after a bankruptcy court filing by two Campeau Corp. units, whose financial troubles triggered the high-yield bond market's severe tailspin last fall. ``Whenever that happens it is a disturbing event and it's a drag on the market and it was,'' said Robert Lupo, director of high-yield bond research at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Traders said issues of high-yield bonds on average fell about \ point to { point. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 for every $1,000 in face value of the bond. The widely watched 13.71 percent RJR Holdings Capital Corp. bond due in 2009 was down about ~ point at 90~. The decision by Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law drew a subdued reaction because it had been expected, traders said. The two units of Toronto-based Campeau operate 260 stores in the United States, including Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh, Abraham & Straus, Lazarus and Stern's. ``I don't think there's any major market participant who's surprised,'' said David Fineman, a trader in Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield division. ``The shock to the market in Federated came months ago.'' Some analysts attributed the dull reaction to the bankruptcy filings, made in Cincinnati, where Federated and Allied are based, to light activity on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday. ``There might be some additional pressure to come from all this once everybody's back to their desks,'' Lupo said. The government securities market was closed Monday. Prices of corporate and municipal bonds were slightly lower in quiet trading, said Eric Friedlander, a corporate bond trader with Prudential-Bache Securities Corp. Junk bonds also fell sharply on Friday in tandem with a sharp drop in the stock market. Monday's decline was the junk market's fourth straight. The $210 billion high-yield bond market has slumped since Campeau's surprise disclosure of liquidity problems last September. Prices have not recovered entirely and new issues of junk bonds have been squelched because of the sell-off. For the 1989 fourth quarter, analysts said, high-yield bonds showed a total return of negative 4 percent. Federated and Allied bonds were mostly lower Monday. Allied 10.5 percent junk bonds declined more than two points to 42, while 11.5 percent bonds were unchanged at 11. Federated bonds yielding 16 percent were down about two points to 12. Bonds of Ralphs Grocery Co., a Campeau-owned southern California chain, took the day's biggest hit, down about three points at 95. Ralphs was not included in the bankruptcy filing but traders said there is concern bondholders may seek to claim they were defrauded because of Campeau's troubles. Among other notable issues, RJR 13.71 percent bonds due in 2007 were down about { point at 79[. R.H. Macy & Co. bonds due in 2001 were down nearly a point at 84|. Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it lowered the ratings on all Allied and Federated subordinated debt because of the filing. Moody's said about $2.2 billion in Federated and $1.6 billion in Allied debt securities were affected. It said the companies were in default on a $2.34 billion bank loan. Due to the bankruptcy filing, the Allied and Federated bonds were trading ``flat,'' that is, without accrued interest. Junk bonds normally pay interest twice a year. In flat trading, sellers do not receive interest accrued from the last payment and buyers do not have to pay it. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds 92~, down 3-32 point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.30 percent from 7.29 percent late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Canada and Venezuela Discuss Oil Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: Venezuelan Energy Minister Celestino Armas on Wednesday opened a round of meetings between Venezuela and Canada to discuss mutual cooperation on technical oil matters. It is the fifth round of meetings at this level since both nations agreed to exchange oil information in 1985. The meeting reflects a growing cooperation between both oil producing nations. Last year, Armas announced the creation of an oil consortium that would include several Latin American oil producing nations plus Canada and Italy. It was not known if details of the plan would be discussed during the meeting. Petroleos de Venezuela, the Venezuelan oil conglomerate, and Canada's Alberta Oil Sands Technology and Research Authority signed a scientific and technological cooperation agreement in 1988. The Canadian delegation is presided over by David Oulton, planning and oil general director of the Canadian Energy and Natural Resources Ministry. The meetings are expected to end on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,730,000 net tons during the week ending Jan. 13, up 1.8 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Monday. The week's production represented 77.5 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said. American steelmakers produced 1,923,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 3,188,000 net tons, 8.9 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 212,000 tons (215,000 tons); Pittsburgh 168,000 (154,000); Youngstown 97,000 (93,000); Lake Erie 120,000 (121,000); Detroit 138,000 (137,000); Chicago 485,000 (478,000); Midwest 178,000 (175,000); Southern 242,000 (238,000); Western 90,000 (88,000).

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Prices Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures nosedived Monday amid profit-taking and investor worries about mounting heating oil supplies. Analysts said warmer weather and growing imports were contributing to a build-up in heating oil inventories just weeks after investor worries about possible heating oil shortages sent prices soaring to decade highs. ``It became clear the middle of last week that the fears were unfounded as cargos of heating oil were arriving at New York ports,'' said Tom Bentz, director of futures trading for United Energy Inc. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the February contract for No. 2 heating oil tumbled 5.05 cents to settle at 64.60 cents a gallon, erasing nearly half of last week's gains of 11.17 cents a gallon. Contracts for delivery after February lost between 1.70 cents and 2 cents. Crude oil and gasoline futures also fell sharply, pressured by weakness in the heating oil market, analysts said. The February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 77 cents to $22.36 a barrel, partly on profit-taking after recent gains. March crude lost 64 cents to $21.49 and April declined 56 cents to $20.95 a barrel. February unleaded gasoline sank 1.50 cents to 63.59 cents a gallon, while March fell 1.21 cents to 63.04 cents and April ended at 62.92 cents a gallon, down 1.14 cents. Analysts said talk of a possible strike at Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, kept gasoline futures from falling further. Brazil currently ships three to six cargos of gasoline to the United States a month, said Bentz. One cargo contains 225,000 barrels. ``A strike would affect us if it's long-term,'' Bentz said. Analysts said worries about possible heating oil shortages in recent weeks brought a slew of imports from Europe and other countries. The concern was prompted by unusually frigid weather in many parts of the United States as well as refinery problems, including a fire and explosion at a huge Exxon refinery in December that closed the facility for several days. ``It looks as if more supply is coming from Europe than before and that has kicked the bottom from heating oil and also weakened gasoline,'' said James Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Int'l Multifoods Selling Mister Donut Franchising To Dunkin' Donuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, The deal...to CLARIFY rankings are on basis of sales. ADDS 2 new grafs to UPDATE with further comments on antitrust issue.
DOC.TEXT: International Multifoods Corp. announced Monday that it had agreed to sell its Mister Donut franchising operations in the United States and Canada to rival Dunkin' Donuts Inc. The deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, if completed would combine the franchised doughnut shop chains that are the two biggest in North America on the basis of sales. Dunkin' Donuts, which was acquired late last year by Britain's Allied-Lyons PLC, has some 1,600 franchised shops in North America, while No. 2 Mister Donut has 558 U.S. and Canadian franchises. International Multifoods said Mister Donut's 475-store U.S. operation would be sold to Dunkin' Donuts and the 83-store Canadian operation will be sold to Allied-Lyons Canada Limited, of Toronto. The transaction is scheduled to close by the end of February. Terms under the definitive agreement announced Monday were not disclosed. ``Over the past several years, we have concentrated our development in food service on food processing and specialty distribution,'' said Tony Luiso, chairman, president and chief executive officer of International Multifoods. ``Though the Mister Donut system is strong and the business is profitable, franchising is not part of our long-term strategic direction,'' Luiso said. Mister Donut had franchisee sales of about $156 million for its U.S. and Canadian businesses in fiscal 1989. In the nine months ended July 29, Dunkin' Donuts reported total earnings of $7.62 million on revenue of $89.7 million down from a profit of $9.86 million on revenue of $82.4 million in the same period a year earlier. International Multifoods plans to continue serving both Mister Donut and Dunkin' Donuts' franchisees as a supplier of bakery ingredients. Multifoods, with fiscal 1989 sales of $1.9 billion, is a diversified food company with major operations in the United States, Canada and Venezuela. Allied-Lyons, a diversified food and beverage conglomerate, acquired Dunkin' Donuts late last year for $325 million. The deal ended the chain's seven-month battle to thwart a hostile bid led by Unicorp Canada Corp. and partner Cara Operations. Richard Hart, a spokesman for Dunkin' Donuts, said he does not expect the government to raise antitrust objections to the Mister Donut deal. He said there is a ``huge, huge, huge'' number of competitors selling donuts, including bakeries, grocery stores and individually owned donut shops. Hart said the shops initially will retain their separate identities, but the company will test the idea of converting Mister Donut shops to Dunkin' Donuts shops.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Hope Incentives, Plant Shutdowns, Will Shrink Inventories
DOC.TEXT: U.S. automakers, wrestling with a depressed market, head into 1990 with an inventory swollen nearly 40 percent over last year's level and hopes that temporary factory shutdowns and incentives will shrink it. The eight major automakers who make cars in the U.S. report early-January sales Tuesday, the first reporting period of a year most industry officials and analysts have said will be weaker than 1989, when about 14.8 million new vehicles hit American roads. The weekly Ward's Automotive Reports in Detroit said Monday dealers had a 91-day supply of new, North American-built cars on hand as of Dec. 31. Fast Track News in Wayne, Pa. showed a 92-day supply at the same time. Ward's said that at the same time in 1988, dealers had a 66-day supply, one day less than what Fast Track News estimated. The 1988 figure was effected by a late-December, incentive-inspired buying spree. The automakers are gambling that production cuts and incentives will shrivel inventories this month. The companies were shut down Monday because of the observance of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday. On Dec. 15, Chrysler Corp. announced an enhanced incentive package which was matched to some degree by Ford Motor Co. And by the end of this month, more than 120,000 auto workers each will have spent at least a week away from their jobs on temporary layoff as the companies tried to bring production into line with stock. ``Production in January, coupled by fairly aggressive incentives, suggest that inventories will come down by the end of the first quarter,'' analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York said Monday. At this time of year, a supply of 70 to 75 days is considered normal. Automakers usually aren't bothered by supplies creeping up a little in January and February in anticipation of a rush of sales in March and April. But things are different this year. The auto industry went into a slump at nearly the same moment as the 1990 model year officially started Oct. 1. Fear of 1990 model price increases and scaled-back incentive programs drove prospective buyers into showrooms in August and September. Because of that, automakers expected depressed sales in October and November, and they got what they expected. But what they may not have expected was that the slump would continue. To deal with the combined effects of lower consumer demand and increasing inventories, automakers shut down plants. And the production reduction spread beyond the Big Three of Ford, Chrysler and General Motors Corp. In the past, U.S. plants operated wholly or partly by Japanese companies, called ``transplants,'' have been immune from cutbacks because demand for their vehicles has held up while orders for cars made by the Big Three sagged. That's changed for some of the products coming from three plants making cars shipped to U.S. dealers under Japanese and U.S. car company nameplates. Mazda Motor Corp.'s Flat Rock, Mich., plant; the GM-Toyota Motor Corp. plant in Fremont, Calif., and the Chrysler-Mitsubishi Motors Corp. joint venture in Normal, Ill., each have announced production reductions. The reductions have come in cars carrying U.S. company nameplates _ the Ford Probe from Flat Rock, the Geo Prizm sold by Chevrolet dealers from the New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. plant in California and the Plymouth Laser from the Diamond-Star Motors Corp. plant in Illinois.

DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Futures Plunge As Weather Warms
DOC.TEXT: Heating oil futures prices tumbled Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as unseasonably warm weather spread across the country, easing demand for home heating fuel. On other commodity markets, orange juice futures ended mixed after soaring early in the session. Futures prices for precious metals, grains and soybeans, and livestock and meat also finished mixed. Most wholesale heating oil futures fell 1.85 cents to 2 cents, the permitted daily limit. The contract for delivery in February, on which the limit has been lifted pending its Jan. 31 expiration, crashed 5.05 cents to settle at 64.60 cents a gallon. Futures prices for West Texas Intermediate crude oil tumbled 22 cents to 77 cents with February at $22.36 a barrel; unleaded gasoline futures settled 1.14 cents to 1.5 cents lower with February at 63.59 cents a gallon. The plunge in heating oil prices marked the first downturn in the February contract in a week. The sell-off was largely a reaction to springlike weather in much of the northern United States, especially the populous Northeast, where record-breaking cold in December had spurred strong demand for heating oil and pushed prices up sharply. ``December's temperatures were 20 percent below normal and now it looks like January may end up 20 percent above normal,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, vice president of trading and research with Carson Petroleum Co., a Chicago-area oil distributor. ``By the time this whole thing shakes out, we're probably going to be close to normal winter weather,'' he said. Orange juice for January delivery fell sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange but prices for all other contracts ended moderately higher after initially surging the 5-cent limit in reaction to last week's Agriculture Department crop report. The report pegged the frost-damaged 1989-90 Florida orange crop at 91 million 90-pound boxes and put the expected juice yield at 1.3 gallons per box. Both forecasts were lower than expected and compare with the previous year's harvest of 130 million boxes and yield of 1.48 gallons per box. Orange juice futures prices had soared their daily limits on Friday in reaction to the report, which followed a devastating Christmas-weekend freeze. Monday's early runup represented the tail end of Friday's buying before profit-taking cut the gains, said Ernie Thomas, an orange juice specialist with Merrill Lynch Consumer Martkets Inc. in Winterhaven, Fla. Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 6.25 cents lower to 2 cents higher with January at $1.9125 a pound. Gold futures edged higher while silver futures fell sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold's finish represented a comeback from moderate losses earlier in the day. Silver was pressured by abundant supplies of the metal. Gold settled 10 cents to 50 cents higher with February at $414.70 a troy ounce; silver was 8.8 cents to 9.6 cents lower with March at $5.298 a troy ounce. Corn futures rose modestly in broad-based buying on the Chicago Board of Trade while wheat and soybean futures retreated slightly. Corn's advance apparently was related to last week's Agriculture Department crop report, which pegged both the 1989 U.S. corn harvest and the nation's corn stockpile at levels that were lower than the market had expected. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 3\ cents lower with March at $3.99{ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 1} cents higher with March at $2.43} a bushel; oats were { cent to } cent higher with March at $1.43{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3 cents lower with January at $5.64 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures finished mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in lackluster trading. Live cattle futures settled .30 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 77.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .50 cent lower with January at 83.35 cents a pound; live hogs were .37 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 50.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .17 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 55.30 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Manville Partnership to Market Insulation in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Manville International B.V. and the Belgian-based Recticel have formed a partnership to produce and market foam insulation products in Europe, Manville officials announced Monday. The partnership, called Marec Isolatie, will have the exclusive right to use the phenolic foam technology in Europe, Manville said in a news release. ``We feel strongly that the European markets offer great potential for phenolic foam insulation products,'' said Jean Pierre Guibert, general manager for Manville's Paris-based division. ``This is the best foam insulation technology available and we are seeking to transfer the technology and its success in the United States abroad.'' The technology was developed by Koppers Co. Inc. of Pittsburgh and is owned by Thermal Products International, which is based in Pittsburgh. Manville International is a subsidiary of the Denver-based Manville Corp., an international manufacturing and natural resources company. Recticel is a subsidiary of the Societe Generale de Belgique, which is based in Brussels.

DOC.HEAD: GE Furloughs 1,700 Workers For One Week
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. plans to close its factory in Somersworth, idling nearly 1,700 workers for a week Jan. 22-26 because of slowing orders, the company said Monday. Zelda Kenney, GE spokeswoman, said the production workers will be given the choice of taking the week as vacation or claiming unemployment benefits for the week. She said the temporary shutdown is designed to avoid laying off workers. The factory makes meters that are installed in houses to measure how much electricity is used. The slowdown in orders comes from a drop in the number of houses and other structures being built, she said, adding that GE sells meters to utilities and utilities rely heavily on a steady flow of construction. Kenney said utilities are placing orders with GE at a slower rate than usual, and the week off is meant to build up a backlog of orders so that employees can return to work at their usual rate. The region's economic slowdown, she added, is another indirect cause for the drop in orders.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Continue Decline As Pessimism About Economy Lingers on Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices and final advance-decline ratio; EDITS to conform throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Prices declined broadly on Wall Street Monday as pessimism about the economy _ which sent stocks sharply lower on Friday _ took a further toll on the market. ``They don't see any reason to take an aggressive stand on the buy side,'' Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co., said of traders. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.84 to 2,669.37. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 11 to 4 in nationwide-trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 395 stocks rising, 1,091 falling and 466 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to a moderate 140.59 million shares, down from 183.88 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 168.13 million shares. Analysts said the malaise that settled over Wall Street after two negative economic reports on Friday remained in place Monday. The government had reported that wholesale prices surged 0.7 percent during December while retail sales rose a sluggish 0.2 percent. The combination of accelerating inflation and a softening economy unnerved many investors and stock prices fell sharply Friday, with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbling more than 71 points. Bargain-hunters who might normally enter the market after a sharp loss stayed one the sidelines Monday, said Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. Jarrett described traders as apathetic. Analysts said many traders were waiting to see what trend might emerge from the Tokyo Stock Exchange, which was closed Monday for a holiday. The Japanese stock market had its worst decline in two years Friday, contributing to Wall Street's dismal performance. Among standouts on the NYSE Monday, Rorer Group soared 13} to 63 after the pharmaceutical firm said it was negotating with an unidentified merger partner. Sea Containers plunged 7] to 59] after Temple Holdings Ltd. said it would drop a hostile offer for Sea Containers if the ferry company agreed to sell substantial parts of its ferry and container assets to Temple. Monsanto fell 4[ to 112{ after an investment firm lowered its rating of the chemical maker. Ralston Purina rose 1\ to 83{ after setting $84.25 a share as the price it will pay for 2.5 million shares in a stock buyback. Philip Morris led the NYSE's most active list, falling | to 38[. Among other blue chip issues, AT&T fell | to 42|, IBM rose \ to 98[, and General Motors fell ] to 41\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market fell $28.681 billion, or 0.87 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped 1.61 to 186.71. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.27 to 387.45, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 2.93 to close at 337.00. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 3.08 to 439.74. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 368.58, down 3.65.

DOC.HEAD: Pharmaceutical Company Stock Soars Amid Merger Talks
DOC.TEXT: Rorer Group Inc. stock soared Monday after the drugmaker said it was negotiating a deal to sell a 68 percent stake to another company. A merger would be the latest consolidation in the worldwide pharmaceutical industry, which has been reshaped by major unions among big-name companies in the last year. Rorer stock was up $13.75 to $63, or 28 percent, in late New York Stock Exchange trading in very heavy volume. Final stock prices was not available due to telephone line problems. Rorer, based in suburban Fort Washington, said in a statement it was negotiating a ``strategic transaction'' with an unidentified company that would acquire 68 percent of Rorer's outstanding common shares. Rorer said the deal was designed to make it ``a larger, stronger worldwide pharmaceutical company.'' It said the company would remain publicly traded and that current shareholders would retain a position of about 32 percent. The statement said the transaction is ``modeled'' on a merger last July in which Dow Chemical Co. last July agreed to acquire 67 percent of Marion Laboratories Inc. stock over the next two to three years. Rorer spokesman John Donahue declined to elaborate on the statement. In addition to the Dow-Marion deal, other multibillion-dollar mergers over the last year included SmithKline Beckman Corp. with Britain's Beecham Group PLC and Bristol-Myers Co. with Squibb Corp. Also, American Home Products Corp. agreed to acquire A.H. Robins Co. and Eastman Kodak Co. bought Sterling Drug. Inc. Edward Stavetski, an industry analyst with W.H. Newbold's Son & Co. in Philadelphia, said Rorer may be seeking to remain stay competitive in light of the recent merger wave. ``The rest of the drug industry has forced this,'' he said, adding that he believed the acquiring company would likely be foreign. Analyst Michael Martorelli with Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia said there was speculation last week that Rorer was negotiating a merger and its stock climbed on the rumors. Rorer's statement said current shareholders would receive a package including cash and securities valued at $73 a share. That price may have triggered the large jump in Rorer stock on Monday, analysts said. Rorer develops, makes and markets prescription and over-the-counter drugs and hospital products in more than 100 countries. Rorer is planning to build new headquarters in Upper Providence Township outside Philadelphia. Another major pharmaceutical company, Sterling Drug, has plans to build a new research and development complex in the same area.

DOC.HEAD: US Chip Consortium Dissolves After Failing To Draw Adequate Support
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Memories, a joint venture created to expand America's small share of the computer chip market, is dissolving because of inadequate financial support from the industry, it was announced Monday. ``What we saw was an unwillingness to support sufficient equity as well as purchase commitments to go forward,'' said company president Sanford L. Kane. At the same time, he criticized the industry for concentrarting on short-term tactics rather than long-term strategy. U.S. Memories, hailed by American companies when it was formed last June to invest $1 billion in a chip-making plant, decided to terminate the venture after a meeting Wednesday in Dallas with the original seven investing companies and four other potential backers. Two original backers, International Business Machines Corp. and Digital Equipment Corp., maintained their major commitment to the venture, but Kane said the others were not willing to put up enough money to fund the venture's first plant or agree to buy enough of its 4-megabit dynamic random access memory chips, or DRAMs. ``From early on we all knew the viability of U.S. Memories was contingent on (that),'' Kane said at a news conference. American computer companies depend heavily on foregin manufacturers _ primarily those in Japan _ for DRAMS, a common form of chip important in computers, household appliances and the U.S. defense system. They often are compared to crude oil in their importance to industry. U.S. Memories, which estimated that American companies currently supply no more than 10 percent of the American demand for the chips, hoped to produce 25 percent of the DRAMS needed by U.S. computer companies. Inadequate supply and high cost of DRAMs prompted the formation of U.S. Memories last year. In addition to IBM and Digital, original investors included Hewlett-Packard Co., Intel Corp., Advanced Micro Devices Inc., National Semiconductor Corp. and LSI Logic. But since then, supply has increased and the price has dropped, largely because several new companies, including Samsung of South Korea, have begun making the chips, according to analysts. U.S. companies needing DRAMs apparently no longer think they have a problem, Kane said. J. Richard Iverson, president of the American Electronics Association, which supports efforts to increase the U.S. share of the chip market, said, ``I don't know what we could have done more.'' ``There's no way of coercing companies into doing what we think is right _ or what they think is right. These are individual business decisions,'' he said. Kane also would not criticize electronics companies for their individual decisions not to give U.S. Memories as much financial support as the consortium hoped. But he was ``extremely disappointed'' and worried about the future of America's electronics industry. ``What happens today does not bode well ... ``It is a sign of where we are going,'' said Kane, who said the developments showed an inability of American electronics companies to cooperate. ``We're kind of like an all-star sports team. We have a number of superstars who are individually great in their way but can't work together,'' he said. U.S. Memories originally planned to pay for the computer chip plant with $500 million in equity financing from chip makers and users and $500 million in debt, with fund raising expected to be completed last year. The consortium later decided it would need $400 million in debt and $350 million in equity _ $150 million from industry investors and the rest from outside backers. Computer companies, however, also would have had to agree to buy 75 to 80 percent of the consortium's DRAMs. But the plant was never built and no chips were produced. Despite Monday's announcement, Kane said the venture had produced some positive results. ``We did achieve some significant things in the process,'' Kane said. ``We showed that with some creativity and support and teamwork we could come up with a solution within the American framework. We clearly increased the impact of the seimconductor industry and DRAMs in particular.''

DOC.HEAD: ALPA Votes to Extend Strike Benefits to Eastern Pilots
DOC.TEXT: The Air Line Pilots Association announced Monday that a majority of its members had voted to continue payments through the end of February to Eastern Airlines pilots who had been on strike and still haven't found jobs. The vote called for maintaining strike benefits, but at a reduced level, through the end of next month. ALPA spokeswoman Julie Reneau declined to provide the vote tally, saying only that a simple majority of the returned ballots was needed to maintain the payments. ``I'm grateful to them,'' Skip Copeland, head of the ALPA chapter at Eastern, said in a telephone interview from Miami. ``It sustains the Eastern pilots a little while longer while we get our life back in order.'' Most of the 2,400 or so striking Eastern pilots voted Nov. 22 to abandon their nine-month sympathy walkout, after President Bush vetoed legislation to set up a blue-ribbon commission to look into the strike. None of the pilots, or the flight attendants who ended their strike soon afterward, were subsequently taken back by Eastern _ which had hired non-union replacement workers and accepted some striking workers who crossed picket lines earlier. The Machinists union remains on strike against the Miami-based carrier. The 40,000 or so ALPA members nationwide had been paying about 3 percent of their salary to their Eastern colleagues. The benefits to Eastern pilots have averaged about $2,400 a month per flier since the walkout began last March 4. Following the new ALPA vote, the benefits will be cut to an average $1,600 a month on Jan. 14 and to $1,400 a month on Feb. 1. They will end on Feb. 28.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Reports Fourth-Quarter Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. said Monday its fourth-quarter earnings declined 1 percent, partly because of higher research and development costs and its stock buyback program. NCR said it earned $147 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, down from $149 million in the same period a year earlier. The company reported per-share earnings of $2.02, up from $1.85 a year earlier. NCR said it repurchased 9 million shares during 1989, which raised its per-share performance but helped lower its overall earnings. Fourth-quarter revenue totaled $1.79 billion, down slightly from last year's $1.8 billion, NCR said. NCR attributed the earnings decline to higher investment in research and development, lower revenue and gross profit margins and the stock repurchase program. The company said it partially offset those declines by reducing operating expenses. For the full year, NCR earned $412 million, down 6 percent from the $439 million it posted in 1988. Per-share earnings were $5.38, up from $5.33 the previous year. The company's 1989 revenue totaled $5.96 billion, down 1 percent from the $5.99 billion of the previous year. The company makes, sells and services business information processing systems for worldwide markets.

DOC.HEAD: New Campbell CEO Asks Dissident Shareholders To Give Him A Year
DOC.TEXT: The new head of Campbell Soup Co. said Monday that he believed the troubled foods giant could show different operating results within a year, but he wanted to focus more on long-term gains. David W. Johnson, Campbell's new president and chief executive, also told a news conference that the best way to keep the 120-year-old company independent was for its controlling Dorrance family _ recently beset by bickering over whether to sell Campbell _ to hold on to its shares. Campbell's board of directors appointed Johnson on Jan. 3, saying the 57-year-old Australian was brought from Gerber Products Co. because of his experience in turning around beleaguered companies. In addition to recently lackluster financial results, Campbell faces dissension among its biggest shareholders over whether to sell the company. A group led by three grandchildren of company founder John T. Dorrance Sr., which owns 17.4 percent of Campbell's stock, has announced it wants to sell its stake and encouraged the board of directors to put the entire company on the block. Three other Dorrance grandchildren who own 31.3 percent of the stock say they want to keep their shares and maintain the company's independence. ``I don't think there's anything wrong with a family to have disagreements,'' Johnson said. He said the best way for the company to maintain its independence was for the Dorrance heirs to keep their shares. Johnson arrived at Gerber in 1987, after the baby food company's market share had dropped to 52 percent from 67 percent. The decline was attributed to a safety scare after glass shards were found in some of the company's products, although the Food and Drug Administration later absolved Gerber of any responsibility for the problem. At Gerber, Johnson sold off businesses unrelated to the baby food operations and made other changes credited for a financial performance that enabled the company to raise its dividends from 66 cents per share in 1987 to the present 96 cents per share. Johnson replaces R. Gordon McGovern, who announced his early retirement in November after serving as president and chief executive since 1980. Analysts have said that unhappy shareholders forced McGovern's retirement. Johnson told an audience of about 200 Campbell employees that in the the company's restructuring, ``there will inevitably be divestitures and redundancies. ``We will try to become leaner and meaner through natural attrition; that is by not replacing people who leave or retire,'' he said. However, Johnson also told reporters that it was too early to advocate either divestitures or acquisitions for the company, which had $5.7 billion in sales in fiscal 1989. ``I came here with no predispositions,'' Johnson said. ``I came in here really to do my homework.'' Johnson said the company falls at the bottom of the food products industry in its earnings per share growth, which has been 8 percent to 9 percent annually in recent years. That number should be in the 12 percent to 15 percent range, he said. In its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 29 Campbell posted a profit of $83 million, or 64 cents a share, on sales of $1.52 billion, compared with a profit of $69.4 million, or 54 cents per share, on sales of $1.33 billion a year earlier.

Editors:
Informatively, Campeau Corp. now says it will not release to the media this evening copies of its bankruptcy filing for its U.S. retailing divisions, as it earlier indicated it would.
AP Business News

DOC.HEAD: Apple Says Expenses, Jobs Will Be Cut
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. said Monday it will cut its work force, possibly in part through layoffs, and will freeze some salaries for six months because of slumping revenues. The personal computer maker also announced that it was eliminating company cars for U.S.-based executives and cutting back its profit-sharing plan. Though first-quarter figures will not be ready until Thursday, ``we know that revenues and profits will not meet our expectations for this quarter,'' John Sculley, Apple's chairman, president and chief executive officer, said in a letter to the company's 12,000 employees. ``In various parts of the world, Apple's growth is slower than we anticipated in our (fiscal year 1990) business plan. Given these results, we are re-examining our outlook for (fiscal year) 1990 and are taking immediate actions to bring expense growth better in line with revenue growth.'' Sculley did not say how many jobs could be eliminated. He said there would be ``normal head count attrition,'' a ``significant drop in hiring activity,'' consolidation of some areas and transfers of some employees. ``It will also be necessary to eliminate positions,'' he said. ``We're not ruling out layoffs,'' said company spokeswoman Carla LeVasseur. She said the only recent layoffs involved 60 employees in Canada on Dec. 13. In addition, 100 employees in the U.S. sales and marketing divisions were ``redeployed'' in September, she said, taking new assignments within Apple or leaving the company. Ms. LeVasseur blamed the company's slump on a general slowdown in the computer industry. But Apple also has been hurt by sagging sales of some of its leading product lines, particularly several models of the Macintosh and the Apple II personal computers, during a time in which it stressed more powerful models for corporate use. Sculley's letter said all professional-level employees would move from a six-month to a 12-month salary review schedule, effective immediately. Ms. LeVasseur said this meant they would get no raises for at least six months. Vice presidents and executive staff members, who got no regular raises last year, will also get none this year. The profit-sharing plan, which paid $49.4 million to employees last year, will be scaled back on April to a plan that ``is more closely tied to Apple's financial performance goals,'' Sculley said. Ms. LeVasseur said the phase-out of company automobiles by April 1 would affect over 100 U.S. executives.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Gulf Announces Recapitalization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Georgia Gulf Corp., which has been trying to fend off corporate raider Harold C. Simmons, said Monday its board approved a debt-financed recapitalization plan that would give stockholders a one-time cash payment. Under the plan, which is subject to approval by stockholders and government regulators, each share of common stock could be converted into cash and new shares of stock, the company said. No date has been set for a stockholders' meeting, the Atlanta-based chemical company said. Georgia Gulf said the recapitalization will be financed with up to $730 million of debt and the sale of about $200 million in debentures, with financing backed by Chase Manhattan Bank, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Security Pacific National Bank and Goldman, Sachs & Co. Under the plan, each share of the company's common stock could be converted into $38 cash, one share of a new series of preferred stock and one new share of common stock. Stockholders will have the option of converting up to 30 percent of their common shares into ``a number of shares'' of the new common stock, instead of taking the cash, preferred stock and common. Georgia Gulf estimated the value of the deal will be up to $55 a share, depending on the number of stockholders who opt to receive only common stock. The company had been examining ways to boost its stock price since Simmons' Dallas-based NL Industries began acquiring Georgia Gulf stock last summer. No tender offer has been made, but NL Industries has acquired about 9.9 percent of Georgia Gulf stock at an average price of $37 per share, NL Industries officials said. NL Industries has said it would not oppose a recapitalization if it resulted in Georgia Gulf stock hitting $50 a share. Calls to Simmons and his associates were not answered late Monday. Under Georgia Gulf's recapitalization plan, the preferred stock would be ``redeemable at the company's option at any time'' and have a redemption value of $17 a share, the company said. However, the preferred stock is ``expected to trade at a price per share that is significantly less than the redemption price,'' the company said. Georgia Gulf said the plan ``is intended to maximize stockholder value in the near term'' while safeguarding the stockholders' long-term investment in the company.

DOC.HEAD: $60 Million Lawsuit Against Texas Air Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A $60 million lawsuit filed by 273 former Continental Airlines pilots against Texas Air Corp., the parent company of Continental, was dismissed Monday, Texas Air said. The ex-pilots claimed that Texas Air had guaranteed Continental's adherence to a collective bargaining agreement that was terminated after Continental filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code in 1983. The state court granted a motion by Texas Air attorneys for a summary judgment on all the pilot's claims, the company said. Spokesmen for the Air Line Pilots Association in Houston and Washington, D.C., were not in their offices and could not be reached for comment immediately. The Texas case is the largest of three suits brought by former pilots seeking to hold Texas Air responsible for damages under a side letter to the pilot's 1982 labor agreement. A side letter is an agreement between a union and company that is not part of the actual labor contract. One case, involving 48 ex-pilots, is pending in a Colorado state court. Another suit was dismissed last year by a Houston federal judge and is under appeal. Houston-based Continental emerged from Chapter 11 in 1986, and has largely completed payments under its plan of reorganization. Texas Air, also based in Houston, also owns Eastern Airlines.

David W. MacEachron, who led the Japan Society for 15 years and advocated close American-Japanese economic cooperation, died Saturday of colon cancer. He was 66. He was executive director and later president of the non-profit Japan Society, which promotes understanding between that country and the United States. He retired in 1989. During his tenure, MacEachron boosted the society's endowment by about $20 million and increased its role in encouraging cross-cultural friendship through film festivals, stage performances, art exhibits and conferences. He also was program director and later vice president of the Council on Foreign Relations between 1962 and 1974 in New York.

Laurence J. Peter, whose ``Peter Principle'' held that bureaucratic problems often occur because employees routinely are promoted beyond their competence, died Sunday of natural causes. He was 70. Peter and Raymond Hull wrote the 1969 best-seller, ``The Peter Principle: Why Things Always Go Wrong,'' a satirical chronicle of incompetence based on Peter's experience with educational and other bureaucracies. His book sold 8 million copies, was translated into more than 30 languages and is still available in paperback. Peter followed ``The Peter Principle'' with eight other books, including ``The Peter Prescription: How to Make Things Go Right'' in 1972 and ``The Peter Plan: A Proposal for Survival'' in 1975. Peter is survived by his wife, sons John and Edward, daughters Alice and Margaret and three grandchildren.

Frank LeRoux, a former U.S. Department of Agriculture official and a passionate champion of American agriculture, died Sunday at 82. The cause of death was not disclosed. In 1961, LeRoux was appointed general sales manager of the Agriculture Department's Commodities Credit Corp. His work earned him a presidential merit award, presented by Lyndon B. Johnson. But when LeRoux resigned his post in 1966, he lashed out at the administrations of presidents John F. Kennedy and Johnson, calling that period ``the worst five-year period in agriculture.'' He then wrote a book entitled: ``1961 Through 1964: The Farmers' Worst Five Years.'' LeRoux published three more books on the problems of American agriculture. His fourth book, ``The Myth of U.S. Agricultural Prosperity,'' tells of his disillusionment with the political treatment of his fellow farmers.
